I don’t how they’re correlated with Duke because this hospital was horrible. Spent 4 hours in the ER just for them to say I’m good and sent me home with nothing.
It was turbo waiting 9 hr for a room, and no one said anything, playing around the deck, don't think I'll be back here, will go to UNC Rex hospital R Chapel Hill UNC hospital

Drove 4 hours to go to the emergency room at Duke hospital to get help was told they are the best but I disagree the waiting period is ridiculous I have been in this waiting area for 6 hours now and still counting now sure how you come in hurting really bad and they stick an IV in which by the way was very uncomfortable and unprofessional blood got all over my clothing.
Was hooked up to fluids and give pain meds and then stuck out in the waiting area no impressed at all I pray the doctor are good cause a 4 hour drive to be stuck for 6 plus hours waiting just cause they were bragged about oh no never again
absolutely the slowest hospital I've ever been to in my life (and I've been to a lot). don't go here if you are dying... you will most certainly die while waiting

We have been sitting in the waiting room ever since 3:40pm Thursday September 24, 2025 now it’s 12:54AM Friday September 25, 2025. What kind of Emergency Room is this. Duke Hospital in Durham NC is not what it used to be!!!!
This hospital has poor service I’d rather be seen at duke regional anyday over this trash hospital

Brilliant. Extraordinary. I didn’t feel like going back home (for real!) as I loved the care!!

Starting my care at Duke ER, Nurse April noted all my issues well, and I was later seen by Nurse Rona who administered the painkillers through IV and informed me about every detail. I was then seen by Dr. Priyanka Sista who ordered a CT Contrast immediately and calmed me down when I was very overwhelmed. I wanted to run away (due to being so jittery), but she explained to me how important it was to get checked out properly. She transferred my case to Duke Neurology under the exceptional care team led by Dr. Stephanie Reyes. Special shoutout to Nurse Megan and Nurse Rebecca on 8th floor DCT for giving me the best professional care I could ever deserve. Thank you so much Megan & Becky! Also to NA Lucy for always checking my vitals on time without any delay. Team led by Dr. Reyes was very professional & methodical - she loves answering questions & queries and seems to be a very nice person overall. Much gratitude to Dr. Athavi Jeevananthan for staying in touch throughout the course of action especially re: endocrinology. They made sure all my imaging and blood work were negative, and the major issues were ruled out pretty quickly. Very professional, a very empathetic experience. I have so much respect for all the people in the healthcare world. Thank you so very much. I’m so grateful ❤️❤️.

My mom had a stroke and was treated at Duke. I am so thankful to every nurse, aide and  each doctor that helped us during a very scary time for our family. The medical care was excellent. What I will never forget is the time, the kindness and love that was shown. 8th floor angels I can never thank you enough.

The ER information desk workers were extremely loud laughing and talking when they didn’t have patients checking in. It was very unprofessional! There were many patients in the lobby, each quiet keeping to themselves. Several were trying to sleep while they waited. My son was there waiting for over 11 hours. The communication was lacking. One nurse and the doctor was great but that’s it. I do appreciate the service they provide and the volume of people they see but the unprofessional behavior was shocking. I even heard 2 nurses sharing they were calling out, one of them was going to a concert. Others were seen watching reels while taking patients to X-ray. Definitely not the level of professionalism I expected from such a prestigious named hospital.

- left me alone in labor and on pitocin for over 4 hours unchecked. When they finally checked me baby was coming out and had been for some time.

Ended up having a C-section because baby was losing her heart beat which could have been avoided.

-Most nurses were great after finally coming to see me. In recovery I had a nurse who came in angry that my baby was crying. Is she stupid?

Anyway. Y'all need to have protocols for checking women that are in labor and not leaving them alone for hours on end and in great pain.

Duke Hospital's Radiology Department is the worst. I have had a referral from a non-Duke Doctor for a CT cardiac scan since mid August and they claim to have not received it via fax, yet my doctor and I have sent it over at least 5 times and here we are in mid September and they still claim to have not received it. Mind you, I have a fax confirmation number! This is the worst customer service ever and the staff seems to be lazy. Unreal.

We were pleased with Duke University Hospital. Husband has serious illness which requires constant treatment. Hospital stays are very good and they do their best to make a very stressful time better. Cancer center doctors listen to you and no one minded that I remained in the room all night with him.
Worst hospital ever! Do NOT come here for any type of emergency.. you will sit here for a minimum of 8hrs.. no matter what you’re here for.
Born here, would be born here again.

Valet brought car back smelling like weed. They haven’t even refunded the $16 for the service that I asked for. We will be going to UNC from here on out, ridiculous and absurd to have your car smell like shitty weed when leaving hospital.
Sent a man home in the same shape he went there in. Had a whole stroke, can’t walk, falling, sick with covid. They suck

Dr Fecci saved my life, he removed a malignant brain tumor almost 9 years ago & I’m cancer free.  The entire  staff was amazing!  I was treated  with much respect at & dignity.  The whole staff was so kind.  I came from NE 2 have the surgery & their recommendations 4 treatment post surgery.  I had chemo & radiation & had very few issues due 2 the surgery & treatment.  I’m so thankful 4 this amazing facility  & staff.  I knew they were renowned 4 their brain cancer center.  It is a well run gray facility with amazing g physicians  & staff members from the techs 2 the assistants &  social services personnel eho were extremely helpful as well as the billing dept.  please tell Denise Lolly we said ji& if she wants any more Runxas  2 let us know.  We’d n happy 2 send her several.  Runxa will ship them directly2 her!  Funny how if u r far from home u still can find a person who has a connection too. 2 your home & state in some way.  She’s an incredible lady as well!  So very talented & kind!  There r not enough things I can say, other that I was blessed 2 have gotten 2 them & God  guided me 2 them & over them as they did my surgery.  Thank u 4 my life, Dr Fecci &  staff!  God Bless all of u!

I’m writing this as I am sitting here with my daughter.
Nurse  Lucy Marie is doing an amazing, outstanding job.
From explaining what she is doing to making sure not only my daughter but also making sure I was comfortable.
5 stars to her

Update:Dr.Aquino was amazing as well
Very nice gentleman who explained things very thoroughly to me.

I really have a distain for this hospital.. Not because the staff or the efforts towards patients but whomever makes policy’s and how the employees are treated.. My wife worked there for 5 years we had a baby the didn’t give her maternity leave with pay because she didn’t work a certain amount of hrs n a year.. This is mind blowing people put all that time in throughout the years to get paid crumbs n denied necessities. Exactly why staff protesting and quitting

Review for Dr. Christopher P. Eckstein, MD – Duke Hospital

I’m 21 years old and recently had a very disappointing experience with Dr. Eckstein. I was referred to him by my previous Duke neurologist, who treated me as a child for autoimmune encephalitis (AE). Since that doctor has since moved from NC, he recommended I see Dr. Eckstein because he is the head of neurology. He also mentioned that I could consider going to Mayo Clinic—and honestly, I should have taken that advice.

Despite my documented history of AE and worsening symptoms, Dr. Eckstein completely dismissed my concerns. He repeatedly said, "I'm not saying you're crazy,"—but saying that multiple times made it feel like exactly what he was implying. It was condescending, unprofessional, and left me feeling unheard and invalidated.

I tried to explain that I’ve been experiencing episodes of severe headaches and intense neck stiffness that last for a week at a time—symptoms so painful that I can’t move my head, look up or down, or even turn my neck. I’ve had three of these episodes this year alone. Instead of taking this seriously or considering the context of my medical history, he told me it was "just a headache" and "everyone your age gets those." That is simply not true, and I know my body well enough to recognize when something is very wrong. He told me after we discussed my neurological symptoms he said my symptoms were residual anxiety and OCD from when I had AE as a child, but I couldn't possibly have that now because I don't look like I'm on deaths door.

He ultimately suggested I see a psychologist. While mental health is important, that recommendation felt like a dismissal of my legitimate neurological symptoms. As someone with a known history of autoimmune encephalitis, I expected to be evaluated seriously—not brushed off and told my symptoms were normal for a 21-year-old.

This appointment felt like a complete waste of time, and I left feeling worse than when I walked in. I would strongly caution others, especially young adults or patients with complex neurological histories, to seek care elsewhere if you want to be listened to and taken seriously.

My daughter was admitted because she had a virus and she was dehydrated. The pediatric cardiac nurses Rihannon and Maddy took such good care of us and all the doctors and nurses were amazing. I trust Duke so much!
They saved my sons life.
Exceptional care from start to finish from reception, nursing, radiology, surgical staff, and consulting providers on my care. Very clean and orderly in all areas.

Never go to this hospital if you are looking for compassionate, accountable care.  The medical team members are so burnt out they have no empathy left. This leads to medical errors and mistakes. They will also judge you before actually assessing or diagnosing you appropriately; so please be very careful and bring another person with you for your own protection so staff do not take advantage of your vulnerable medical state (observed by a RN/NP of 25 years).

I can only say that all the staff and doctors were angels in my life! Every person working there does so with so much love and professionalism! They had to transfer me in an emergency due to a high-risk pregnancy. I was on absolute bed rest and they took care of me every day. However, my baby was born by emergency cesarean section. The doctor who attended to me during delivery was an excellent doctor and his team!!! They did everything possible so that my 23-week-old baby could survive, however, he didn't make it and died on the third day after birth. However, every doctor gave their empathy and professionalism to me and my baby!! I am only grateful for everything they did for me!! I am also very grateful to my baby's social worker, Ismael Erazo. The social worker took care of all the paperwork to process my baby's death. A very noble woman with a very big heart, despite being Hispanic, the treatment was very effective and dedicated! God bless every doctor and every staff member who works there! Thank you for everything!
The hospital served my mom's needs well.
place sucks especially valet parking

As a preganant women that also is seen at the high risk clinic for the 1st lost her  20 week baby.now pregnant again I was urgently rushed to labor and delivery for my 2nd cervix shortening for cerclage and was told but doctor #1 it HAD to happen today. When we arrived to check in no one knew anything about it. Once we finally got into a room we were stationed there for more than 9 hours with no food and no water.Doctor #2  had to stay over night because they were short staff and no one could do the surgery. Which seem to be a normal thing for labor and delivery. Buecause thr amounts of c_sections. We stayed over night due to the fact we were promised to be the 1st for day shift to do our surgery. When day shift came they still did not see us until mid afternoon.again no food or water for pregnant  women. When you advocate for yourself they tell you you HAVE TO TAKE DRUGS. EVEN IF YOU DONT WANT TO.They do not keep their promises and do not have enough hightly skilled physicians. But they do have TONS of RESIDENCE  to practice on you. Please preganant women try to fine a better choice for you and your baby.

作者: TV HOST STANLEY B WILSON JR
評論內容:
**Review Title: A Truly Disheartening Experience**

I had the unfortunate experience of visiting this hospital, and I can honestly say it was one of the worst I've encountered. While the doctors are skilled and knowledgeable, the rest of the staff leaves much to be desired.

The security department is particularly rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful situation even more difficult. It's hard to believe that such a crucial role in patient care could be filled by individuals with such a lack of empathy.

The kitchen staff was unhelpful and unpleasant, which only added to the frustration. The housekeeping staff was acceptable, but the overall atmosphere in the hospital felt negative and unwelcoming.

My son is undergoing treatment for cancer, a time when compassion and support are desperately needed. Unfortunately, the staff here seemed to have no understanding of that. The transporters who move patients around were also unfriendly and seemed to add to the misery rather than alleviate it.

This facility left me feeling more distressed than when I arrived. I would not recommend this hospital to anyone, not even to a dog. The attitude of some staff members was downright appalling, and I will never return here again.

Excellent hospital, clinics, and staff.  Competent, honest, and professional.  I’ve been a patient in many hospitals in my life and this one is phenomenal!  Excellent communication with providers and staff.  The only problem is paid parking. I highly recommend this place for  complex specialized care.

I visited your hospital today to see my sick mother. I flew in from key west Florida because of her condition. Been a long time since I seen my mother…. I would suggest reviewing your security department by the emergency room entrance video footage 7-14-2025 at approximately 6:30pm. The heavy set older woman with the nasty and combative attitude would not let us finish a sentence to explain to her the doctor was waving me and my sister in together. Haven’t seen my mom in 10 years and her mental state was not good, she doesn’t know even what I look like. What a horrible experience dealing with someone so combative and aggressive, even to the point she was combative and rude to the young gentleman working the stand. She locked the door and refused us entry and wouldn’t let us explain to her the doctor is waving us in together. We were instructed by the front desk staff, they told us to return in 10 minutes, the literal nursing staff is waving us through and your security finds it amusing to lock us in and talk aggressively to us? Remember people are here dealing with emotional circumstances…. If my mother wasn’t sick and didn’t need me, your facilities would have been attending to your staff. Completely unacceptable behavior, I heard her nasty mouth as we walked away.. one day your staff is going to find out the hard way.
I've been with Duke for 12 years by far the best hospital ive ever been to.

This hospital is not everything it is hyped up to be. Today I was brought to the ER with very bad chest pains, a racing heart and my head felt very spacey. I layed in a hospital bed for 6 hours in the hall wall and was
Never assigned a dr, a nurse or a room. About an hour after I was laying in the hall a dr who told me she wasn’t going to be my dr stopped by to see me and told me she wanted a complete cardiac work up since I had been having problems with chest pains for a few days. That was
The last time I ever saw a Dr. thought many walked passed me up and down the hall. Someone did come and get an EKG and I did get a chest X-ray after the X-ray tech waited for an hour for someone to bring me to get the X-ray. She said transport probably couldn’t find me because I was never assigned a dr or a nurse. As I lay in the hall more and more people were brought in by ems and just left unattended in the hallways just as I was. The final straw was when a nurse who brought a man from the waiting room into a room that had been empty for an hour right across from me. I’m glad I was not having a heart attack. No one would have been there to notice. I was not hooked up to a heart monitor or anything. Most of the people in the ER halls were elderly and brought in by EMS. People with chest pains and patients brought in by EMS should take priority. (As long as the hospital is not being used for a bandaid). This hospital is nothing more than a luxery Mariah Parham. Aka Murder Parham. If it wasn’t for my surgeon being the best surgeon in the world I’d leave Duke all together.

I had 3 back surgeries at Duke. The last two times there the care was awful. Nurses and assistants with the exception is a select few. I did not feel safe there at all. I had problems with low blood pressure.  No one would ever come check on my beeping monitor. One night just after surgery I told the charge nurse I felt like I needed to throw up.  No one came in until about an hour later. I was yelling at the top of my lungs for a nurse. I had thrown up all over myself. That’s just one example. Make the trip to Raleigh to UNC. Hopefully they are better about caring about their patients.

I was recently in North Carolina to visit my friend and unfortunately my son got allergic reactions. I called 911 and luckily the paramedics came very quickly. This is where everything started going down hill. The paramedics seemed very unprofessional in how they were handling my son. The paramedics recommended duke university. Little did I know, he recommended this because his friends were in that hospital. We went to Duke university and from minute one, I just didn’t like the environment. The nurses seemed to be chilling and chatting about their breakups while my son is getting severe allergic reactions. They seemed unempathetic to the whole situation. Patients were all over the area and no one seemed to care much about them. The whole hospital made my wife sick. Once they found a room for my son, all the nurses were very unprofessional and looked to be students rather than professionals. They couldn’t find the vein of my son for injections and the hygiene seemed very low. They didn’t show any signs of empathy when my child was crying the whole time. This whole experience was awful and made me never want to come back there. They would just put the syringes on the bed while my son is there and wouldn’t care to comfort him when he was crying.

Furthermore, the nurses/doctors would just walk in without knocking on the door. Male doctors would just walk in while my wife is breastfeeding the baby. We warned them that we didn’t feel comfortable with that and to let us know if a male doctor was coming in. Next time, a male doctor came in without knocking and this put my wife in a vulnerable position. I really disliked this and the nurses and doctors should have known better. I would never go back to this hospital.

I had an extremely disappointing and hurtful experience at Duke after giving birth. The staff treated me poorly during a time when I needed care. To make things worse, they made me walk out of the hospital carrying my newborn baby in my arms in the cold with no proper assistance or concern for our well-being. I expected professionalism, but instead, I felt neglected and mistreated. No mother should be treated like this after childbirth.

Duke Health has some of the most frustrating billing practices I have ever encountered. They frequently modify bills without providing a clear and detailed breakdown of the charges. Additionally, patients cannot set a minimum payment; they must comply with whatever amount is demanded. The assignment of multiple representatives to a single account leads to unnecessary confusion, especially when others need access to your information. Notes are often inadequately maintained or communicated late in the month, if they are communicated at all—even when legal representation is involved. This is completely unacceptable.

It is also well-known that they faced legal action in 2019 for overbilling and using similar tactics. Furthermore, the surgery wing has the poorest mattresses and bedding I have ever experienced, along with dirty rooms and mediocre services. I do not recommend going here at all.

This hospital has been good to me. I went to get a x-ray and was throwing up blood. They rushed me to the emergency room and took test and took great care of me and I ended up staying for three days and had bleeding ulcers.

My brother was seen in the emergency room. My son and I were sitting in the lobby while my brother was being seen. He was discharged at 3:00 AM (today, June 2nd). A nurse came up and asked me was a patient or was I there with someone. I told her my brother had just been discharged. She asked me for his name. When I told her she told me that nobody by that name was seen in the emergency room. I picked the papers up and showed her. I guess she was upset that I showed her the papers after she tried to play me. She was very rude and said I had to leave. They pick and choose who they want to approach in the lobby.

Every time my family or I go to this hospital it’s always a lady sleep in the same corner. They never say anything to her.

I’ll just go to UNC from now on. I’ve been there twice and I’ve never heard or seen any of the staff be rude or disrespectful towards anyone in any kind of way!

Never visit them o/w you will end up paying unjustified bills throughout your life, they just try to do everything to make more and more bills, no matter if you have just a fever. pathetic place, rude customer care with no management.

Worst service ever. I took my friend who has sores on the back of her throat she couldn't drink and she couldn't eat because of how painful it was. We sat there for five hours not once did we get seen. One nurse acted like giving us a blanket would be the end of the world. I even seen her threaten to kick a poor lady out when she was asking why her bracelet changed after she had it on for a hour. Absolutely horrible, there were some nice nurses but I felt they didn't see us as important. Do better. Going to wake med next.

The nursing staff here is absolutely horrible. There are very few, and I mean few that actually care about the patient. The charge nurse on the 6th floor didn’t even know what HIPPA is, which is very concerning. The secretaries answer the call lights with the worst attitudes like they are being bothered. I believe most of this staff were hired just to make sure the numbers were right because they are so short staffed. It’s no excuse for them to be so awful.

Arrived at the ED for eye necrosis. Was taking into a room so small for the procedures on my eyes, that the doctors did not have enough counter space to even lay out the tools needed to perform the task. I compared it to a closet. The doctors were great and made it was but was constantly bumping into items in the room and fumbling around the room on every move. The lighting was poor and the amount of stuff packed into the "procedure room" made it feel very unsafe since there was needles going into my eyes. That needs a major upgrade. Shout out to the doctors making it work and being optimistic the whole time.

Hello all, first let me commend all the medical staff except for the night time   CNA Areeb. I reported to Areeb that I had a bowel movement and that they may need a stool sample. When he checked he stated he would check to see if the specimen was needed, which he never did and partially rinsed out the collection bowl and he left feces in the bowl and it was smeared over the toilet seat. I'm being treated for lymph node infection so I am very susceptible to infections. Myself and my wife had to clean and sterilize the commode.

11 years ago I walked into this place and they saved my life.  I had never seen such quality of care.  The events of this past weekend were troubling.  I was manhandled and laughed at, intentionally hurt, billed for services that never happened and received "care" from sub-par staff.  After telling a staff member the line was NOT in my vein she flushed it anyway, filling my elbow with flush and causing extreme pain. I had to remove it myself because this "nurse" didn't have a single clue as to what she was doing.  Was supposed to have a referral and they messed that up as well by referring to the wrong department.  When I called for correction they were unwilling to help.  After asking to speak to a supervisor or patient advocate I was put on hold.  After 20 minutes I hung up.

My wife had an appointment setup for tomorrow and they called her today and said they canceled her appointment. She went through all the paperwork and stuff online and they tell her today that they can’t see her because they don’t do second opinions. What kind a place treat people this way. They actually told my wife they couldn’t see her because she was seen by another doctor in the past. Are your people incompetent and uncaring. Well my family definitely won’t be referring anyone there.

Duke Hospital is the reason my father is dead. He was viable to receive kidney transplant and even had a family member lined up to donate, but instead of giving us a list of things that needed to happen before transplant could be done, Duke made him jump through hoop after meaningless hoop, one at a time, until his body was no longer viable to receive that transplant. He would still be here with me if we had gone to another hospital to attempt to transplant him. He did not have to die. Take your loved ones somewhere else, please.

I was going through some very severe life ending health issues and Duke University Hospital and my medical care team did everything possible to help save my life, though there are some health issues that can't be resolved, my life still exists because of Duke University Hospital!

I made an appointment to see a Duke University neurosurgeon.  I presented with extreme malaise, nausea, and neck pain.  My cobalt levels were through the roof.  I happened to have a MobiC cervical  disc replacement made of cobalt and chromium. I was hopeful to get it explanted. The surgeon told me there was no way my high cobalt levels were caused by the cobalt device in my neck.  In fact he boasted that he placed ADR’s in people with higher cobalt levels than what mine had.  Are you kidding me?

Anyway, a fantastic surgeon in Texas did a revision to titanium and I’m much better.  There may be some decent surgeons there, but I didn’t meet one.
Great place I highly recommend this place for cancer treatments.

One of the top hospitals my foot they should be last so far my experience with this hospital has been a horrific experience waiting for transportation takes hours in this place they left me in radiation for hours someone findly came in and found me can't get a straight answer from any doctor there is never a nurse around you can die before they get to you.  This place is a joke
When you can't say anything good about a facility it's best to tell all your friends, family and neighbors to avoid it.

If you or your family member have a disability please don't go to this ER.  My daughter is paralyzed from the waist down and was taken via ambulance to Duke hospital in Durham.  She was locked in a severe spasm and was unable to move at all.
After 6 hours on a gurney in the hallway of the ER a very kind cna found a room for her with some privacy.  We stayed in the ER all night with very nice nurses and a caring PA.  This morning we were told that she didn't meet their criteria to be admitted.  She was and still is in incredible pain and still stuck in the same locked up position.
Once we were told we were being discharged the urgency to leave the room became awkward.  I couldn't make them understand that my daughter couldn't physically get into her wheelchair and that we would have to roll her to the car on the gurney.  They immediately said that wasn't an option.  At this point I am so confused as to what they expect me to do. The sweet nurse was so upset because she didn't know what to do either.  She asked her manager and they agreed to push her outside on the gurney to the entrance where the ambulance brings patients to the hospital.  The manager was close to my age 56 and the nurse was quite petite so I was concerned about how we were going to pick her up in such an awkward position.  We get to the parking lot and they realize they need more help.  They enlist two other young girls and everyone has my daughter wrapped up like a burrito trying to shove her in the backseat.  They kept expressing concern about dropping her and I said please be very careful!!! She is paralyzed and a fall on the concrete would be awful.  The young nurse starting laughing loudly and said She’s paralyzed. Omg that's hilarious!!! I was so shocked and said what's funny??? She said omg. She's really paralyzed??? It was so uncouth and I know embarrassed my daughter who was already in a vulnerable situation.  They pushed and pulled and got her in the backseat still in the same locked position she had arrived in.  We left and came home.  We had to call EMS to help get her in our house.
I regret not asking to go back to chapel hill.  We are scheduled for a ketamine treatment tomorrow in Durham and I need prayers that she can get unlocked and we can get her back to Durham for her treatment.
Please do your research before going to this hospital.  I am not sure how bad off you have to be to receive help.

Laughed at the fact I was shot & paralyzed. Stuck in such a bad back spasm that I couldn’t go in or out in my wheelchair and they refused to even look at my back or admit me. First and last time coming here. If you or a loved one has disabilities go to UNC

Duke fails feed lactating mothers with infants in the PICU when their EPIC and phones are down. No one would provide my daughter in law’s preordered dinner tray. I talked to the charge nurse, 2 different HUCs, cafeteria personnel and the hospital switchboard. They were not concerned. You’re on your own in this place.

Hospital Nurse Comparison

I’ve been in 3 hospitals in this 1 week and this is how I would rate the nurses across the 3 hospitals:

Wakemed Cary: the best nurses. Response time; in most cases 30 seconds with max of 2 mins. Most attentive, knowledgeable and empathetic. Demographics of assigned nurses: Asian, Africans who were not raised in U.S.

UNC Rex: Average nurses. Gossipy, Helpful, Empathetic, complaining about work overload from other patients - 1 nurse to 5 patient ratio. Response time: 5 mins. Demographics of assigned nurses - White, Latino

Duke University Hospital: Worst nurses. Response time: depends on your ask. Most of the times no response or poor response time of 10-15 mins. Least empathetic. Arrogant. Ignored the water swap request the entire night saying give me some time. If asked to pee, then came in 2 mins and handed over the pee bowl. I asked to walk to the restroom. A bit of frown but she had to unhook me so I could walk. Demographics of assigned nurses: African Americans. The white nurses were relatively prompt

I know everyone many have different opinions about Duke University Hospital but to my family.we had a great experience with them. Starting from my wife conception of the baby and down to her delivery. All the Nurses are great. Each one of them are all ready to assist you. There is a slogan i noticed from them. asking you, did you need anything or is there any way they can help you all. This makes us comfortable and we could pour out our feels and ask questions.
The receptionist are the worst and the most rudest especially the one with the name Felecia. They should respect everyone and believe when it’s their fault.

I would give zero stars if able.

My boyfriend had to carry me in as I was unable to walk, so we used the valet. Air pods were stolen from our jeep while getting checked in. We reported the theft, but no action was taken. The administration really didn't care. The air buds ping'd a week later at - you guessed it - Duke ER.

I waited over 13 hours in the ER in agonizing pain and uncontrollable vomiting. I had dropped over 20lbs by this point. When I was finally admitted, a doctor was shocked at my condition. He said he would do any and all tests to help figure out what the issue was and that I was in good hands.

Not even 10 minutes later, I was told I was being discharged by a nurse. My body was still convulsing, and I was still in a very bad way.

I filed a complaint via patient advocate due to negligence in care and theft, and received a letter in the mail stating no action was being taken about either issue.
My mother received the best care! Thank you!

Sadly my brother put total faith in them. The oncology department showed us that just because a Hospital has a “ Big Name” does not mean anything, unless you have a Doctor or Doctors that fight for you.As my brother is putting everything into fighting for his life, his Oncologist says directly to him “ you wont live long.” Who does that? He did prove him wrong and lived another year. He fought so hard and was doing so good that they gave him “A Break” in his chemo. He had SCLC extensive very deadly and aggressive. He had a brain MRI that showed lesions and a possible stroke. Was supposed to have a follow up Brain MRI in 3 weeks. Even though he showed signs of brain cancer, he was sent home twice from ER with “ vertigo” His partner fought for an MRI for months. She finally got it scheduled in October of 2024  . Cancer was all through his brain. He said to me before he passed “ they really messed up” Yes they did my sweet brother. He passed on 2/6/2025

I've never had a hospital take as good of care and pay attention to what my symptoms were as much as this group did the morning of the 2/28 a little empathy goes a long way. Thanks, team, for realy listening and caring.

I came from Sanford because my husband had a stroke and he was flown in from central Carolina Hospital and when iI got here I didn’t know where to park then when I went to the main entrance and the guards had no access to the information where I was supposed to go then I had to call the main line and they took the time to help me find out where i had to go then I went to the right floor but the wrong area and got a bad attitude from the staff because they didn’t want to take the time out to guide me in the right direction until i mentioned where I had to go to then all of a sudden they knew where it was

Do NOT go to Duke Hospital if you have a choice, they only care about money!! I was diagnosed with PNH, which is a very rare blood disease. I was referred to Duke from my hematologist in Wilmington due to the rareness of my disease. After months and months of trying medications, doing tests, hospital stays, surgeries and biopsies I was told that I need immunization therapy. The purpose of going to Duke for this exact reason. I was scheduled to see Dr. Castro's due to the fact he receives lots of grants for doing PNH research and studies. However, two days before my appointment, I was contacted by Dolores from Duke who stated that if I did not prepay upfront, I would not be treated, and my appointment would be cancelled. I then explained my situation to her, and that I could not prepay upfront. She then stated that she would notify the Dr that I would not be coming for my appointment. After that phone call I sent a mychart message to Dr. Castro's staff thinking that this may help. I described in my message just exactly what had happened during my phone call with Dolores. The nurse that answered simply stated I will let the Dr know you will not be coming for your appointment, nothing else. I have been diagnosed with this disease for almost a year now. I have lost my job and all of my life savings trying to combat it. Now that I really need help from the hospital and its services, I'm being turned away. They do NOT care about your well-being. Duke hospital only care about getting their money, and from what I have seen from the staff there, they have no humanity. Hospitals are supposed to help people, not turn people away that really need help just because they're worried about their bank account. Duke Hospital should be ashamed.

Do not take adults with cognitive impairment or mental disabilities without guardianship documents. Healthcare proxy and POA are not respected if family member is an "adult". They will use security to escalate situation and still not assist patient with correct treatment even if documentation is provided. Also, emergency Department bathrooms are full of feces and no paper to wipe your hands. They discriminate against adults with disabilities and race.
dirty unsanitary bathroom. very unorganized and unprofessional

Worse Hospital I’ve ever been a patient add. I was told I would have one day surgery on my neck and could go home next day. Which Never Happened, I ended up in ICU with a terrible infection. Wound back. If my Daughter which is in Healtcare at another Hospital close to our home, had not been there to Help me I Honestly don’t think I would be living. I highly recommend doing some research on any medications Duke prescribes or asking a family member or friend to help you look them up. Starting in early December 2024, I was at Duke for AFib and an enlarged prostate, there was an issue with the way a Physician's Assistant administered my medication. I was given a prostate drug at 10 p.m. every night, on an empty stomach, right before bed. Unfortunately, this led to a month of nonstop painful diarrhea.

Once at home, after my son researched the drug, we discovered that this medication should never be taken on an empty stomach, as it can cause painful and dangerous side effects. Thankfully, after making the adjustment on January 5th, 2025, and taking the pill correctly, after eating food, the symptoms stopped.

While we appreciate the care Duke provides, this experience taught us how important it is to double-check medications. I encourage everyone to take a moment to research any new prescriptions to ensure they’re being used correctly.

Duke University Hospital, located in Durham, North Carolina, is a leading academic medical center affiliated with Duke University School of Medicine. Established in 1930 through a bequest from James B. Duke, the hospital has grown into a 1,062-bed facility renowned for its comprehensive patient care, education, and medical research. ￼

The hospital offers a full spectrum of healthcare services, ranging from primary care to specialized treatments. It is consistently recognized among the nation’s top hospitals, ranking first in North Carolina and nationally in 11 adult and 9 pediatric specialties, according to U.S. News & World Report. ￼

As part of the Duke University Health System, Duke University Hospital serves as a major training site for medical professionals and is dedicated to advancing medical knowledge through research and innovation. The hospital’s mission focuses on providing exceptional patient care, fostering medical education, and contributing to groundbreaking research. ￼

For more information or to plan a visit, please refer to the hospital’s official website: ￼

Dirty, everyone looks lost and confused. It's clearly a training hospital.
The same nasty rag they use to wipe down the bathrooms is the same rag they use to wipe down the patient sitting area. Lord where is common sense around here.🤮

I cannot tell you how many times I have been here and been treated like dirt. I have had colon cancer, too many surgeries to tell, and many bowel obstructions because of it. They have sent me home knowing I have a bowel obstruction and told me come back if it gets worse. Really? People die from bowel
Obstructions all the time. 10 years ago I was treated so well, drs and nurses were caring and I felt safe. But that is in the past, now, even if they do keep me they are cold, uncaring, and cruel. They don’t give pain meds for pain anymore because of the “War on Opiates”. Sounds like a good thing? Wrong! It is crazy. I agree we want to stop street use of opiates, but to stop using them for everyone else is crazy. My best friends daughter had sickle cell anemia. A very deadly, serious and PAINFUL disease. They treat is like dogs, refuse us pain meds when we need them, and give us antipsychotic drugs instead that make you feel like your having an out of body experience or that your Alice in wonderland! It’s insane. I thought it was just for us “druggies”- you know- people you take pain medicine for serious medical reasons(Not people on the street). But then I had my hair permed and the lady-78 yrs old had never had a pain pill in her life, had knee surgery. First they forgot to get her into physical therapy(this has to be done and started immediately or it won’t turn out well) for weeks, and she was in terrible pain. So much so she kept calling her dr saying i’m in so much pain. I don’t know what to do. I need you to help me. The doctor didn’t answer any of her phone messages. Finally set an appointment with her. And when she came in, the doctor said really snuggly so what is it you want? That alone to me speaks volumes. And just for your information they told her for her pain to not take one Tylenol but to take two. The lady was in so much pain that at one point in time she had said things that let her husband to believe she may consider suicide. So he gave all of his guns away. This is a normal person who’s in so much pain. Her husband thinks she could possibly commit suicide. I have been in this place multiple times and thought to myself there just must be something wrong with me. But it’s not me that there’s something wrong with it. It’s the healthcare system. I understand we all want to get drugs off the street. But that does not mean that you can treat regular people the way you do. It is not justifiable and I’m tired of it. I now refuse to go to the hospital when I have a bowel obstruction because they refuse to keep me anymore and one day, I will probably die at home from a bowel obstruction And I never realized it before, but I know of people that I’ve died at home of a bowel obstruction and now I know why. Aren’t you glad we have doctors and nurses that we know we’ll take care of us when we need it.
Duke Univereity Hospital 🏥

They say it's always darkest before the dawn of a new day... Well, the nights & days spent in the "World Class" Duke University Hospital🏥 with a loved one❤️‍🩹... provided much relief🫂 from concern as I watched and engaged with the knowledgeable, caring, passionate, professional staff members(Doctors🧑‍⚕️👩🏽‍⚕️, Nurses, Techs, Therapist and even sanitation employees) who cared for my brother who had a stroke😥 He has a long road ahead, nevertheless, he's still here🙏🏽and doing much better👍🏽
👏🏽 My family and I truly appreciate you all❤️

Kristy Smith from the cash management dept is doing a great job , she went above and beyond to return our check, she's a prime example of integrity.

I don't recommend this hospital. They roughed my girlfriend up after her surgery and she was terrified. That in itself is a joke. As far as the nurses and doctors, half of them are great and seem to care, the other half seem to care less. If you need a surgery done, I'd probably check another place out, the recovery nurses seem to be extremely disrespectful and unprofessional.

Awesome Job, I’m not originally from the area, I went in due to horrible nausea, staff was very patient and informing, the wait was long but that’s pretty much any hospital, the way they handled me with care and compassion made me forget about the wait honestly, constantly making sure I’m okay and getting me things I need, I can’t say much but a big thank you to this hospital, they don’t operate like that where I’m from so I’m grateful for Duke Hospital.

My Sister is at Duke, and I must say between high prices for families to eat for long periods at a time is ridiculous. My Sisters room on the third floor was horrible, extremely hot due to no air flow in her room and yes it was reported, and a broken bed that would call the nurses for no reason but when my sister really needed someone no one would come due to them thinking it was a bed malfunction. And it’s crazy in ICU patients pick what they want to order but in a regular room it’s whatever is on the menu, kinda backwards don’t you think. And the sleeping chair in the regular rooms are so uncomfortable and only has a sit up position. Nurses in hall laughing at all hours of the morning. Also none comes back and picks up food trays and trash left to flow over on the floor
Staff were caring and attentive. Follow up was very organized. Surgical waiting room staff very kind and concerned.

they took good care of me here during my procedure and my overnight stay. made sure i was comfortable and got enough food to eat. surgery went great and i've ran into no problems recovery wise so far. highly recommend

Just waited over a month for an appointment to get an EMG they called me today then say of my appointment to tell me that my Dr rampazzo put the order in wrong and I'd have to wait at least a month and a half for a new appointment like my life and my well-being don't matter it's been nothing but problems with Cleveland clinic since my injury including doctors treating me like shit if you can help it go somewhere else

My review is based simply on the fact that no matter how hard I try and who I contact, I am constantly bombarded with Cleveland Clinic advertisements in my email feed. Three times now I have gone through considerable effort to find a live person and request that the incessant messages stop. Three times I have been told they would and three times I have been lied to. Absolutely no interest in Cleveland Clinic and now that I know they are such a nuisance to the unwary public I wouldn't go there even if I did think I needed their services. Please go away!!!!

I cannot say enough positive about Cleveland Clinic. I have been taking my sister there for over five years for cancer treatment, and I receive services for heart issues. Our doctors are excellent! The other professionals and support staff are typically very good at what they do. The organization is run like well-oiled machine. I stayed recently in the heart step down unit and my stay was excellent. They also have helped my sister afford her treatment for multipe myeloma which is extremely expensive and not fully covered by her private insurance. We feel so blessed to live in the area of Cleveland clinic. Both of us highly recommend Cleveland clinic to anyone needed excellent medical care.

It is not possible to make appointments. I was on the phone for 30 minutes and the call was transferred between many offices which I did not have any idea who they were. I just tried to make appointments with my family physician's PA. I called the number they gave to me on MyChart. This kind of service is not acceptable.
They have become one of the worst hospitals in the Cleveland area.

I just want to take a moment to thank the entire Cleveland Clinic team. From the security staff to the valet, to those in the halls helping with directions, the ladies at the check-in desk, and especially the pediatric PACU staff and Dr. Ernest Young in orthopedics—every single person was amazing. My son had surgery, and the whole experience was prompt, smooth, and compassionate. No long waits, just kindness, professionalism, and clear communication at every step. We truly appreciate the care you gave our family.

I rushed my father to ER because he was fainting from his pace maker shocking him.  He was quickly admitted, but didn't see a cardiologist until the next morning!  Day 2, the cardiologist introduced herself to my father's roommate, thinking he was my father.  Day 3, dad is still in ICU, but stable.  Cardiologist diagnosis was that dad needed a new pace maker because his heart had deteriorated.  Day 4, I arrived at 9am to chaos in his room and red lights flashing.  He'd had another heart attack right there in ICU because the nurse was ordered to remove him from all of his IV meds.  So the nurse did.  But didn't replace any medication in any form.  Can you imagine being taken off of all your IVs and medication and being thrown into a heart attack, in Cleveland Clinic, in ICU.  He was shocked with the paddles, given life-saving medication and CPR.  The cardiologist blamed the nurse and vice versa.  They stabilized him again by putting him back on the IVs.  He was sweating, breathing heavily and clearly in so much pain from the heart attack.

The level of care at Cleveland Clinic facilities in Akron Ohio has deteriorated! I waited 4 months for much needed colon surgery at Akron General which my primary care doctor said caused me to get a life threatening blood clot. I was told they had a shortage of doctors and I would just have to wait. In my opinion, the CEO is more concerned with profits and purchasing more and more hospitals and private physician practices. As a result, the quality of care is suffering. Supposedly, it’s a nonprofit organization, yet the CEO is paid over $4 million annually. Again, my opinion, but Cleveland Clinic is now just all about the $$$. There was a time when it was a patient first organization. Very unfortunate…

Mind boggling.  I've been to a few hospitals in my time but nothing like this.  Cleveland Clinic saves and transforms lives as a matter of routine, with the best physicians in the world collaborating for optimal patient outcomes..

The cardiologist is wonderful! He takes the time needed to evaluate you as an individual patient. The billing here is a damn mess and you are doubled billed for everything. One bill from the doctor and one bill for use of the facility. This makes no sense. Even after your copays your account sits dormant for weeks then the billing department calls to get authorization to apply those funds to something else after the fact. It takes about 2 months to get all of your final bills before you know what you really owe or are even paying for. Pay attention to your billing too because doctors you never saw or were treated by are adding bills and you have to call to have it removed. It's a shame that a great facility has to do things this way.

Best experience with taking care of my wife. They treated her with the best care. Traveled from Michigan because we were told there wasn't anything they could do a the first large hospital we went too. From the staff in maintenance, food staff, nurses, aids doctors, surgeons. Everyone was wonderful. Sincerely thank you for everything.

I just want to say what a fantastic experience I had with my mom in the ER yesterday at Cleveland Clinic. As usual, everyone was beyond nice but Dr. Steven Dorsey went over and above. My mom is 84 years old and has a complex medical history. He addressed all of our questions and took amazing care of her. He even brought a computer in and showed us the CT pictures after getting us coffee! I’ve never had a doctor be so kind. We will never go to another hospital. Thank you so very much Dr. Dorsey.

I recently had a kidney stone which was one of the most painful experiences of my life and resulted in me having to call an ambulance to the emergency room. I feel like my pain was taken seriously and treated adequately and the doctor who was assigned to me was very informative when explaining the results of my testing/images. I cannot recommend Cleveland Clinic enough for anyone who is looking for good, quality care! God bless our healthcare workers!

The Cleveland Clinic is posh digs for sick people. They have pretty much the best of everything for your health and well-being. Kudos to the workers at Cleveland Clinic, who make it what it is to patients, family members, and the greater Cleveland area.

I want to take a moment to sincerely thank the Cleveland Clinic pediatric staff for their outstanding care during our recent visit. Every single time we come, the experience is nothing but amazing — the staff is always so helpful, caring, and compassionate.

From the doctors to the nurses and sitters, each person has been a true blessing. If there’s any way for them to be recognized for their dedication, it would be well-deserved. As a care giver to an autistic brother you guys have done everything to help us thank you for making a difference in our lives.
Very well thought out

This death trap is the main reason my husband died. We took him on Christmas day and was given false hope of him getting a transplant. They scheduled him for testing in February. He was in and out of other hospitals until he was transferred to CC for his testing. His first week in the hospital, they gave him peritonitis from doing dirty dialysis. He was in so much pain that they started him on Dilaudid. Between the pain and medicine, he because delusional so he was transferred to ICU. They held the transplant over his head, telling him if he didn't switch to hemodialysis, they wouldn't consider him for a transplant. We agreed and they put in the port.  In his delusional state, he tried to pull it out. They strapped his arms to the bed for his own safety. He was claustrophobic though so this sent him into a psychosis. It was horrible watching him go through this. They wanted to install a drain in his abdomen to get rid of some of the infection. After over a week of him waiting for that, they overdosed him, had to narcan him and put him in a vent. They said he overmedicated himself because he had a pain pump at one point. Once they tired his hands down days before, they took away the pump.   Once he was stable from the overdose, they put in a drain tube, in a bile duct. When they tried to replace it, they nicked his gall bladder.  He finally came out of the psychosis but was never the same. He had to have anxiety meds, have the light on at all times and couldn't be left alone because of the trama he experienced there. They denied his transplant. He was in and out of a different hospital that was trying to fix his gall bladder.  He kept getting weaker due to not being able to walk around to get exercise and build his strength from the pain and infection from the gall bladder. He passed at home on July 14th, 2025. He wasn't at CC but they certainly caused his death after a long and painful few months. If you love someone, I BEG YOU, please take them ANYWHERE else.

If you're looking for an oncologist who pairs world-class skill with heartfelt compassion, Dr. Schwartz is someone you will be grateful to have advocating for your well-being.

As a long-time resident of Cleveland, I find it disheartening to witness how Cleveland Clinic has increasingly shifted its focus away from accessible care toward luxury services for the privileged few. While VIP suites and Premier Care packages are heavily advertised, regular patients and working-class families are often left waiting in overcrowded lobbies, facing long delays and limited resources.

This hospital was once seen as a cornerstone of community health, yet now it seems more interested in catering to high-income patients than serving the people who actually live here. The imbalance is glaring: fancy executive wings sit nearly empty while understaffed emergency departments struggle to meet basic needs.

It’s a clear signal that profit has overtaken purpose. Hospitals should prioritize equitable care, not exclusive services for the wealthy. This community deserves better, and CC should be providing more for the community of Cleveland. I've taken my primary care to Metro and I couldn't be more pleased and impressed.

I would not recommend Dr. Jaime Ann Vondenberg. My experience with her at Cleveland Clinic was deeply disappointing and felt like a complete waste of time, energy, and money.

I drove all the way from North Carolina to Ohio to see her in November, hoping to finally get clarity and support for my ongoing health concerns. At the initial appointment, I shared that I had been treated for years as a child for autoimmune encephalitis, that I’ve had a positive ANA multiple times, and that I was experiencing symptoms like chronic fatigue and a red rash across my cheeks. I told her I suspected lupus, and she ran tests—eventually ruling it out. That was fine, but what followed was incredibly frustrating.

We scheduled a Zoom follow-up for February so I wouldn’t have to drive back, and during that appointment, she told me she didn’t believe I had any autoimmune issue at all—despite my medical history and repeated positive ANA tests. She also told me I should see an immunologist, even though she is double board-certified in both rheumatology and immunology herself.

When I asked about the facial rash—after a dermatologist specifically said it was not rosacea and told me to talk to my rheumatologist—Dr. Vondenberg brushed it off and said we should just try a cream because she thought it looked like rosacea. This felt dismissive and unscientific.

Later, I contacted her again after another doctor found elevated thyroid antibodies and wanted more testing done. I reminded her again of my history with encephalitis, and she told me to schedule another appointment. I did—even though it was over a month out—and when I finally saw her again, she was late and completely dismissed everything I had to say. She refused to run any more tests, and repeated the same opinions from our earlier conversations as if nothing new had been presented.

I don’t understand why she had me book and pay for another appointment if she had no interest in revisiting the situation or digging deeper—even when new labs were available and there was a clear history of autoimmune disease.

If you’re looking for a rheumatologist/immunologist who will actually listen, consider your full medical history, and take your concerns seriously, I strongly recommend looking elsewhere. This felt more like a routine dismissal than real care, and I left with more questions than answers.

I am writing this post with 100% accuracy from my perspective and my experience here. I did not get an easy diagnosis, I’ll keep it short on that piece. What I will elaborate on is the care and intelligence I received from the NP on staff Sam in the emergency room department was the best doctor I have met in life. He sat down with me, became a human, and walked me through everything. Like intelligent, kind, genuine, authentic, and didn’t show a single desire to rush away from me, he saw I was anxious and he took time to explain to me everything. He did not owe me that level of one to one care but he stepped up and went above and beyond. I was worried about my kids and he did all he could to reassure me about the facts so far. Some people are meant to be doctors and Cleveland clinic seems to attract that top talent: shout out to Emergency room NP Sam who was on staff May 8th night shift  at this location. Anyway, it was evident in the speed in which I was taken care of, the kindness, literally having a doctor sit with you and walk you through scenarios if we do xyz. This is unheard of and why people travel from all around the world to come to this hospital to meet these doctors . They threw the book to figure out what was going on with me and figured it out within hours.

Literally I couldn’t make it up if I tried. I am extremely impressed!

They apologize and say they will give me a refund. I get a call back an hour later (this person was very kind when I burst into tears) and they tell me that I'm the one who has to call billing department to get a refund on my copay. This whole time I could have been looking for a specialist/getting on the waitlist somewhere else and now I'm stuck on hold with the billing department, STILL SICK, while I could be calling other specialists (where I will probably have to wait months to see).

Seems to me like they are lining their pockets. My wife and I have spent countless hours fighting with their billing department to make corrections, and rarely can get a proper resolution. It is not worth it anymore - seriously considering moving our family to a different hospital system to avoid the ridiculous billing.

I went to the Cleveland clinic in Solon Ohio because of a tremor in my right hand. The doctor ran the test but immediately diagnosed me with having Parkinson's disease. I must emphasize he ran no tests! He looked at me and said I had Parkinson's. Had he run some test or an MRI he would've discovered that I had had an ischemic stroke and it hit in the part of the brain that Parkinson's hits. I wouldn't cross the street for the Cleveland clinic.

My experience with this Cleveland Clinic hospital has been absolutely awful, from when it all began months ago. Do your research thoroughly before coming here over other hospitals that are doing very well with their patients, even though those hospitals aren't marketing all the prideful commercials about how "great" they are. Once you get on CC campus and see what a logistical nightmare it is, from parking and valet to your patient meals to dirty rooms and old fashioned treatments, plus dragging their feet on discharging you as long as they possibly can, you will gladly go to a better place for care.

The Cleveland clinic is using adult geriatric primary care nurse practitioners in their
neurosurgery department.
Have a neurologically complex condition? The brand new nurse practitioner will be handling it for you. They only need 500 clinical hours to graduate. Oh, and you can’t sue them after they inevitably botch your care.

The doctors up there are nice. Also the valet are all nice and are great. But the reception lady named Toya Smith at the cardiology section. Was very rude. We were standing behind the lady who was talking to lady Toya. We were next in line and than a nurse lady went around us to put a paper in the basket for Toya and the nurse took her patient to waiting room. Than Toya was done talking to lady she was with and than she gave us a look and  attitude saying someone is ahead of us. That we are not next. She said it’s the person who put paper in basket Which we literally was standing there for almost 10 minutes waiting to talk to her. But she said we will be talked to after she’s done with this person whose paper was put in basket after us. She just gave us attitude. We just said ok and sat in waiting room to be called next to talk to her. She was rude to us when we were next in line. It just ruined the experience for me and my fiance.

I have a number of very rare conditions that have not been properly managed at many, very large, teaching hospitals across the country.  I now travel from Detroit to Cleveland clinic and have received very extremely specialized care for multiple rare conditions that sit on top of each other, and I am delighted with the quality of the doctors in the specialty fields. I have not had experience in managing my primary care, for example at this point because I’m still traveling to Cleveland every month or so.
I live in New York this facility has saved my life due to the care and high technology used.  They found issues my doctors couldn’t here. I highly recommend this facility

This place is a joke, very unorganized, very rude, can never actually talk to a dr. My dad and I have been back and forth from Indiana. 6.5 hour drive after they say they have a bed for him and ended up sitting in waiting room for almost 5 hours because no bed available. Their doctors are NOT as experienced as they think,,, my dad had surgery to clean out a pocket of infection and they cut one of his arteries down by his pelvis and now he can’t walk or stand more than a few minutes! The JP drain they put in after the surgery was left in for 4 months…. Only should be in for 2-5 weeks. Now since his JP drain was in for too long another pocket of infection has formed and they still haven’t taken out the JP drain! Lawsuit is pending! I wouldn’t take a stray dog to this place for them to put a bandaid on! It’s a big place, but a big mess, and a huge Joke!

Cleveland Clinic will not honor the contract that they agreed upon with my insurer and are billing me for the difference. I already pay a lot of money in insurance premiums. I can not afford to be overbilled on top of that.
Update: After the company's insurance broker got involved, they finally fixed the bill. It took the broker 2 times to finally resolve the issue. They told my broker that they would freeze the bills while it was in dispute. They sent me statements threatening collections well after that. I'm happy it worked out, but this experience has led to me not getting further care. I will be trying to find another provider.

Very unprofessional. Staff is demeaning. I’ve been trying to get a feeding tube placed since May. Still don’t have it. They keep sending me to the wrong doctors, and I’ve been going around in circles since then. If I could give them 0 stars, I would.

Update: 04/22/25

Still no feeding tube. They refuse to switch me to a different provider, because of a “verbal agreement”,  And now they’ve completely stopped calling both my team and I back. Honestly, disgusting treatment of a patient.
Had a great experience at the cleveland clinic

If I would have written this review 3 years ago I would have given a 5 star without a second thought. However, recently dealing with Cleveland Clinic has been a nightmare. My outside physician sent a referral in December. At first I waited patiently for them to reach out to schedule the referral as they used to do but nobody ever called. I started calling on a semi-frequent basis and NO ONE could help. Scheduling couldn't schedule it because financial services, financials services couldn't get it authorized because it had to be scheduled. NO exaggeration I have probably spent 10 hours on the phone with these people trying to get it scheduled. I asked for supervisors and was never permitted to speak to one and most of the call agents would just talk over me when I tried to explain. They need better training. And now they're telling me that instead of just the testing I was under the impression I would have to do that now I have to do a consult with their practitioner too which is more co-pays. So finally, after 4 months I MIGHT get what I need. Would go somewhere else only Cleveland Clinic is my only option for the testing I need.

I was so excited for my appointment,  only to be told that my migraines are to complicated to get help? SERIOUSLY?? Instead of letting another Dr.(s) have a go- im dismissed..Just turned away because someone doesn't want a challenge? I'm so disappointed in this response. I expected much better from the Cleveland Clinic.

The worst billing customer service in existence. You are forced to talk to people outside of the country in order to resolve your issues.

The local financial advocates however are amazing and are the only reason I achieved resolution.

Do not make a prepayment unless you are willing to take a chance at never getting a refund.

Waited 4 months for an appointment, assembled & uploaded entire medical history, flew and then drove 3 hours to get there, promised a 3 to 4 hour thorough diagnostic-type of exam only to have a 30-minute chat with  PA advising to eat more protein & get better sleep. When I asked about the other promised services, they said that their protocol had changed the week after I made the appointment - 1st appt is a brief get-to-know-ya & then they recommend follow-ups. With no regard to the fact that so many people who seek their help have to take off of work, travel & make hotel accommodations each time. AND no notification to us re: the change in protocol. And no change on the website. FALSE ADVERTISING.

Most of the nurses during my mother’s stay were kind and professional, and we’re grateful for them. But we did have one nurse who refused to help her out of bed to use the restroom, saying it wasn’t her job. My mom didn’t have a catheter at the time, so without me there, she likely would’ve had an accident. The shortage of PCNAs was obvious and caused long delays in care.

At one point, I came back from the cafeteria and found my mom’s lunch tray—still sealed—over an hour later. She was too weak to open the soup bowls and no one had helped her. If I hadn’t returned, she wouldn’t have been able to eat.

Valet parking was a mess with long waits, and the Panera Bread on-site had poor service and very dirty restrooms. These may seem like small things, but they add up and affect the experience, especially for patients who are alone. I hope Cleveland Clinic addresses these issues soon.
It’s one of the best hospitals in the world flat out. I received medical service offered by no other practitioners in my home area. CLE Clinic CLE OH!

Cleveland Clinic denied access to ER and had my non nonverbal, Autistic  niece stranded on streets on. We came from Massachusetts for apparently best treatment and kick out and refuse access to ER has and Severely Autistic individual stranded on the streets and refuse access which is against the law. You cannot refuse the. Access to ED. The EMU  Medicating my severely artistic niece against her will because she wanted to go to another floor and wanted to see me she did not lay no hands on nurse or doctors. I don’t understand how this is the number two hospital in the world and they cannot deal with special needs patients or patients that are deaf and autistic. They do not deserve the number two title if they’re abusing patients on the autism spectrum disorder refusing access to the ER that is against the law and putting patients that are severely artistic on the street of Cleveland that is dangerous that is deaf, nonverbal and autistic, which is against the law that does not deserve the title of number two in the world. If anyone has family members that are special-needs deaf autistic, I do not recommend this hospital. They will force medication and they will throw them out on the street. If you are not chaperoning your family 24/7.
Once they threw her out of the hospital, not notifying the family or the healthcare proxy she was reported missing. I also want to state denying access to an emergency room is against the law. Every patient has the right to be seen in emergency room. They broke the law.

Let me start with having my daughter here in 2009 for her migraine headaches. She’s tried different doctors and medications in Evansville, IN where we’re from with no success. Cleveland Clinic was able to break the migraine cycle and give her relief at last! 😁👍

Fast forward to now…. I brought my fiancé to the Clinic for her ascending aortic aneurysm and high blood pressure after several different doctors and specialists, again in Evansville, IN with no success! Are you seeing the issues here?

The doctors in Evansville have no clue how to treat their patients! The doctor she saw at the Cleveland Clinic knew exactly what her issues were and was able to readjust her BP meds, (she was on FIVE different medications with no success) and got her down to only three medications just once a day instead of FIVE medications three times per day!

The doctors, nurses, and other staff were absolutely AMAZING!!! Belinda McKinney in the registration office was ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL!!! She was SO CARING and so polite and friendly! She actually CARED about the patient! The staff at Deaconess Hospital in Evansville, IN DOES NOT CARE about the patients AT ALL!!!

The specialist doctor that treated my fiancé was so polite, knowledgeable, helpful, and professional! He actually CARED about her and wondered why she was on so many different medications for her blood pressure! He made her feel better about her aneurysm overall and putting her on less medications as well.

We are looking forward to working with the Cleveland Clinic and their team in the future. We’re DEFINITELY not going to let any more of the doctors OR hospitals, especially Deaconess Hospital in Evansville treat us again! They are absolutely HORRIBLE!!!

Don’t be afraid of getting a second opinion about your medical issues if you don’t feel good about your doctor, and ESPECIALLY if you’re having a bad experience with the hospital! SPEAK UP FOR YOURSELF!!! The doctors and ESPECIALLY the HOSPITAL STAFF in Evansville OBVIOUSLY DO NOT CARE!!!
Absolutely fantastic staff.
I came for a national consult due to complex needs. Every provider seemed knowledgeable and wanted to be part of the solution vs pointing fingers at other specialties. It was refreshing.
