But  they are so pro active when 15 minutes after we arrived at the emergency room they  are already making sure they have your signature to be liable for the service!!!.
We didn’t ask much, not for a prívate room, but at least for a more decent space where a person doen’t get depressed besides being sick.
I love my primary dr. He's amazing

UCLA Santa Monica Medical Center is truly one of the most professional and well-organized hospitals I’ve ever visited.
The staff is incredibly skilled, kind, and attentive, making sure every patient receives top-quality care.
The lobby is spotless and welcoming, and the patient rooms and transfer areas are always clean, modern, and comfortable.
They also offer convenient parking, which makes a big difference.
From check-in to discharge, everything runs smoothly and with great respect and professionalism.
I highly recommend this hospital to anyone looking for excellent medical care in a clean and supportive environment.

when you're at your lowest, they will kick you and try to bring you down to a new low. the nurses all can't wait to get off shift and don't respect or have any care for the patients at all, and the doctors won't even spend 3 minutes in your room.  everything takes forever from the food bring brought to the room, to the nurse being called, to maintenance, to any test results.  i am so sad to see that the medical personnel here all don't care at all about the patients (they can say whatever, but their actions speak louder).   I hope everyone's here gets re-trained in sympathy and understanding and knowing they are there to help people (yes, they need to make money too, but human lives should matter more).  I hope they improve because being the 1 of 2 main hospitals here, this was a disgrace and appalling and humiliating.

Expensive, poor service and outdated. You make appointments over the phone or messages only, no schedule system. They might charge you by sending message because they might consider them consultations. To exemplify, I sent a message indicating that I won't be using their services any more through the MyChart app,  and I got charged $64.03 after insurance. Doctors are good but isn't worth it.

⭐ 1 Star

The worst emergency room experience I’ve ever had.

I came to UCLA Santa Monica ER on June 30, 2025, around 1:30 AM with dizziness, high blood pressure, and a severe headache. I was subjected to multiple failed and painful IV attempts by four different nurses. One of them even grabbed my arm roughly, showing no regard for my comfort or pain. My concerns were ignored and dismissed the entire time.

I was then hooked up to an IV without being given a call button, left alone in the room and unable to move. I had to scream for help through the door just to get anyone to respond. A nurse finally entered, only to say she could “see my vitals from somewhere else,” and then walked away without checking on me. All while the vital signs monitor was beeping for an extended time.

This was negligent, unprofessional, and unsafe. There was no compassion, no basic care, and no concern for patient safety. I’ve filed a formal complaint with the hospital and with the California Department of Public Health.

If you care about your health, safety, and being treated like a human being, do not come to this ER.
This UCLA patient was wheeled out into the sun outside the hospital and was simply left there until I went home for work for the day. He was yelling nearly all day. Clearly in distress.

If you are an out of state patient, dont bother, AVOID!! They have no regard for patients traveling from out of state. They scheduled my husband for an appt with the incorrect doctor so he came all the way down and wasn't able to see his doctor and now they are requiring the SAME tests he already had here in Vegas but saying he has to come back to do them at UCLA before the surgeon will even agree to do the surgery. My husband has a degenerative disease that is getting worse by the day and hes down 30 lbs in months because he can't eat. It is absolutely unacceptable that a referral FOR THE SURGERY is being treated like he needs a diagnosis AGAIN. We are paying out of pocket and its been an nightmare with how many tests they keep doing and asking for. He has already been diagnosis and proposed treatment.  AVOID UCLA.
I had to come here through the emergency room while I was traveling. I ended up having appendicitis. The staff was so kind all the way around. Absolutely blown away by how lovely the people were

The need for just Basic response to patient would be appreciated. I have developed bed or pressure sores allegedly because of a bed that was designed for me but has not worked for me that was not adequate knowledge of how to operate the bed due to inadequate pressure in the bed I find myself on metal. After requesting countless times just to transfer me out of the bed have asked to speak to charge nurses that don't show from operators won't transfer you to numbers other than your own station don't fully understand how to get the help I so desperately need reference 5 North wing. What appreciate any help desperate and in pain
Worst hospital ever. I had an appointment for 10:00 and didn’t get seen until after 2 because “they forgot about me” and i’m pregnant. So crazy. I don’t know if it’s a race thing or what but smh.

We spent a week in the pediatric unit and the staff was amazing. The nurses and care partners were attentive, personable, and caring. At a difficult time when my infant was sick the staff brought us joy and we felt taken care of. The staff brought by gifts for my older child, who was not hospitalized, and consistently asked how she was coping with her younger sister in the hospital. It warmed my heart that they cared and wanted to still make her feel special. The unit also has a playroom and the hospital has beautiful outdoor areas that help you forget you’re in a hospital.

Surgery is never fun but I felt very taken care of throughout the process. This place has the kindest nurses, from start to finish, including the pre-op schedulers. Every single nurse I had was prompt, attentive and caring. 🌟
Parking attendant is so rude and unprofessional

I came here for my first time last week after getting hit by a car. Mind you I’m very skeptic of police and paramedics and have trust issues… but I was extremely glad I came here. The staff was professional knowledgeable  , swift and really actually care. They tended to me immediately and ran me all the tests and x rays and medicine I needed super fast without compromising any body else’s place in line. I got no special treatment but that’s the thing. Their regular treatment is special treatment FIR ANYONE that walks through these doors. God bless the Doctors , nurses , nurses aids and the security for running such an amazing hospital

Very incompetent administrative and medical team.  Zero communication among them internally so no communication to us as patients.  I am so disappointed that this is the closest hospital to us.   I would sell my home and move so the ambulance will never bring me or my family here again if i had any money to afford another place.  🤣  This place is a waste of space for something useful to the community like a park.

No one wants to be sick enough to need surgery, but I had Dr. Mehta and his extraordinary team, so I was privileged enough to receive the best of care. Everyone, from start to finish, was simply exemplary. I always felt safe, looked after, and have healed nicely. It goes without saying that this hospital is one of the best in the nation, and having received care there, I understand why.

The hospital is wonderful.  Most of the nurses are caring. The doctors are very good.
But I hope you NEVER have to go through the ER here. It is a zoo 24/7

10/10 chocolate cake. If you’re going to admitted to a hospital, I highly recommend this one for the food alone. I was in here for 3 days and I was well taken care of by a medical staff who really love their patients. I have terrible insurance too and the doctors found a way to keep me without trying to bankrupt me. I don’t want to go back to a hospital but if I had to, it would be here. Thank UCLA!

I always choose them over any hospital when any of my 6 get sick or needs the ER vist this is OUR #1 CHOICE 🥰 From the ER to Pediatric dept PURE KINDESS , CARING PPL who's just @ wrk they're professionals and well EDUCATED jus AMAZING 👏🏾

Really good chocolate cake. Highly recommended.

The ER doc fought my partner’s insurance company on his behalf to get him admitted to UCLA and then she and the whole team at the hospital proceeded to take exceptional care of him. 10/10 hope to never experience this again, but will return for continued medical care and in case of future emergencies.

Thank you.
The best hospital ever, every time we have to go, is a exelent service,no complaints at all.
good, clean hospital. smart, capable doctors and nurses. only compliant is that the ER is disorganized and long wait.

I came to this Emergency Department for the first time ever. I’m part of the Army National Guard and have been helping with the LA fires for 2 weeks. I suddenly needed surgery for my appendix after being diagnosed with appendicitis.

All I have to say is from start to finish, almost every staff member (nurse, doctor, and surgeon) were extremely nice, helpful, and supportive. I hate being a burden to others but they went out of their way to make sure I felt better in every aspect.

My only complaint I had was after being moved into a hallway getting ready to be taken to surgery, these 2 CNAs in the ED treated me like I was a burden to them. An example: When they gave me these wipes I asked them what they were for and one of them said “are you serious? You never used wipes before?” While they other one laughed and walked away. I wont say their names or describe them but it really put me down.

Besides that interaction I had a great time. Thank you!

Regarding the Emergency Department: Initially transferring via ambulance from GLA VA, was told a room was available, entrance nurse told EMTs to leave me in the lobby, placed in the hallway and Ignored by staff and approached by the same nurse three different times, with three different names for different treatment reasons unrelated to me. Left in a hallway to discuss very intimate feminine issues when I finally addressed the lack of care, pain was not manageable, Jocelyn second nurse who left me stirring for over an hour in pain after medication did not work, no explanation or help from anyone else in her absence, nurses had “wellness session” with tea at the front desk where I sat in the hallway,I asked repeatedly for a pillow, my nurses location, next steps regarding scans and the non effective medication since I was now in severe pain, asked Three different nurses about these things and I was completely ignored, They walked by me repeatedly as if I’d never asked for anything. I was taken outside to a filthy and completely unsanitary storage area outside the ambulance entrance to conduct a pelvic exam by the gynecologist. Release myself on my own recognizance after being left for hours with no assistance to return to GLA VA. This is how they treat Veterans. I wouldn’t even send my dog here.
Nothing really compares
Some one is on live she got stabbed with her boyfriend asked for whater didn’t receive and asked for help and never got it sje has been waiting for 5 hours and no one has helped her

I am leaving UCLA Health. They signed up a billion patients and are okay with what this does to medical care. It is literally true that I am unable to contact any of my doctors (several departments) even though you are supposedly messaging them by name and by their smiling face. Your messages are answered by a message answerer, who answers for the doc; not from the doc. So, their answers are off. The positive reviews on here are about the Emergency Room (so, not us the regular patients).

I was recently admitted for a day for an emergency treatment. I have been absolutely blown away by the kindness, the efficiency and the dedication of the doctors, nurses and all staff members. It made a huge impact that not a single person gave the impression that my concerns were invalid, or that my decisions were unimportant. I can certainly attest to the fact that the ER and the Labor & Delivery unit are staffed by some of the most compassionate and expert healthcare providers I’ve ever encountered. And, bonus, job well done because I feel SO much better.

Care us really gone down. Doctors have so many patients now that the quality of attention has really deteriorated. The hospital system has a poor communication system, doctors work in silos, are unable to see a patient holistically and take days to get back to someone with urgent matters. It’s a shame that the quality of care has dropped so low, putting patients at risk. Particularly the elderly. Elderly care is absolutely awful.

ER @ Midnight Friday Very Busy waited Apx 2hrs to be shown a gurney which was "my Room" for Most of my Stay Which Turned out to be Several Days. I was Diagnosed Properly & Treated for That Until I Felt Ready to go!
Top marks all around.
Superb in every aspect.

Went to the ER and stayed for a day, the team was so attentive, genuinely caring, and even followed up 24 hours after discharge to make sure I was still doing okay. God willing I never have to go to the hospital again, but if I must let it be here please.

This has been the worst hospital experience ever! I came in to the ER and the quality of care was terrible.  I’m from out of state so I was by myself, scared, and they didn’t provide any comfort. Super disorganized and the restrooms we’re disgusting.

It is impossible to see your doctor. They advertise that they car about you but doctors no longer respond on MyChart and you better not need to reschedule an appointment, I tried to reschedule a cardiologist appointment today..Oct 9, 2025.  Next appointment available is December 2026!!!  This is no joke.  They just want to order tests with fancy facilities and load their doctors with too many patients and limit time spent with you to 15 minutes. Unconscionable.
I'm an unwavering fan.

The worst place to go to, just stay home n die, the security treats you better than the nurses here. The nurses lack empathy and are so dismissive that it comes off disrespectful. I rather die than come here again because it seems like they only care if you’re literally dying for them to give you any kind of treatment. If you have the choice do not come here.
Northwestern Memorial Hospital offers exceptional medical care, advanced technology, and compassionate staff dedicated to patient health and comfort. A top choice for quality healthcare.
emergency have waiting 10 hours 😴

My mother has been at Northwestern Memorial Hospital for a few weeks now and let me tell you the nurses and doctors on the 15th are MAGNIFICENT!!! Every nurse every doctor that came into her room was very attentive very supportive and very cheerful! They gave us straight answers and allowed us to ask many questions. We got calls from them to keep us updated on her care and that’s the type of medical care that we all want. They have the most caring and compassionate people! They didn’t allow her to be discharged until they had answers! Thank you Northwestern Memorial Hospital for the excellent care of my mom and a special thank you to all the nurses  doctors and cleaning crew on the 15th floor!!!!!!! ❤️

Quality of service here is not groundbreaking or any different from other healthcare systems. I have been here to see both PCP and specialists and they didn’t do anything different from what I would get in another system.

What will make me switch to another system is the fact that billing is super expensive for what you pay for. Also, lack of parking at the hospital is a pain for patients when the lots are always full and when you do get a spot it’s expensive. Lastly, and the biggest issue, is lack of appointments. I have to wait months to see a doctor in various departments, which is longer than other hospitals/clinics I’ve been to. Even if you tell them an issue is critical (in my case, I have family history of stroke and I had symptoms of a mini stroke), they make you wait 4-7 months to see a specialist.

Not sure what the issue is if they don’t have enough doctors, but the waitlist seems inhumane for most people dealing with symptoms that need to be addressed more immediately. For as expensive as this hospital is, they should be able to budget to hire more physicians or expand their buildings in the downtown Chicago area if there is a high demand for certain areas/specialties.

Do not mistake this place for a homeless shelter.  Avoid this ER, as you will need to educate the medical staff on medical care.  Their triage component is a failure.  Our life threatening situation was triaged at the lowest priority and the patient began neurogenic shock.  We were refused blankets to shield the patient from the public as we were catheterizing.  The medical advice of our existing medical team suggested an alternate offloading every 2 hours.  9 hours in the powerchair contradicts their own medical advice.  The nurses scoff when you approach them.
Upon intake, a cot in a busy corridor becomes your awaited oasis.  Your meal is thrown into your crotch.  You need to provide your own catheters.  This place is a complete joke.
No complaints about the vibe!

作者: โก๋ หลังวัง
評論內容: Simply the best taste.
i’ve been in this room waiting for the doctors to come in for about a hour now! it’s almost 1am ! this is ridiculous!
Beware this hospital only cares about your money and not your health.
Clearly the best choice.

I came to Northwestern Memorial Hospital for medical assistance that ended in a mental health crisis. I requested emergency assistance and accommodation. Instead of receiving informed triage, I was directed to a quiet area, where a staff member raised their voice and demanded that I leave. My requests for accommodation and a patient advocate were dismissed, and I was left unattended even after disclosing escalating hyperarousal, suicidal ideation, and while actively bleeding.

This experience left me feeling humiliated and unsafe. I have since filed formal complaints with regulatory boards. My hope is that Northwestern will review its policies and strengthen trauma-informed care for patients in crisis.

Your vice matters. Please report any maltreatment and good luck with your health and healing

The specialty services at Northwestern are world class. The physicians and nurses are exceptional.  The emergency portion of the hospital is not good. Going on my 7th hour waiting. With access to billions of dollars, you’d think they’d also invest in the emergency room services. It’s like something out of a developing country. I’ve had faster emergency responses in rural Mexico. This is a shame and it must improve.

Update: now going on 8 hours!!!
The hospital is great but their financial department is horrible I have to constantly stalk them to verify my insurance properly. It is very frustrating 😤
Some ER employees have no compassion at all  especially the white man with the black frame glasses.

This hospital REFUSES to perform the US Test ordered by my doctor instead they are BLACKMAILING ME into getting a test that is NOT needed (a mammogram) or else they said they will NOT PROVIDE ANY CARE AT ALL - putting my life in peril!
It is TIME WE WOMEN stood UP FOR OUR HEALTH CARE!
Waiting over 6 hrs in the er. May as well just die

They don't understand mobility issues, how to compensate for them or how to properly communicate the issue. Our 1st Barium swallow on Friday got cancelled because they didn't realize my wife was incapable of sitting erect unsupported for 30 minutes despite endless notes, conversations and her file.
Their only rational answer is "wait till Monday and come up with a plan". Monday comes around and we send her down on a hoverboard assistance device, have a nurse to nurse conversation and her file from Monday is still available to the technician.
So I was very surprised that not only did they ignore all of that.
They dropped her.
They dropped her.
They dropped her.
She will be fine but for some that is a death sentence.
20 hours later I'm being told it shouldn't have happened and they will get it worked out. I have my doubts.

My wife has been suffering for months but "stable". We just need 2 diagnostics tests and then can leave this house of grift and incompetence.

PSA do not leave your loved ones alone with these people. The number of times I had to remind them to give medications on schedule. The number of times I had to remind them her diet needs to be NBO. The number of times they need to be prompted to attend to their patient. Absurd!
Susan B. Who handles appointments etc. Was absolutely amazing, she took her time and gave excellent customer service!!

While Northwestern still has some awesome Drs, their ER department is a mess. Long, long waits - we have spent literally 24+ hours at an ER visit. Their new thing now is metal detectors at the entrance where "security" treats people like they are drug smugglers getting ready to board a trans Atlantic flight... because someone coming in with an emergency health situation really needs to go thru a multiphase search of "Empty your pockets ...oops something set the alarm off, go thru again...ooops. oh, what can it be? Go thru again. Oh! U have a cane because u cant walk! 💡"  Save yourself the hassle of going to the downtown location and dealing with Barney Fife and if u can, go to one of the suburban ones instead. They are more than half less the hassle.

I’ve been with Northwestern for some time now.. My doctors Is in Wicker Park, I get my labs drawn on Irving Park… Then I had an emergency and I realized Northwestern Hospital downtown is just not an option for me living on the north west side when I have an emergency. They really need a hospital on the northwest side. Ended up at Swedish. Now I might just switch everything
To be one of the top hospitals in Chicago , you would be better off at Mount Sinai hospital! The wait time is beyond ridiculous!

The most disgusting hospital I have every been at. Homeless people sleeping in the lobby where you have to wait for hours sitting right next to homeless people.  The funniest thing is that they kick the homeless out at 4:30am and clean the floor every morning.  Afterwards, it looks as if nothing happend, you see people sitting in the same area and and same seats and tables that others have been druling and urinating in. Disgusting.

My husband has been here for a few days on the 10th floor.  No one cleaned the room for 3 days untill I complained.   The room had no bathroom and he had to use a bathroom in the hall.  There was a pan filled with urine sitting on top of the sink for 3 days.

Some doctors are probably great here, but some are completely clueless. My husband was in pain all night because the doctor would not give him pain medicine even though plenty was given in the ER.  The most miserable experience I have ever had in a hospital. If you have options you may want to go somewhere else.

Due to their negligence during our prenatal care, they botched an ultrasound and our daughter was born 3 months early back in 2006. She was born with cerebral palsy as a result. After years of litigation they still deny accountability and used my now 16 year old daughters Tik Tok against her in court claiming since she can use her hands to operate a smart phone, all is well.
Well, social media works both ways so now I'm using it to tell my daughters story. Between the prenatal care we got from Northwestern and their "partner" Erie Family Health, our daughter has a lifetime of hardship that could have been prevented if everyone involved had done their job efficiently. Go anywhere else for your prenatal needs if you want to give your baby a good start in life. 1,000 negative stars if I could.
This hospital, staff and attorneys showed zero remorse for ruining my daughters life and claimed zero accountability for a birth injury they created. If you see Northwestern on the door, turn around and run away as fast as you can from these butchers!!!! I advise getting any other doctor than William Grobman to read images.
Is the worst hospital In emergency room. Workers don't care, take time to attend the patients more 13 hrs. Very dirty. Floors
Those security guards will be dealt with. Good luck
Worst hospital I’ve ever been too . How can you be an ER where the wait time is 5-6 hrs? Atp who are you saving ?

I had a zero dollar bill for four years. Last week, a collection agency said I owe them over $1100 from NW. I called Northwestern billing and they were hot from the start. I maintained professionalism and kept conversation to be productive. They wanted me to give up and have me go away. Apparently, after 4 years, I have a bill. They sold it with out me knowing I had one. ALWAYS had a zero balance. I truly believe it’s made up, even billing doesn’t know where it came from. Reporting to governor, mayor, and trying to get the news involved. Any ideas? Who’s doctor or business accreditation can I go after? Anyone else? Let’s do a class action lawsuit! Unethical!!

During a recent vacation to Chicago, my husband suddenly became ill and had to be admitted to the emergency room at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. What started as an unexpected and frightening experience turned into one filled with compassion and exceptional care.

We ended up staying for four days, and throughout that entire time, the staff was truly outstanding. From the ER team to the nurses, doctors, specialists, and support staff—everyone we encountered was professional, kind, and attentive. They took the time to explain everything clearly, answer our questions, and ensure my husband was comfortable and well cared for.

Being away from home made the situation more stressful, but the staff at Northwestern Memorial helped ease that burden. We’re incredibly grateful for their dedication and compassion. Thank you to everyone who helped us—you made a difficult time so much more manageable.
Did excellent jobs to my day went well I have nothing negative to say about northwestern hospitals

I need a mammogram for September.  I was given  a reminder notice in the mail.  I called and cannot get a mammogram until January of the following year.  I have had breast cancer twice and do not want to miss an annual exam.  I was told someone would get back to me.  No one has.  I called and was put on hold and then was disconnected.  Now I know why some women do not get mammograms - stress and personnel who are unwilling to help - terribly disappointing!

The worst experience of my life!!!! I went into the hospital for severe malnutrition and Gastroparesis to get a GJ tube. needless to say, they put in the wrong tube and I lost 6 pounds during my stay. After my procedure to get an NG tube, I was in extreme pain, blood on my face, hands and gown. At first I was told I was struggling during the procedure and the report said there was no blood loss,That led to days of no voice. I would write notes and the nurses and doctors were visibly annoyed. I went down for a GJ tube placement and was given a G-tube that fed my paralyzed stomach for days. I told 10 different people, doctors and nurses that I did not feel good and it was not the right tube. I even showed Google pics and still was dismissed. The pressure buildup in my stomach was so much that I passed out and they told me that it was from the hot shower that I didn’t take because the water was so cold. They were working on my discharge papers when a pump Representative came in to show me how to take care of my tube. She noticed that it was indeed the wrong one. So I went seven days with no food. I lost 6 pounds and had to go through another weekend before they could get it corrected. At discharge My prescriptions were called In to the pharmacy. When I went to pick them up, the pharmacist told me that he told the doctor at the hospital he could not get one of the prescriptions. The facility needs major major Updating. The staff only say hello if you are their patient and they are in your room. This included both doctors nurses, and any staff you see in the hallway. No one listens. I can’t stress enough that I have no interest in ever going back to Northwestern hospital in Chicago!!!!

I can't express enough gratitude to the team at Northwestern—the nurses in the ICU, the respiratory staff, the doctors, the nurses on the 11th floor, dietary, cleaning staff, etc. Everyone I came in contact with was pleasant, knowledgeable, and amazing in their area of expertise. I am forever grateful for my experience at Northwestern. God placed me at the right place at the right time. While the experience was an adjustment for me as a patient, they all made it as pleasant and supportive as possible!
3 hrs to get transported to a room?  Stupid!  This hospital doesn’t care about its patients.

DON'T GO HERE. Absolutely terrible experience. You will wait a minimum of 6 hours. There are homeless people sleeping all over the waiting area. One homeless person was going around with a cigarette asking everyone if they had a lighter. The women's bathroom had blood all over the floor for hours on end. Such a disgusting experience overall.

I thought Northwestern was a great hospital, with high standards, especially because of its self published Best Hospital ratings. But I truly do not see it. It is better to try to take yourself at home, because this Emergency Department is not for emergencies at all whatsoever.

I would never come here again.

Overcharging you. Financial assistance is petty and scam. “How you pay monthly bills” not everyone lives alone. Waited 5 hours for hellhole just to be billed full ? No discount for those struggling. Shows how the healthcare is a joke
Horrible services I came to the ER and had to wait 8 hrs in the waiting area.

My best friend Noel had to go the emergency room at night which is kind of scary when you go at night.  A lot of drug addicts and homeless people, but once he was admitted to the hospital he was well taken care of but a great team.  This was the first time he was admitted to the hospital and he was well taken care of by the team of Doctors and the nurses.  Thank you to all who took care of his diverticulitis.  I am so grateful for the wonderful care given to my friend.

I have been a patient at the hospital for about 20 years. I hadn’t been in the ER for a while and when I came  in having flu-like symptoms I found it to be a nightmare.  Nothing but young people on staff who were socializing more than working.  I’ve been waiting for about 6 hours and I think they have barely called 10 people.  Most people got tired of waiting and just left.  One lady said he blood pressure was over 200 but instead of continuing to wait indefinitely she chose to go home and take her meds because she felt that she would have a better chance with that.  There is a lady next to me that is in chronic neck, shoulder and back pain who also has been suffering all night.  The security guards are unprofessional as are the medical staff.  The moved with no since of urgency at all.  It was as if they were just waiting for the next shift to start so that they could pass the work load.  The entire night shift was completely unconcerned and clearly only work for a check.  This is not the Northwestern Memorial that I am accustomed to to.  It is actually pretty appalling.

I called the operator number and spoke with Calvin who was very rude and had an attitude. I asked to speak to a  manager. He transferred me and then the phone hung up. I called back reached sassy Calvin again. Asked for a manager and a lady picked up and she said she was going to send over my complaint and apologized many times.i was transferred to the wrong department. Calvin probably won't be punished for his horrible attitude but at least people are aware. Listening skills are important working with the public!

My sister is in the hospital and this review is for the department that brings the food trays to the patients.

If you don’t want to work around people who are sick, this job isn’t for you, should think about finding one more suitable.

My sister is in the hospital and she has not gotten food that was hot for two days. I find out later that it’s because the staff has to wear yellow covers before going into patients’ rooms.

So the food will sit and sit and when the nurses bring the food in, it’s cold. Some days the food doesn’t come at all.

It’s expensive as hell to order uber eats because staff don’t want to do their jobs. If you don’t want to work around sick people, find somewhere else to work!!!

I was visiting from out of town and I had to go to their ER. Excellent service. All staff was very helpful and very professional. The nurses and doctors are very caring. I was treated very well and my medical issue was sorted immediately. I will forever be thankful for this wonderful experience when I needed most.

The worst hospital in the world. That’s why American are dying and nobody in the states care. I was with my dehydrating family member in the emergency room. I was carrying her in a wheelchair and she couldn’t even walk and felt like going to shock in anytime.
Thanks for the dangerous United States.
The counter is talking untrained and rude like she had a miserable life that she should be fired.
I read some others comments suffering the same and realized Changing her job is her best choice.
The security guard took time to check out the security, leaving my sister .
And next, thankfully the nurse is kind and act fast. However next we were left in a freezing cold waiting corridor. I was worried about my sister was having fever because the waiting corridor was freezing cold, and I asked for a male nurse to check out her temperature, and he walked away and never came back.
This place is like the worst place without humanity. All the patients were waiting helpless in the cold. If some suffer coma , I guess no one in this hospital will notice until the next day this person is dead cold.

This hospital is cruel, untrained and people there only care about themselves, not taking care of each others. Disappointed!!!!
Astonishingly Perfect. From ER intake to release. A well ordered machine with brains and an abundance of heart.

This place is horrible. Lack of care was the reason for my father’s death. He could’ve been saved, but they were not very attentive. He went into cardiac arrest if they responded the way they should’ve  he could’ve been saved. He was making a recovery but he was tied up during his cardiac arrest, imagine suffocating and not being able to move Both his wrists had blood imagine being tied up and trying to get up gasping for air he couldn’t  even press the panic button because he was tied up He was tied up because he didn’t want to eat the hospital food

I find this to be one of the best hospitals and healthcare institutions I've ever been using. I'd have a hard time giving any of these companies 5 stars because it's nearly impossible for a company like this to be that good. But 4 stars is about as good as it gets otherwise. The professionalism of the nurses for inpatient; the modern use of technology in medical care and in patient portal and records request; the preparedness of the company as a whole. These are major pluses.
Wonderful doctors, nurses and entire crew.

The service here was great.  My wife enjoyed most of the doctors, and they successfully delivered our two children.  The billing department on the other hand is a disaster.  The first pregnancy they had billing issues and set us to a collection agency even though we were still figuring out all of their mistakes with Blue Cross Blue Shield of Illinois.  The second pregnancy has been actually worse, which I didn't think was possible.  They are billing me for my wife's pregnancy, and it has taken over three months for them to figure it out.  It has been re-billed three times, and each time is incorrect and takes 30-45 business days to get the next bill.  It has caused many issues with my family's insurance plan, and has taken over 16 hours of my time, and counting, with no solution at all.  Be prepared to spend hours of your time with their billing department and your insurance agency.

Update on 5/5/25
They have now sent us to a debt collector.  The same exact issue from our first pregnancy with them.  I spoke to "a manager" last week and told them exactly the issues and that we would pay all the bills once it is corrected so we know how much we actually owe (since if you pay anything ahead of time and overpay you just piss money down the drain and never see it again).  My two stars just went to one star.  Avoid them like the plague unless you want to was 20+ hours of your life dealing with an absolute mess.

My wife went there recently for heart palpitations and tachycardia and they ran every test but found "nothing". Then upon us receiving the results we found that she had extremely  high THS indicating hypothyroidism which can cause the palpitations, and an elevated glucose that wasn't mentioned. They gave her no treatment on top of no diagnosis. All they had to do was literally Google what the results could mean and their implications. Wow I'm actually in complete shock that these people can call themselves professionals. Also they talked over my wife the entire time invalidating her concerns.

The security guard did not talk to me directly. Instead, he talked to my Uber driver. He just didn’t know how to act around me because I am visually impaired. Other than that, the medical staff were wonderful. They talk to me like an adult which I really appreciated. And they also ran some tests to diagnose me. They diagnosed me correctly. And I was seen before my scheduled appointment time of 11 AM. I am so glad they helped me. If I ever have an emergency in the future, I will choose Northwestern over the hospital near my building. They have excellent medical staff and they treat you like a human being. I cannot express how much I appreciated the care Northwestern gave me.

Wonderful hospital with wonderful care!  There have been NO homeless people wandering around!  Security is excellent!  You even need to get a security badge in order to visit the patient in their room!  I cannot say enough about the excellent care my husband got from his surgeon!  5 Stars!
Poor Services in the EMERGENCY Room. Nurses are inefficient. We waited for almost 8 hours just to do simple blood works and trans v ultrasound. WORST EMERGENCY ROOM EXPERIENCE !!!

Getting my IV placed was not an experience I'd like to repeat. It was bruised massively, I still have a bump there as well as pain weeks later. My specialist was good, I did feel a little rushed out, but I get how busy they are. I just wanted to ask more questions about my specific imaging, to be shown where stuff is.
Parking was $14 with the validation they give you at check in, FYI.

I was completely shocked on process to get into ER .  I have never experienced being treated as if you are visiting prison or going thru TSA check in before even allowed to enter ER with patient who was suffering from post operative complications.  The security was rude and bothered.  However, nurse were very patient and kind.

The lobby area is full of homeless people and others clearly not here for  emergency maters.  Complete deterioration of the ER.

Staff ER are outstanding. If u get in right away if it’s true emergency, which ours was.  Please don’t go here if u have cold or minor issues.  It will be awful experience waiting in that lobby

The wait times at this hospital are beyond ridiculous. They need to figure out how to get patients through faster 7 to 10 to 14 to 18 hour waits should not be the norm. I don’t care what hospital you’re going to people come there because they’re sick. They do not want to sit there all these hours waiting for somebody to finally take them in the back there needs to be a different system. They need to revamp their whole emergency room. I have a suggestion how about they make an area where if triage thinks that the people that are less sick can go to and see a doctor and then that doctor there can determine if they actually need to go back into the ER. This would filter out the people that are less sick. I think it’s genius. Maybe they should think about doing it this way it would weed out the people that only maybe need an antibiotic or just have a cold and nothing else serious those people can get prescriptions or told they’re fine and go home. This would probably get rid of half the people day in and day out. Question to the hospital why do you see your system is so broke but ignore it? That’s the question that really puzzles me and needs to be looked into.

Review of Emergency Room Experience – April 28

I am writing to document a deeply troubling experience I had in the Northwestern Memorial Hospital Emergency Room on April 28.

I was brought in following a seizure. I was disoriented, in physical pain, and needed urgent care. Instead, I was labeled with a psychiatric condition and ultimately admitted involuntarily based on an inaccurate and unfair characterization.

According to my medical records, the psychiatric resident, Dr. Bowlby, cited “intense eye contact” as one of the reasons for diagnosing psychosis. I want to be clear: I have had this kind of eye contact since birth. It's simply how I look — and, ironically, this appearance has been further shaped by a long-standing and unaddressed medical condition involving facial bone loss and empty sinuses.

The ER team dismissed this. I had been seeking care for years at Northwestern for these physical changes, and rather than being evaluated or believed, I was labeled.

It is unacceptable to pathologize a person's appearance — particularly one they have been asking for help understanding and treating. It is even more damaging to use that as justification for forced psychiatric intervention.

I am asking Northwestern to reflect on how often subjective impressions — especially from residents under pressure — are given institutional power over someone’s life and chart. In this case, a seizure, and a visible anatomical issue, were overridden by discomfort with how I looked.
Run as far away from this hospital as you can.

If you’re looking at Northwestern for lung transplant DO NOT BELIEVE the picture they sell you about after care. Any little thing u call for help they will tell u to come in emergency but leave you down stair for 7hours no exaggeration

Terrible experience I will be notifying the Chicago health department and reporting my ambulance driver. They still have my drivers license that is out of state if they do not return that I will take legal matters. This is ridiculous if you come visit Chicago good luck if you get sick Terrible people do not care.

Worst experience and I felt like I have been scammed when the bills came. I went in to NWurgent care because I had this recurring chest pain that occurs once a month. My husband said to go to urgent care so they could do .a ECG when I am experiencing the pain. Even though ECG was normal the nurse urged me to go to emergency room and when I asked her why she said my “condition” required blood test which they could not do and offered to call an ambulance and I told her I feel perfectly fine and I would walk (that was creating a sense of urgency with ambulance offer so I think twice about not going). When I was there they did another ECG and I asked them if they could get it from urgent care as it was literally done 10 mins ago. They said no. Then I waited 5 hours in the waiting room. My “condition” that I was offered an ambulance for suddenly became nothing even though they dod not additional test until 2 hours. They did a blood test and chest x-ray which came out negative. After 5 hours I was given a seat inside which was screened (not a bed). They made me wait for another hour, during which they did another repeat of blood test.And then the doctor declared I did not have a heart ttack but I should go through a stress test, which I was fine with. I feel like I have been scammed and they billed me for highest complexity emergency room visit which was nothing but outpatient care after hours. Why send non-emergency cases when you know your emergency room already has 4 to 6 hour wait time?
Sadly we spent our NYE here in er, BUT nurses and staff were lovely, thank you for taking care of my husband that fast! 🙏🙏

I now see why they are only a 3.5 star rated organization on Google. Being newer to Chicago, I always thought Northwestern was the hospital group to go to and that they were prestigious, employing the best staff, but I am wrong!

After having a surgical procedure scheduled not once, but TWICE, having to make big sacrifices around the scheduling, they have dropped the ball.

If you are getting surgery, you will want to make  triple check that you are in fact actually covered and they have your correct insurance plan ahead of time! Get it in writing that they have verified your insurance and your information is correct immediately as their incompetent staff will inform you a few days prior to your procedure that you’ve had scheduled for 90+ Days! Also demand that their pre-op team schedules you 3-4 weeks prior to ensure you can actually keep your date!

STOP WAITING FOR THE 11th HOUR TO DO IMPORTANT TASKS THAT IMPACT YOUR PATIENTS. DON’T CONFIRM SURGERIES UNTIL YOU’VE VERIFIED PLANS!!!!

That’s not much to ask for!

This could be a sign that their surgeons are trash and I need to seek care elsewhere.

Good luck!!
Literally the worst hospital in Chicago. Churn and burn don’t care for the patients at all. Go sit in a bed in the hallway for 16 hours just to get no help.

My Drs care team doesnt do a good job working on my behalf. For example They told me that calling the Billing Dept is my responsibility

And their hours for Drs are pretty bad, about 8-4
I’m on vacation and thought I’d probably die last night but could not call 911 because people who work in er rooms are so mean sometimes I’d rather just die alone in my room.

Great Hospital that has outgrown itself. I have been an off and on patient for 30 years, had 2 kids here and received MRSA infection during 2nd C-Section but it is still a shining star of Chicagoland medical field.

I've been waiting since 4:15 pm to be discharged it's now 10:58 pm I haven't had a nurse to stop by and check up on me within the total time frame not see if I needed water to get to urinate to see if I needed a sandwich to check my blood pressure my oxygen levels nor  my ekg not one nurse saw me from I was pushed outside into the hallway from ER room 21 pushed al9ng side the wall 2 200bft from the emergency door entrance I've sitting here being subjected to cold air sitting next to a toom that says Isolation my doctors were pulled into a dire emergency yet I'm experiencing a clot in my vein wasn't given any blood thinner medication or shot to prevent it my last dose of my elliquis was at 8 am I could've been laying in the hallway dead they probably wouldn't have noticed not one single person checked up on me I had to continue to get up to go the nurses station for updates bout my discharge not one single person seemed even slightly concerned what a terrible experience I've had today and I'm still having it I'm writing this as I still sit here waiting 1st they said the doctors were busy then they had to figure out course of treatment to take before discharging me even when the doctor had that information I still had to get up to go ask for an update I sat here and sat here like I was invisible what imperfect care I received today I'm disgusted

Best hospital in Illinois

I am grateful for them helping my mother who had Severe, I repeat, SEVERE Acute Pancreatitis, but the urgency for emergencies and her condition especially was off. When we arrived at the hospital by ambulance, she was screaming in pain and just didn’t know what to do. I didn’t know what to do either. When they were checking her in, they asked her for her ID while she was in severe pain and acted like it was just a minor condition. They also couldn’t get the difference between internal and external pain, in which both need to be taken seriously. Her screams of pain were almost ignored. It was so serious that she could’ve died from multiple organ failure or developed pancreatic cancer. They then had the both of us wait in the lobby, where she was still in so much pain and needed immediate attention. I eventually had to call a friend nearby to advocate for her while the staff are the ones who are supposed to advocate for patients. Their communication is also an issue and it needs to be fixed. However, I still rate 4 stars for them helping my mother live a longer and healthier life to show my gratitude.

The arrogance runs rampant through this place! From the phlebotomists to the cardiac specialists, there doesn't seem to be a shortage of self-inflated egos!! I'm not here for that. *Not all employees here,  just a few!

There is a tremendous lack of communication in this place which is truly frustrating for family members that deserve to be in the know.
Secondly,  the doctors never seem to be on the same page regarding the care of the patient.

A colloboration between physicians and family members to ensure exceptional quality  health care for the patient should be the no.1 focus.

Constant surgeries are not always the best option for curing an inherited heart  disease.
You are professionals. Do your job!  Earn your keep!

Northwestern Memorial need to improve on actively communicating with family members by providing comprehensive exceptional health care for families and their loved ones! This place causes more damage than good.

*Nurses and doctors should remain professional at all times, starting with (Cait)
*Cait 29792   10/28/2024!!

I do not wish to address this issue with a superior,  but I will not hesitate to do so!!

I think this hospital deserves more than any other hospital , the doctors and nurses are the best ! What words can I say. Thankyou for carrying for my mom 2 years ago, she told me all there is amazing care only the best she said. She passed in 2022. Thankyou for her care.🙏

Excellent patient care,and good doctors, and no long waiting to be seen by a doctor.I'm posting this review on my friend's phone. My name is Rosalind Williams

“I just want to take a moment to thank Rafael, Maria, and Will for everything you’ve done for me during my recovery. Floor 9 and 12 Your constant care and kindness have meant the world to me. Your dedication and compassion made such a difference, and I’m forever grateful for the way you looked after me with so much heart. Thank you all for being there for me when I needed it most.”
L.R.M

I have never written a review for a hospital. For this to be the alleged "best hospital in Illinois 13 years straight", I am convinced they are not including the Emergency Room. I have been here several times and my last visit was my last visit because of the care, or lack thereof, received. I miscarried and asked to have any tissue or remains sent to my doctor per her request so we could determine the cause. The tissue disappeared. That was 9 years ago. I've never returned. Today I'm here with my husband and we have been waiting in the waiting room for 3 hours. No bloodwork. Nothing. They couldn't even find the vein in triage. My husband has huge veins. I know it's in order of severity. However, he is diabetic and they should be making sure he is stable. Oh and in case you were wondering, yes he's Black (I only mention that because many of the previous reviews come from people who have had horrible experiences and they are also Black).  The fact that this hospital has 2.6 stars and they are doing nothing to rectify it is a testament to their disregard for the welfare of others. You're supposed to "do no harm"--when in fact, you're doing nothing. Do better.

Came in at 5 am and is 7 hours and counting. Doctors seem to lack urgency for an emergency room?? People should definitely know in advance that this is a teaching hospital and the only thing I have learned is that they lack medical urgency.

I wanted to write a quick review to thank Dr. Ziho Lee and his amazing urology team of caring, professional doctors and nurses for the excellent care I received during a recent major surgery at Nothwestern Memorial. The procedure was very complex and intricate but, because of the absolutely amazing job and contributions of everyone involved, it resulted in an excellent post-op course and outcome.

Shortly after my retirement (4 years ago) I was diagnosed with radiation cystitis following the treatment for prostate cancer. All of a sudden, the retirement that my wife and I had looked forward to all our working lives turned out to be NOTHING like we had planned. We had lost hope that we would ever have a normal life again. However, once we met Dr. Lee and his wonderful team our hopes were soon restored. As a result of the miraculous, minimally-invasive robotic feat of Dr. Lee and his team our lives are back on track again!

Needless to say, my wife and I are so grateful that we were led to Northwestern Memorial.

Special thanks to Dr. Z. Lee, Dr. A. Tavakolian,  Dr. D. Greenberg, R. Lewis, PA, Chauncey, RN, Dr. T. Zembower, Elizabeth Rauh, RN and all the other wonderfully personable, talented, professional individuals who played a part in my recovery.

I AM FOREVER GRATEFUL!

I came to the ER here and was admitted as a patient with a 5 day stay and the care here was horrible. Dr. Denise Monti, why is this unsympathetic uncaring doctor allowed to practice. Brian, thoracic spine, kidneys, adrenals, pancreas, pelvis and lymph node metastasis.  The modern targeted therapies have been a cornerstone of treatment along with my complete lifestyle changes.

Message for Sean you are awesome and you shamed a lot of Doctors in the ER yesterday you are going to be an awesome Doctor God bless you on your journey you are a natural healer by how you treat people im glad I came in and met you🙏🏽💕
Worst ED I've experienced. Staff thinks everything is joke.

In September 2021, my life changed in the most unimaginable way. At just 34 years old, I suffered a ruptured brain aneurysm. As a mom to two little girls, ages 6 and 7 at the time, I was terrified — not just for myself, but for them. I couldn’t imagine leaving them behind, and I certainly didn’t want their lives to continue without me in them. In that moment, I had no idea how my story would unfold, but thanks to Dr. Patel and his extraordinary team at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, I am here today — alive, healthy, and able to embrace life more fully than I ever could have imagined.
Dr. Patel is incredible. From the very first moment, it was clear that he and his team were not only highly skilled, but also deeply compassionate. They treated me as more than a patient — they treated me as a person, a mother, a daughter, someone whose life and family mattered. Their urgency, care, and expertise were matched only by their kindness. Every nurse, doctor, and staff member went above and beyond to make me and my family feel supported, informed, and reassured during what was, without exaggeration, the scariest experience of our lives. I could feel that they were fighting for me as much as I wanted to fight for myself, and I knew I was in the best possible hands.
Thanks to Dr. Patel and his team, I recovered. I returned to work only six weeks later, something I didn’t think would be possible at the time. Since then, I’ve received a promotion, bought a new home, and even started a small family farm. Yes, after surviving a ruptured brain aneurysm, I apparently decided that goats and chickens would be the perfect addition to my life — and somehow, even in the chaos, it’s all been joyful and fulfilling. More than anything, though, I have been here for my daughters every single day. I’ve watched them grow, celebrated milestones, shared laughter, wiped tears, and read countless bedtime stories — experiences I almost lost forever.
Every single day is a reminder of the gift I was given. Dr. Patel and his team didn’t just save my life — they gave my daughters their mom back, they gave my family a future, and they gave me the chance to continue dreaming, building, and laughing (yes, even with goats and chickens in the mix). They combine world-class medical skill with genuine humanity, and I have never met a team so dedicated to their patients. Their compassion and care made a terrifying experience not only survivable but also, in many ways, life-affirming.
If you or a loved one ever need care, know this: Dr. Patel and his team at Brigham and Women’s are not just exceptional doctors — they are miracle workers who restore hope, heal families, and give people the chance to live fully again. I am endlessly grateful to them, not only for saving my life, but for giving me a second chance to keep building the life I love. No words can fully capture my gratitude, but I hope this gives some sense of the life-changing impact they have had on me and my family.
To Dr. Patel and every member of his team: thank you, from the bottom of my heart. You didn’t just save me — you gave me back laughter, dreams, chaos, and joy. You gave me back life itself.

Good luck trying to schedule literally any type of appointment through this hospital system, even when you have insurance THROUGH BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HEALTH PLAN. Oh, and if you decide to move at any point in your life, it isn't possible to switch your doctor to any other location in Massachusetts. I will not be driving over an hour just to get to a primary care appointment while there are other doctors that are accepting new patients fifteen minutes away from me. Good thing I'm healthy enough to wait God knows how long to get new health insurance and find another place in the area that actually lets you make appointments with them rather than giving you random phone numbers to call where nobody helps you. **If you’re considering a quadruple bypass surgery for your loved one—**PLEASE READ THIS FIRST. It could save a life.
I am writing this in heartbreak and outrage over what happened to my father-in-law. In mid-March, he was admitted to the hospital and told he urgently needed a quad bypass. His arteries were reportedly 80% blocked, and we were told he could have a heart attack “at any moment.” The pressure to agree to surgery was intense—from the doctors and, painfully, from us as a family. We were told this was a “routine procedure,” that he was a “perfect candidate,” and that this would give him a better, longer life.

That could not have been further from the truth.
Shortly after the surgery, he suffered a micro stroke—which should have been a red flag. Instead of investigating further, they rushed him to a rehab facility. Days later, he suffered a massive stroke that has now left him in a near-vegetative state, requiring constant oxygen, with a severe Stage 3/4 untreatable bed ulcer, and unable to return home. Since then, he’s endured even more trauma: additional surgeries like a tracheostomy that only worsened his condition and quality of life.

What we thought would be a healing process has turned into a nightmare. This surgery destroyed his life.
No one told us to get a brain MRI first. No one talked about prior mini-strokes. No one explained that his age or condition could increase post-op risks. We were just told to “trust the process.”
Let me be clear: Quadruple bypass is not a “safe” surgery for everyone. It’s not “routine.” It’s not “low-risk.” And no one should be pressured into it without full transparency and thorough testing—especially neurological evaluations. The system failed him. And it failed us.
Now we are left helpless, watching a strong, intelligent, beloved man fade before our eyes—all because we believed the doctors when they said this was the best option.
Don’t let this happen to your family. Do your homework. Ask the hard questions. Get second opinions. Get full-body and brain scans. And don’t let anyone rush you.
This review is not written out of anger—it’s written out of deep pain, and in the hope that it might prevent another family from making a decision they can never take back.

It was discovered that i had lung cancer in mid October of last year. On Feb 20th of this year, I was fortunate enough to have the brilliant dr Lanuti and his brilliant team do surgery to first remove a wedge with the growth in it, and ultimately the upper lobe at the same time, as it was malignant.
Having this amazing team defined how I dealt with surgery and the whole ordeal. They were all so attentive, caring, thorough and even loving as they dealt with me.
I was in hospital for a week and every day I had a few visits from the team, including dr Lanuti himself,  the surgeon, who often changed my bandages. Imagine.
Dr Lanuti and his team (shout out to Kelly and Matt, who i dealt with alot) made me feel well taken care of,  important, and most importantly safe. I felt safe from my consultation to date. A million thank yous to my wonderful team. And whatever I must face in the future, I will be fine, because I will be in the care of Dr Lanuti and his amazing team.

Special thanks to my nurse, Olga Campose, who looked over me with care and diligence, reducing my stress and making sure I understood daily what to expect and told awesome cat stories, distracting me and keeping me entertained ♡

We recently had the privilege of visiting Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston to welcome our new granddaughter.

The hospital campus provides ample amenities to make the waiting period more comfortable, including a cafeteria, a 24-hour Panera Bread location, and a food court just a short walk away with additional dining options and a sit-down restaurant.

I have PSC and was emailed from PSC Registry regarding a Dolphin study being done by Brigham PSC Collaborative and Harvard. They listed criteria of being over 18, having a 1.5 times upper limit of normal ALP and the inclusion criteria listed, I met all the requirements. I went through the process of having an interview going over study and releasing all my medical records. I specifically asked during interview if I needed to have IBD, IBS, Crohn's, UC, any of those things to qualify. I was told I did not. I was then notified that I qualified for the study and would likely be in group 2 pool, possibly even group 1 if people were disqualified. I was very excited. Not more than 2 days later I was told I was disqualified from study because I did not have IBD. I asked that this is not in any of the study source material or in the inclusion criteria. I was told that within 2 days, they changed their mind and only wanted people with PSC and IBD. It was a huge waste of time, giving over sensitive medical documents and just pure disappointment. Months go by and the Brigham PSC collaborative sends another email saying looking for more people in for the Dolphin study. Again, no mention of needing IBD. I email them asking about it and again is told they are only looking for PSC with IBD for study. How can a person have any confidence that the study will be professionally administered if they can't even update the criteria for the study under inclusions or description. Then the people I speak with, Sophie and another, act like I am the idiot who can't follow instructions or that I am being unreasonable and ignorant.

Not only did they save my Dad's life 27 years ago but now saving my mom's. Would HIGHLY RECOMMEND! The staff here are absoustely wonderful angels, every single one of them! Thank you all for ALL that you do. I'm beyond thankful for you all.

They came and I asked to go to Lenox Hill Hospital but I was taken to this poor excuse of a hospital. I was seen by several drs and was asked each time what was wrong with me.  I could hardly talk because my body would not stop convulsing. The original Dr that saw me told me that I was probably having a reaction to the injections that my neurologist gave me st his office. He stated that I needed to be observed for 4-18 hrs. I arrived at the hospital at approximately 3:30 pm. They refused to help me up go to the bathroom. My sister arrived and she stayed until around 10:40. When she left she was assured that I would stay overnight. Fast forward to 1 am. Another Dr came in and told me that I was being discharged because they could not find anything wrong me. I was still experiencing symptoms and had horrible nausea and a horrible migraine. I had to dress myself and they wouldn’t help me to get a ride. Since I was still experiencing spasms, I was unable to put my shoes on because they were heels. It was raining out and had to walk out barefoot and transport put me in a cab   I cannot believe that these horrible people call themselves drs. And in the condition I was in the Dr told me that I could drive myself home if I chose to do so.   This was the absolute worst experience of my life. When I raised this concern, the charge nurse on duty, Amy, responded, “What did you expect the nurse to do?” Wow. That’s not someone I would ever trust to lead a unit, let alone care for a loved one. Absolutely unacceptable.

They say they can call security if a patient’s family member gets loud—but who do we call when the nurse and charge nurse are the ones being loud, inappropriate, and lacking basic empathy?

This kind of treatment reflects a bigger problem. It’s no wonder others have shared similar experiences in their reviews. A hospital’s reputation should be earned by how it treats people—not just its ranking.

Went in to the ER and was treated beyond good. The doctors listened to everything I said, they constantly came to check up on me and the nurses were even greater.my wait wasn't long. I'm changing over to this hospital for everything. Being treated like an actual human being

I came here for pregnancy related matters and honestly the doctors, nurses, and reception staff were all wonderful! They gave me extra cookies when I was hungry, and covered me with blankets when I was cold. Would recommend!

Went to the ER because I had been feeling extreme fatigue, dizziness, nausea, and loss of appetite for over a month that had gotten worse (I lost 10 lbs). Although I have easy and visible veins, they missed and dripped blood all over me. After about 5 hours, they said my labs came back normal and that they were sending me home, even though something was clearly wrong with me. They didn’t even put me on an IV (which is one of the first things doctors do with fatigue). Luckily, I was able to go to my parents’ in Florida and got actual help from doctors there. Don’t go here unless you know what’s wrong with you, because they won’t figure it out either.

Came in with a family member. One week of illness. One day vomiting and black stool. 6 days of Nausea  and dizziness, chills,hot flashes and pain in side.  Couldn’t go to work. Dr says probably a virus.-maybe there’s a hemroid and she could check that.  I insisted on an mri but she would only consent to a cat scan and they came to give an x ray for procedural purposes.  I said no to the c ray and cat. Both are useless. The mri would show blood vessels in his side and organs. Leaving with fluids given and trying to get them to take a stool sample for analysis.  This is the second time I felt like the place has become mediocre.  Years here with my elderly parents I’ve never had complaints.  The one before this the same family member had a bacteria gone sepsis. They treated it but couldn’t identify the bacteria.  Never heard of this kind of thing.  How can you not take a sample and identify the bacteria.  Northshore has been slipping under too. Now I have to find a new hospital for my family.  I drive 2 hours for crappy care.
Rude and unprofessional security! Do they really think I come to the hospital for leisure and fun??

My 5-month old daughter was injured by the EEG technician, Junqi Zheng, and my MIL and I were verbally abused by her. Attached is a photo of the 0.5” scab on my daughter’s head where Junqi (the technician) scraped my daughter’s head so hard prior to placing the electrodes.

This is not the first time a complaint has been made about Junqi so I am frustrated that my family’s pain could have been avoided as it sounded like she should have been fired a long time ago. The fact that she knew nothing was going to be done about her poor performance is why I am writing this. I hope that no other family will be hurt by Junqi. She even said to me “go ahead, report me, here’s my ID. The camera isn’t on” (i.e the interaction wasn’t recorded so she knew she was safe). She is a drag on her team, patients and the Cornell network, and needs to be fired.

From the moment she walked in, she had a bad attitude. For example, she ROLLED HER EYES when I asked her two questions:
(1) how long the procedure would take, and
(2) whether she had to tie my baby’s hair in buns bc she was pulling so tight that it made her cry

At times, she was PURPOSELY HURTING my child. Junqi used a wooden Q-tip to separate my baby’s hair into sections and was scraping her scalp so hard with the wooden end that my baby was crying. She COULD HAVE USED THE SOFT COTTON SIDE to separate her hair into sections. She didn’t even have that much hair!

In addition, I asked her if we can use water instead of the suction to keep the tape on (the suction was making my baby cry even more) and she said “have you done this before” and I said “well we did a 1 hour EEG here at Cornell and they used water so was just wondering.” She ROLLED HER EYES and said “THAT WAS A DIFFERENT LOCATION.” Please note she COULD’VE SIMPLY LOWERED THE SUCTION LEVEL. The second technician did exactly that and explained that there are different suction levels. Why would you use the same suction level for an adult on a baby?!

When I asked for break because my baby was freaking out due to the pain caused by Junqi, leading my baby to scratch her face so hard it was bleeding, Junqi said “why are you here” and I said “well because she’s been having spasms”. Her response was “you can refuse EEG. You’re hurting baby”. I told her that I didn’t want to be there and wished my daughter was happy and healthy but that she was having spasms and she kept repeating “you can refuse EEG.” She thought this procedure was unnecessary, which is absurd and not her decision. And if anything, SHE had already hurt my baby creating a wound on my baby’s scalp.

This was the last straw and I told her if she was having a bad day, she should not take it out on her patients and that she didn’t have to be there. Her response was “ok it’s better for me to leave.”

Not only was my daughter injured, but Junqi wasted my time (I had to take off work to go to the EEG with my daughter) and many medical professionals time (from the NP to the nurses to the management team), her team’s time as her team member had to cover her patient, and 4 hours of my life as she did not complete the procedure and I had to wait that long for a new technician.

No actions were taken against this woman who hurt my child, no apology from her, and it is unclear whether she was provided training after this incident (i.e. use different suction levels based on patient’s age, don’t use a sharp wooden stick to separate a patients hair - use the soft side, don’t roll your eyes at patients, etc.)

I went to the hospital tonight. Was very bad stomach pains? A man came to try to draw my blood. He couldn't, because my veins is hard to find. So what did he do he? Left him with somebody else instead doing. What are you supposed to do for me? He went to somebody else. Never came back to see if I was okay. None of that so I got up and I left

Horrible. Came all the way from Queens 1.5 hour trip and hiked 20 mins, to visit my Neice(8mo). And they said I can't see her because I'm bringing my 4 year old child. When 2 staff members over the phone already had confirmed I could come with my child. This hospital has no near by train stations, that was a horrible walk and it was raining out side. Staff members need to be more considerate of people especially people with children. Please take care of your diet, exercise, wash your hands, breathe through your nose and open the windows so that you won't end up in this hospital.
Great doctor always take care and put 100% of her knowledge to help my daughter to feel better

Literally the worst hospital I’ve been to in my life, fainting and falling, but they couldn’t even give a wheelchair or a walker or put a fall risk… the diagnosis they gave ended up being completely wrong, thank god I got out of there and went right to nyu langone. Literally a ghetto clinic s better than this hospital

Waited for gastroenterologist for over an hour on telehealth,  called office twice while waiting told me to wait. Dr logged in for new pt appt , didn't go over history,  meds, issues I'm having.( total of 7 mins interaction). I have severe gastro issues and I won't be going to this office again. Ridiculous my time is just as important.
The nurses are very professional,especially nurse PHIL from 8north. The Doctors ,well the younger the doctor the worst the service.

I gave birth to my son there. Although the Dr was great. The service was horrible. After being released the nurse just pointed to the elevator and told me to take it. I was completely lost. While my brother went to get the car. I never had such a terrible scary experience. Never again. Disappointed 😞

No this hospital my family trusted for years .My mother went in got diagnosed with the flu and was overdosed by a nurse with her pain meds and this lead to my mother's passing 😢 bye the way they allowed the nurse to continue her care after the incident. The doctor on December 26th stated that when they had to give my mom norcane through her nose it went into her left lung which caused a Septic pneumonia in which that caused cardiac arrest then her demise 😩😩😩😩😩
Large hospital complex. Lots of specialties. Plan ahead for very long security lines. 45+ mins sometimes

I recently accompanied a client to Cornell, where I had the opportunity to observe the exceptional care provided by the staff. As a caregiver who frequently visits various hospitals, I was particularly impressed by the professionalism and warmth displayed by the team. My client was very pleased with the experience, and I would like to commend Ms. Antoinette in particular for her informative guidance on wound management. Overall, the visit was outstanding and truly exemplified high-quality care.

My wife was recently admitted in NYP for car-t cell transplant, and had an exceptional experience from start to finish. The facility was clean, well-organized, and efficient. The reception staff was friendly and made the check-in process seamless.

Her doctors were not only knowledgeable but also took the time to thoroughly explain my condition and treatment options. The nursing staff was incredibly kind, attentive, and made sure I was comfortable throughout my stay. I truly appreciated their patience and professionalism.
Oncologist Dr Mejia is an outstanding physician.

The hospital also maintained excellent hygiene and safety protocols, which made me feel secure during my visit. Overall, I’m extremely grateful for the outstanding care I received and would highly recommend NYP to anyone in need of medical attention.

I was trying to make an appointment with the urologist but the receptionist kept hanging up on me. At first she told me to hold and I got disconnected after 10 mins. Later for the 3rd time she picked up my calls and hung up right away. I don’t understand why they have to work in a medical field if they are not an empathetic being

I’m parking my car all the time outside of the hospital .todayThe nasty security guard told me that I can’t park there and when I try to tell him that I’m parking here every day, he screamed at me and told me that if I park there my car will be towed and unfortunately I need to to park on the Avenue

I feel very disappointed by the customer service by phone, I called to make an appointment and the woman “Leni” gave me the worst service being very rude to me, I think a welcoming and warm service is very necessary in medical industry, please take care of that.

I agree with the other dissatisfied patients. Each and every visit I encountered was negative. One dr was such a disaster I got up and ended my visit they were calling me I ignored them got on the elevator. This same dr lied on my summary which I’m getting amended. And then another dr tried to gas light me after procedure ask me did I read summary I said I didn’t receive one the nurse told me the dr are the ones that bring the summary so why is he asking you then the other dr tells you one thing but put different info on your summary there’s more but it’s a waste of energy all I can say is if dr nurse don’t do what they are supposed to do contact office of professional discipline

Security is behave inhuman,we came with patients,distance who came with patients,they are in stress,we come from different,place,only reason we came here, somebody say is hospital,

Hopefully this is the last visit for patient.

This place is a true example of healthcare professionals who not only possess the highest level of expertise but also show genuine compassion and care for their patients. I will never forget the kindness and warmth of all the nurses, doctors, and staff members who made me feel human again during my recovery.Thank you, once again, for giving me the gift of health and life. Your professionalism, compassion, and dedication will never be forgotten.
With heartfelt thanks,
NATIA MALAZONIA
Nice hospital, but there should be more privacy in the pediatric unit
Is an amazing hospital all around.

Don’t park in the garage at the hospital.
