This review is about the security process for visitors  .. it’s ridiculous for such a big hospital. You have three to four security personnel standing around and only one checking in a line of 30+ people. It doesn’t matter if it’s 8am or 5pm - this is always the case. I’ve been to NYU, Elmhurst, Sloan Kettering, Mt Sinai etc and never had to wait in line for over 30 min. It’s ridiculous, do better NYP.

A place with very good care from a range of medical services. No one wants to be in a situation to need it, but they try to make the stay as comfortable as possible. Special shout out to the team on 10-Central and 10-West for their wonderful care.

Building is comfortable.

Absolutely hate the 11th floor South team they are very inconsistent and inconsiderate.. they nurses in this unit are mediocre and they seemed as if they just went to school to collect a pay check and dont serve any definite purpose in this field . They lack the compassion and empathy it takes to complete this role & they treat your loved one and you as if you guys dont have a chance and its the end of the road . Marguerite Koch especially show a lack of care and attention to detail and comfort in my mothers state . Complete disregard for her situation and treated her like a piece of nothing on the side of the road . On top of not getting the attention and level of care we deserve they continuously try and discharge and push my mother out to a different facility.. i wish i knew where to file a complaint and make my voice heard against this entire hospital. I hate them . And i honestly hate the people that work there . I pray when Marguerite parent is dying & fighting for their life that someone does them worse than what they did me and that by some grace of god that im there able to witness and watch the sadness and heartbreak in her eyes and look her in her face and show no remorse towards her situation no matter how bad her parent life is being affected .
Rude operator hung up on someone  when i had hard time speaking

Review for the Psychiatric E.R. It is important to know that this is nothing more than a holding cell. They can hold your loved one here against their will, or the requests of the family - for as long as they want. We brought a friend suffering from depression and they held him for 3 nights.  He voluntarily checked in and was stable/sane the entire time. They offered ZERO therapy or psychiatric services except offering benzos for panic attacks. The cost for holding our friend against his will for 3 days was nearly $20,000. The entire time we were begging to
have him released and Dr Benudis said she will release him when she feels like it. They never discussed a plan of discharge or would give us any metric on what it would take to to have him discharged until the last day. Their job is to lock up the patient as long as possible and extract as much money as possible while
providing no medical services. It’s a JAIL CELL. A horrible facility and truly terrible doctors I wouldn't wish this experience on my worst enemy. DR. Abigail Benudis was particularly terrible. One of the meanest and dismissive doctors I’ve ever spoken to. Incompetent and unavailable the entire time. Keep in mind they make the patient sign away their rights once they are admitted and we were LUCKY to get him out in 3 days. Most stay much longer or are transferred to the 3 week psych ward.

Dirtiest hospital EVER and that says alot considering ive had 23 Surgeries. Staff was too busy on their phones rather than find care for the patients at hand. Severely lacking in care and empathy. Waiting are was pushed an hour back more than once due to over booking or lapped schedules…
The ER is always overwhelmed.  They need to expand that ER drastically. That's why you get stuck in a hallway for hours and hours.

This place saves lives I can attest to that first hand . The ER is exceptional . Virtually no wait and they are very attentive. The oncology Dept. is a beast and will not dilly dally in regard to treatment and go full send  to combat the disease and get you relief. They are upfront and don’t pull punches. I fully recommend this hospital and like I stated before the E.R. Here  should represent the standard for all hospitals. I understand everyone’s experience is different due to different ailments but for the many times I have experienced their care they have been outstanding. If you are admitted the rooms and care provided by the staff is way above average compared to many other hospitals I have encountered. The only discrepancy I can say is the parking fees at the hospital valet. It is way over priced but they do give vouchers for admitted patients family for one vehicle while the person is admitted.

We had a midnight emergency (croup) when we first moved to the state. We took my 2 year old in to the ER, and they were so kind! They made her feel safe, our wait times were so short, and we were only in the building for 1.5hrs. They were also so understanding, and this is the first ER that took our medical history/medical allergies seriously. They were very very knowledgeable about our rare conditions as well which is something I’ve never seen in an ER setting! I was very impressed!
Very nice and much faster than other hospitals

ER service is horrible. We were admitted to the ER the night before. By 3:30am they were confident the patient needed to be admitted to the hospital for a room. But no beds. So it is now 6pm, still in the ER without a bed. Staff makes themselves incredibly sparse. At one point, the patient needed a vomit bag since he was admitted for vomitting yet none were given as stand-bys. I rushed to the desk where no one was there. A nurse came with her back turned to me, I had to ask “ma’am” three times before she turned. At this point, the patient was already projectile vomitting on the floor. They did clean it up though- by sopping it up with towels. No custodian mopping any time after. There was also a half full urine sample behind our bed from god knows who. Each doctor that comes every 5-6 hours or so says something different or treats us like brand new. No one addresses the bedside family, and prior to the projectile vomitting we hadn’t asked a thing from staff. The patient also has something highly contagious, but that isn’t stopping them from cramming the area bed to bed with patients. I hope the old couple sharing the curtained area with us is healthy enough to not be immunocompromised. Oh wait, they are old and currently in the ER. Horrible facilities, horrible staffing issues. I have seen staff sitting around on facebook messenger (the same nurse who couldn’t be bothered to be addressed until projectile vomitting was audible), as well as several staff members sitting and scrolling tiktok. I get that there is a ton of downtime between test results, but for god’s sake just make these people do their rounds and talk to their patients so that they don’t end up projectile vomitting all over the floor. Horrible, cynical place. You will go hours without anyone talking to you as the patient, never if you are at the bedside.
Trash hospital, I highly don't recommend

Medical staff are good buildings and signage are embarrassing bad looks run printed paper signs etc  also good luck actually getting to your appointment if you go into the  wrong entrance the staff won’t even know how to lead you

Being hospitalized in this hospital is being the worst experience of my life, for almost two weeks with prostatitis I have never been seen by a urologist, they removed the urinary catheter without an evaluation by the urologist of my prostate, so they had to drain my urine, the staff has no empathy with the pain... it was terrible, terrible, and to this day I still haven't seen the urologist even though I have an emergency with a urinary catheter, they postponed my appointment for next week. in September explain by this same way the horror that had been my days of hospitalization on the 7th floor of this place between September 7 and September 10 of the year and year

my complaint was attended by the lady Kelly McCabe but apparently she misinterpreted my discomforts, she in her report dated October 15 of the year in progress I put her on the way to what she calls pain management by the nurse involved, and it is the opposite even though I told her about it. repeatedly that the nurse that day did her job in the best way and managed the pain in the best way she could, my discomfort was with the 5 doctors who during that stay were in charge of my health, they decided to remove the urine catater without evaluating the prostate, having on my chart a CT abdomen an pelvis with contrast dated September 7 that said that my prostate was enlarged so it was evident that my prostate did not allow my urine to go down alone, in its report also sealla who refuses to take ibuprofen on September 9 obviously had to do it I have kidney failure 3A and that drug is contraindicated but the Drs did not sin that detail either, another point in their report says that it was I who said that I wanted to urinate without the totally false cater urine and proof of this was that all the nurses were asked to please place the permanent catarer urine and they told me that no that the Doctors specified that they were going to urinate without the cater urine and proof of it was that was that all the nurses asked to do not to urinate without the urine catering and that they were going to put it on the doctor's. I had to urinate by myself and after having a strong discussion with the Dr who was in charge was that I agreed to put back the urine catheter proof of this this my discussion with her that must be recorded by requesting an interpreter from Spanish to English, another important point and to finish the Drs who in the end are the ones who make the decisions withdrew the initial catarer without 1- evaluating and checking that the prostate was still inflamed which made it impossible for me to urinate for me. same and 2- had changed the antibiotic 3 times, that is, they were not even ready to see if the antibiotic was the one to verify whether or not they should remove the catheter in principle and then to the horror of the pain of removing the urine without wanting to put the urinary catheter back fixed as at the end I pass after me arguing with the Dr in charge that night I agree to put it back, and I repeat it was I who told her everything about it, then do not tell me about the nurses involved that they did their best work, my annoyance is with the origin of that horror that were the bad decisions of the medical staff that...

So, NYP responds, it's sorry my expectations weren't met.  If my review had been read by a Human Being and, NOT a COMPUTER responding to the ONE STAR, my written review would have been enough for NYP to know what the problem was and that its feedback department didn't need additional information.  NYP is USING A STALLING TACTIC.  IT KNOWS THAT MOST NEGATIVE REVIEWERS WON'T follow up and respond to its feedback department.  This shows an Egregious CYNICISM on the part of NYP!!!  If NYP WANTS TO BE A DECENT INSTITUTION IT CAN CALL ME!!!  My original review follows: "Terrible and disorganized.  I came on time for my procedure and was left waiting for 75 minutes.  When I finally got to speak to the doctor, he said he could not perform the procedure because his assistants had left 45 minutes earlier. He offered me another appointment, BUT NO APOLOGY.  I left without making another appointment, but in extreme pain.  AVOID THIS PAIN PRACTICE LIKE THE PLAGUE!!!"
They will quite literally let you bleed out on the floor

My experience with Doctor Ami P Vaidya, was a positive and great one. Very professional, explaining everything that needed to be done. Her staff would call and keep me updated on every step that needed to be taken care of. If I had  any questions they made sure I had answers to my questions.  She is also straight forward with what needed to be done.  Thank you Doc Vaidya!!😊

But I'm infuriated and I already reached out to a lawyer. That's how bad it is

This hospital and it's staff is extremely overrated especially the Surgery Department.

I sat in a patient room for over 2 hours. I went to the front desk to ask what is going on and was told that the doctor was called away for emergency surgery.

Not one nurse or other personnel came to the room to let me know what was going on.

I came from NJ to see Dr. Afaneh. I asked to be reimbursed for my expenses and they refuse to reimburse me.

I urge you not to use this hospital or Dr. Afaneh (Surgeon).

Dr. Virk was recommended to me by my twin sister because he performed cervical spine surgery on her.  I have had a horrendous experience trying to get a new patient appointment.  I would not recommend anyone to go through this experience
Only visit the ER here if you are prepared to wait for many hours to be seen, I left in pain to another hospital

BEWARE!
My mother is currently admitted and is getting absolutely unacceptable care.

If your family or friends are not in the ICU and having delirium and are at risk of falling DO NOT go here. They do not listen to you or properly document incidents that occur. My mother had issues of climbing out of bed during the middle of the night then they refused to put a 1 on 1 with her or allow my father to stay over.

They only changed their attitude once we were RIGHT and she fell out of bed which is extremely dangerous.

In addition to this they forgot to put her medicine patch on TWICE after getting scans. Doctors who examined her were confused where it was it, this is a critical medication that they missed and allowed her not to have for 12+ hours.

We have been working with patient services and nothing is changing. The only part of the hospital that world class is the ICU.

I'll say the manager on the floor has stayed in close contact with us to ensure that after the third scan that her medicine is put back on correctly (which still should be standard care) and one of the day nurses Ahmed did all he was able to do for us.

Only other highlight was the day nurse Jessica on the 8th floor but the night nurses were not equipped support with someone like my mother and put that on my father who stayed over and wasn't even supposed to be there (they made an exception).

Wild to me that I have to continue to escalate to just get standard  care...
Worst experience! Had to wait more than 4 hours to see doctor

Poor staffing, poor empathy, no janitors, dirty rooms. Long time to get help once call bell is on. Would not recommend this place to my enemies! Not what I expected at all. Surgeons are good. Care after surgery is poor, mostly due to lack of staff! Please hire workers!!!!!
They wait time in the ER for an MRI is just out of control. Waiting for 15 hours and counting...

Update: My sister was hit by a car this past Friday and is pretty banged up. Her head hit the ground so hard it cracked her bicycle helmet!  The staff at this place didn't even have the common courtesy do a full body CT scan to check for internal injuries! They just scanned her head and one foot. They were supposed to keep her overnight for observation.  She was discharged and sent home after a few hours in the ER. Today, she discovered that her other foot is infected, the one that wasn't scanned. THIS IS WHY YOU CONDUCT A FULL BODY SCAN FOR COLLISION VICTIMS! You don't tell them that they have no internal injuries if you haven't properly checked for any! Crazy thing is that she requested that the ambulance not take her here.  Please be careful if you need to go here.
Read my prior review below. For further information.

This place is notorious for changing the rules as they go along.  Not to mention shady practices by its staff and the constant flow of misinformation. This is especially important if you are a person of color - and I speak from experience.  Please be vigilant if you are admitted here, and if by the grace of God you are allowed to have a visitor with you, make sure that they stay alert as well. Ask questions! Take the names of anyone who comes into contact with you or a loved one. Pay attention to your surroundings, and document everything!!!!

First time my sister, who’s at a nursing home and cannot speak for herself, was taken by ambulance to this hospital. Being her proxy I think I can be of help to the nurses and doctors to figure out a treatment plan. But they didn’t let me in claiming that they are at full capacity. Patients have told their relatives waiting outside that the emergency room is not at full capacity. They are all complaining and very upset. Some of them have called the patient’s information line and they have not been provided with any updates on their relative condition.  HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE. DO NOT COME HERE, this is very different compared to Columbia Presbyterian at 168th St. I never had a problem over there.

While this is an excellent hospital, the security guards are the front desk are total unprofessionals. It bothers them if someone asks an question. They have 4 computers at the desk and someone spilled coffee on the keyboard. Naturally the computer "froze" and these inept careless people with horrible attitude didn't care that the line was long. They could have advised the growingly long line of what was happening. I had to turn around and let the people at the line know. They are so rude. They don't care about the people they serve. They represent this amazing hospital very poorly and give an awful first impression. THEY NEED CUSTOMER SERVICE TRAINING.
Could not be slower or more confused service

First, care wise, they are either understaffed, nonchalant, uncoordinated, or just not concerned. My significant other was in patient following surgery; and the care on the floor was worse than any I have had or seen. Call buttons are not responded to for 10, 15 minutes. The noise outside the door (which never closed) is so bad that no one could sleep. The staff is all very lovely, but there’s not enough of them to go round. The room was so crammed and uncomfortable and just not nice. The bathroom could have been way cleaner.

Downstairs, it’s worse than the security line at Newark airport. An HOUR to get thru as a visitor. Absolutely ridiculous process. They don’t give you a pass for the number of days your family will be there, or even for multiple days at all. There’s no point to security.

The surgical process was impressive, on time, and professional. The rest was lackluster and didn’t feel good. I personally would avoid this hospital for any in patient stays because of what I experienced.

I was in patient up the street at THE HSS and it was like the Ritz. I absolutely adored them. They treated me with such concern and care. I had a nutritionist assigned to me from the first night. I was given huge menu options. Every nurse was amazing. It was sparkling clean and so quiet. It’s hard for me to believe that NYPH can be under par, but it is.
Hospital is amazing. It’s ridiculous though. The lines to go visit are insane. 1 hour wait sometimes

I was sent here at the age of 16 following a traumatic incident that required me to drop out of school and focus on mental health recovery full time, and the Presbyterian was quite possibly the worst possible outpatient program I could have attended. Seven years later, I can say that the experience traumatized me and left me with even more issues than I had when I arrived. The staff here appears to have an obsession with attempting to diagnose its patients with any and every mental health disorder, and displaying one symptom one time is apparently enough grounds for them to do so - one of the nurses asked me if I sometimes find myself struggling to focus during school, and when I said "eh, sometimes," her response was IMMEDIATELY "we're going to look into an ADHD diagnosis." Really? Having a singular trait of a disorder that isn't even prevalent enough to impact my daily life and functioning is good enough for you to try and diagnose me? They would routinely come up with a new disorder to try and "look into" for me - ADHD, autism, Asperger's syndrome, social communication disorder - not once stopping to consider that I was maybe just a teenage girl struggling to process a severe and very recent trauma. The way they all grasped at straws to answer the question of "what's wrong with her" made me feel as though the trauma and abuse I endured was my own fault as it CLEARLY must have been caused by deficits in my own brain, not the experiences I'd had or the environment I was in. What I needed was coping skills to process my trauma, NOT to have some arbitrary label forced onto me - which is exactly what they did. Please, if you have any sort of mental health ailments, seek services elsewhere. All the NYP will do is ignore your concerns and make you feel as though there's something wrong with you.
The emergency room is a disgrace!

ER staff is horrible, they have no empathy and will purposely ignore you, side eye you when you need help. If you want to wait for hours and get dismissed my staff this is the place. I grew up coming here and it has deteriorated so badly in the last few years.

Rude nurses
Sarcastic staff
Manuela and Mellisa

My 82 year-old mother came in by ambulance on 10/1/2025. There were some ER staff who were helpful. She waited 3 days to be admitted to the acute care unit in the Milstein Building. She has yet to see a doctor. We, the family are receiving conflicting messages. We were told she was medically cleared for discharge and then we were told she was being admitted. I still don't know what they found regarding her condition. We, the family are in the dark, despite attempts to get answers. The nurses are attentive and warm; however they are not doctors so there is only so much they can do. I've been in healthcare and public health for three decades, so I know how hospitals work and it has been my experience that some doctors fancy themselves to have rock star status - forgetting they took the Hippocratic Oath, to do no harm. I am not pleased. My mother does not understand why she hasn't seen a doctor. There are facilities in third world countries that treat patients better.

While my sister in law was admitted, ON HOSPICE at 37 years old( who is also a NURSE).. I was in the room with her alone while my and her family was having the discussions of going forward with wishes and final care. During that time alone with her she became aggitated, confused, attempted to pull out her IV and foley, attempting to get out of bed, at this point I decided to press the call bell as any normal person who needs assistance would especially since I couldn't leave her alone to go find a nurse. The call bell preceded to go off for OVER 30 minutes. At this point I was screaming for help from the room. Finally when I thought it was someone to come help/ assist, I was greeted by a VOLUNTEER who then told me to MOVE THE CHAIR, and I just looked at her like excuse me ? She said move the chair I need to shut off the call bell. I said well I'm calling because WE NEED HELP. She then shut offf the call bell and then TOLD ME not to press the call bell because THEN SHE WOULD HAVE TO COME BACK AND SHUT IT OFF. I couldn't believe what I was hearing during this!!!! I said well we need help clearly that's why I pressed the call bell. She then said " I'll go tell the nurse " and left. Another 15/20 minutes go by, the nurse walks in and says " what are you doing ??" Because at this point me and my mother were addressing the situation ourselves because it was apparent that no one clearly cared enough. I was then asked by the RN, why i didn't " use the call bell" and I explained that I did and I was told " not to press the call bell " and she should go tell the nurse. The nurse then told me he was never made aware that we needed assistance in the room by the "volunteer". It's a shame this is how you treat a 37 year old palliative care patient , I only can imagine how they treat elderly patients and how many " call bells " this " "volunteer " has shut off on patients that needed assistance. Working in the healthcare industry for over 15 years I'm absolutely appalled this is how we treat patients in their time of need these days.

P.S.- The side effects of some of these perscription pills have VARIOUS SIDE EFFECTS and HEALTH complications the doctors and staff DON'T MENTION!!! Two words; internet search...

I then also observed a key figure, by the name of Nurse Gabriella Martins clock in,  deal with the back up of patients from the previous shift and single handedly bring things back up to par - and without complaining! She even supported her team with her technical know how.

I can recall the x-ray transport guys name, but he too was very pleasant as was the x-ray tech...

Overall, it has been my best experience w NYP Hospital thus far - you guys rock!

I cannot express enough how grateful I am to the incredible team at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University Irving Medical Center. After struggling with Hyperhidrosis for years, I finally found relief and a renewed sense of freedom thanks to the thoracic surgery performed by Dr. Gorenstein. The entire experience was seamless and surprisingly painless—from consultation to recovery.

Dr. Gorenstein’s skill and compassion truly changed my life. His expertise gave me the confidence to go through with a procedure that I had put off for far too long, and the outcome has been nothing short of miraculous. I now live with significantly less discomfort and far more confidence—something I never thought would be possible.

I also want to give a special thank you to Sabina Shpati, the Practice Associate, who was incredibly supportive throughout the entire process. She helped guide me every step of the way with care and kindness, making what could have been an overwhelming experience feel manageable and reassuring.

To anyone suffering from Hyperhidrosis—please know that there is help out there. I wholeheartedly recommend the center at Columbia. This surgery has opened a new chapter in my life, and I am beyond thankful to everyone who made it possible.

Thank you again to Dr. Gorenstein, Sabina Shpati, and the entire team. I wish you all the very best and continued success in changing lives like you did mine.

I arrived at the ER with chest pain, shortness of breath, and ongoing symptoms related to a pending lymphoma diagnosis. I was seen by Dr. Osman R. Sayan, who made me feel completely dismissed, mocked, and gaslit. Despite being in clear distress, I was offered no pain relief, told I had a UTI (which I do not), and handed a discharge diagnosis of “anxiety.” I refused the unnecessary antibiotics.

I spent **eight hours in the ER—9:00 PM to 5:00 AM—**only to be told I was “crazy” for even coming in.

To make matters worse, the patient in the bed next to me—a woman scheduled for serious cardiac surgery just days later—had been left without medication or basic care since noon the day before. She had to beg for Tylenol and was still completely unattended when I was discharged. The neglect I witnessed wasn’t just toward me—it was systemic.

This experience has made me lose all trust in the medical system. I’ve now made the decision to refuse any further communication or care from doctors, because it’s clear that my concerns will never be taken seriously.

I will be pursuing legal action and sharing my story publicly. No one deserves to be treated like this.

On February 8, 2024 I had a right ICA Aneurysm repaired by Dr Grace Mandigo.  Over the next 7 months I heard absolutely nothing from Dr Mandigo or anyone on her team.  When I begin to have severe gastrointestinal bleeding along with severe joint pain, swollen legs, huge amount black and blue marks on my all over my body.  Within the 24 this information was communicated to Dr Mandigo who ordered me to immediately come to 161 Fort Washington to measured my Brilenta and Aspirin level.  These levels were subteraputic and I was advised by Dr Mandigo to increase the baby aspirin twice a day which I was already taking.  Over the next the next 2 week blood level were repeated and were still low despite the change in doses of medication which still left me continue subtheraputic levels.  After having done this therapeutic test I heard nothing from Mandigo or her team on the Subsequence months about this abnormal blood result. The next problem ensuede Dr Mandigo and her team have promised to scheduled appointments for follow up for MRI and MRA of my brain. Finally after making approximately 15 phone calls and getting the run around I finally received confirmation that they schedule the tests, however I never at any point received any communication about the results of this test.  I was aware at some point that Brilenta would be discontinued and changed to Plavix however, due to the complete lack of communication from Mandigo and the significant persistent effects from Brilenta i was force to seek outside neurosurgical consultation from an outside surgeon on the best way to discontinued Brilenta and changed to Plavix.  This entire situation caused me extreme pain and suffering.  I strongly suggest that Dr Mandigo be repremended for poor medical care and this repremended should be forwarded to the department of neurosurgery and the Medical Board of Columbia.

If I could get a lawyer to sue this hospital, I would! The way I was treated while having surgeries for cancer was horrific!!! The nurse Busted vein while taking blood , And was annoyed with me that it happened … The doctor just Pulled out the drains after the surgery in the way that was so painful. I nearly fainted.! Stitches opened up after surgery and took the doctor four days to call me back to make a zoom as if she can fix it in a Zoom call. Had to redo surgery, Waited for hours Just to find out that there was nobody in the room by the doctor. Run for their life. Absolutely not recommending.

THEY WILL KILL YOU! I was admitted to NYP hospital for aortic valve replacement. They put me on a PCA pump with dialudid despite warning that i do not do well with dilaudid and should not be given it ( worse, they ordered the PCA pump less than an hour after I was snapping selfies of silly faces and sending them to my coworkers/bosses, so I was in good spirits and not pain to warrant pain needing to be escalated to a PCA pump). Afterwards, I became oversedated while being on a PCA pump (as staff put the button in my hand and pressed it for me) and required multiple doses of Narcan but my mental state was still altered. I also had fluid in my lungs from the respiratory depression but pneumonia couldn't be ruled out so Dr. Groves prescribed Zosyn. However, this is noted in my chart as a severe allergy with the reaction being severe thrombocytopenia. Very rapidly my platelets dropped from 165 to 5. This intentional oversight led to severe thrombocytopenia, necessitating urgent intubation and a head CT scan to rule out bleeding or a stroke. However, Dr. Groves did not tell my sisters that he gave me the zosyn and tried covering up the reason for the CT scan and sedation. the CT showed that I had a stroke but no one told my family about this or started me on medication to prevent another one. I only found out a year after when I consulted a neurologist and she then started me on cholesterol medicine that is necessary as per guidelines. when I woke up from sedation  while I was in the hospital, and was told that I was given the medication, I was furious and felt so violated as I know it was noted in my chart previously. The complication significantly prolonged my hospital stay (including being restrained and sedated for multiple days that I won't ever get back) and led to a series of traumatic experiences. I developed a wound infection that required more surgery.
I started therapy shortly after I was discharged and continue to suffer from PTSD, major depressive disorder  and anxiety, all stemming from this experience. I also left my job because it was triggering and too hard for me (I worked as an administrator in a medical/surgical practice). I also use a walking stick because I continue to deal with dizziness and balance issues, new after this hospitalization.

Yes, I am alive but my life as I knew it before is gone. NYP you really messed up and I will tell you this, you have violated me and made me feel so powerless, but I will do everything in my power, no matter how little, to make sure everyone knows what you did and that you will not get away with this.

Also, stop harassing me over my balance. I'm not paying anything to you. You offered me $50K to settle when you billed my insurance $1.3 MILLION in the month I was there. So how does that make sense?  and you continue to harass me over a smaller balance? Please stop. You're only making things worse.

This is pertaining to emergency room section D- nurse kassandra Mochi who contacted security to have me removed for simply asking her who my husbands nurse is and politely requesting that she NOT YELL at my husband when he was simply asking for help since there is no call bell in the room he was assigned to. a nurse is the only one allowed to turn off the IV machines therefore a nurse must be reachable! Sept 1st 2018, I had a brain aneurysm rupture and was med flighted from Laconia NH. I had collapsed twice walking out of my bathroom so my 12 year old daughter called 911. Thank God she was still awake at 1:30 am or I wouldn't be here. Laconia EMTS treated me terribly and thought I overdosed. The two men kept telling me multiple times that I need to "stand up" as I was crying on my kitchen floor curled up in a ball holding my head. Laconia EMTs kept asking me how much heroin I took and told me we weren't leaving till I told them how much. My son said "My mom doesn't do drugs". The EMTs snickered and said "yeah ok". I knew I was going to die in front of my children so I used every single ounce of strength that I had to get on the gourney. Yes, two men that easily had well over 50 pounds on me if not more, wouldn't place me on the gurney to get moving.
My whole stay at Mass General (all 17 days) was great. I was brought ice cream at 1 am when I couldn't sleep. Since I was bedridden, one nurse "Grace" even washed my hair while I was laying in the bed.
She even tried to get the knots out of my hair. She was incredible and such a sweet, caring girl.
I was moved up from the ICU to the floor above after 15 days, I was told I'd have more freedom without being hooked up to all the machines. I thought that meant I could go get a soda. I was stopped at the elevators and told I couldn't go off the floor. The woman at the desk who stopped me went out of her way and brought a soda to my room. This hospital and its staff are incredible. They saved my life as most people die before reaching the hospital. I'm incredibly grateful to be alive and the hospital staff made my ENTIRE stay more comfortable. I can't thank you all enough for all you have done for me.

MGH is one of the biggest hospitals in Boston, but it you have minor acute needs or if the nurse staff team deems your illness acute, then they will send you to the “Fast Track” side, completely separate from the ER department and the wait for the Fast Track on most days is about 15-20 mins to be seen by a clinician regardless of your condition.

Also, I talked to a group of dental students about something called the “Molar Study Program” and these people/this dental office has been calling me nonstop with phone calls after I requested them to stop for the past 6 months. So, be a little cautious about what studies you sign up for.

Otherwise, known as one of the best research hospitals in the region. I think they also might be Harvard Medical School doctors affiliated as well.

racial discrimination, Racial biased, Unethical behaviors. This hospital has no patience and does not welcome individuals with autism spectrum disorder. The phone systems that support incoming calls to MGH are a complete travesty.  People's lives are in the balance of this system and it is nearly impossible to obtain accurate information (even recordings have inaccurate fax numbers).  I retrieved 4 different fax numbers for MGH Gastroenterology and 3 of them were inaccurate.  I had to contact Patient Advocacy to get support -- this took 3 phone calls, where with each, I was transferred at least 3 times.  How can anyone, especially someone who works in the business of people's health, think this is efficient or of high care?  I understand this is the responsibility of the Information Technology team at MGH -- I wonder if they realize the gravity of such poor design.  I also wonder if they understand the importance of training the MGH employees who have to deal with this system.  If I was a senior citizen or someone of lesser tenacity, I would never have completed my task with MGH (to get care) because of this confusing, inadequate, error-prone calling system.  Do better, MGH Information Technology. It's a shame that this phone system is the front face of all the good, talented, hardworking people who work for MGH.

May 30, 2025:  As an update, my general practitioner's office (not with the MGH system) followed all the correct procedures, following my instructions provided by MGH's website, automated messages, and even a person, and it was still inaccurate.  When they finally faxed the correct number, the intake people couldn't find the fax!  So, my GP's office sent it again with special attention to a human I finally found willing to watch for the fax. I repeat again without being hyperbolic, this system is a travesty and a risk to people's lives. How can the MGH administration stand by this system?  Do you find it reliable?  Are you proud of it?  If not, are you doing anything about it?

I also tried to use patient advocacy and called them a number of times and they did *not* at all help me achieve an outcome.  In fact, I called several times and I did not receive a reply.

I shared this story with a friend whose wife is a *doctor* at the Children's Hospital and she, too, couldn't get in touch with a specialist!  So, my friend actually showed up in person at MGH to finally close the loop.  This is really sickening for MGH to let this happen.

I recently gave birth at MGH, and I can’t express enough how deeply grateful I am to the incredible team at the Labor and Delivery department. From the very beginning, every single staff member—nurses, doctors, anesthesiologists—was so kind, supportive, and genuinely caring.

Special thanks to nurses Colby, Daniella, and the sweet Italian nurse (whose name I unfortunately forgot), as well as Dr. Packard and the amazing anesthesiology team. Each person made me feel safe, respected, and cared for during one of the most important experiences of my life.

I’m so happy and thankful that I gave birth to my daughter at this exact hospital—Alhamdulillah.

it seems as if you’re not a white, rich, straight,  cisgender person they treat you badly here… i don’t even know why i’m thinking this but it just gives off that vibe. like white snobby nurses

I had the privilege of being seen by Dr. Alister Martin in the ER, and I cannot express how grateful I am for his care. From the moment I arrived, I felt heard and understood. He took the time to listen to my concerns and was incredibly patient throughout the entire process.

Dr. Alister Martin answered all of my questions with clarity and compassion, which made me feel more at ease despite being in a vulnerable state. He provided me with a clear plan and, after feeling completely exhausted, I left the hospital with a sense of relief and hope.

The impact of his care was immediate—after days of not being able to eat or sleep, I was able to enjoy a meal as soon as I got home. I truly feel so much better and cannot thank him enough for making such a difference during a difficult time.

If I could provide 0 stars to this institution I would.

I went to this institution after having an operation and having a number of very bad issues with moving implants. I went asking for help and was violated in the worst way.

If it wasn't for the Doctors, nurses, N.P's, P.A's, therapists, N.A's, techs. Everyone that was responsible for my husband's care. We are going back on Friday for my husband to have lung surgery! We could of had the surgery closer to home. But we trust M.G.H.!

If I could leave 0 stars I would. This hospital failed my mother, who posed a risk to herself. The hospital was supposed to call us if she left, we spoke to several nurses who assured us that if she left they would call us. We couldn’t be more grateful for the exceptional care my dad, Antonio Silva, received from Dr. Shankar Ganesh during his spinal surgery. From the very beginning, Dr. Ganesh was real and honest while maintaining a sense of optimism that made my dad feel safe and confident. Throughout the entire process, it was clear that my dad was in the best hands possible, and Dr. Ganesh’s calm and caring demeanor gave us all peace of mind.

The surgery and recovery exceeded our expectations. My dad was up and walking the very next day without any pain, which was truly surprising to him. His recovery has continued to be smooth, and two months later, he just keeps getting better and stronger. The day after the surgery, Dr. Ganesh was there to personally check on him, take care of the stitches, and ensure everything was on track.

Dr. Ganesh’s professionalism, skill, and genuine care have been a blessing. My dad was so touched by how Dr. Ganesh looked at him—with a sense of responsibility and empathy, like it was his own result. We’ve been incredibly lucky to have a doctor with such ‘angel hands,’ who truly cares for his patients’ well-being. Thank you, Dr. Ganesh, for everything. We are forever grateful!

Worst hospital on earth. Got billed $920 for a primary care visit and I have insurance. I'd give zero stars if I could.

UCLA is a scam, all they want is MONEY. I have a lipoma that has been giving me ZERO issues and the only thing I wanted was to make sure it wasn't cancer. Told my GP about it, said it was most likely a lipoma and sent me to a General Surgeon here to apparently verify. I did not call to make the appointment, this office called me multiple times to make the appointment which should have set off red flags right there. I was charged a $300 facility fee for this General Surgeon to take less than 2 minutes to measure the lipoma, confirm it was a lipoma and tell me I needed surgery for it and had me schedule the surgery. I literally got stuck with an over $200 bill just to schedule a surgery I DID NOT NEED. I was given zero options besides surgery, the ONLY reason I was being checked out for this was ignored, there was no mention of doing a biopsy and I was made to believe that the removal was necessary. Medical records for the appointment were not fully accurate, lipoma was stated to be considerably newer than it was. When sent the invoice for the surgery they charged the HIGHEST threshold amount for the surgery which conveniently capped out my deductible and they wanted me to prepay $3k my insurance didn't cover before the day of surgery. Even chatgpt examined the invoice and said it was more on the high end for the 45 minute procedure (13k).

My experience at UCLA Ronald Reagan Medical Center highlights everything broken about the U.S. healthcare system. I was charged $4,270 just for walking in the door, and a total of $9,190 for a few simple stitches on my eyelid. Beyond the shocking bill, I spent over 6 hours waiting in a dirty tent, only to be moved inside where I waited another 2–3 hours before finally seeing a doctor. This isn’t just about UCLA it’s about how hospitals in America can bill patients outrageous amounts while making them wait for hours in poor conditions. Patients deserve safe, clean care at a fair price, not financial exploitation on top of an already stressful medical situation. I don't recommend this hospital to anyone in need of any type of medical help event if you have a heath insurance!
Unprofessional towards both patients and family members. I got nothing else to say.

UCLA Ronald Regan ER is the WORST.
1. No empathy, respect, or compassion from nursing staff- extremely rude and dismissive. I have never had to request a new nurse, however I asked for my nurses to be switched because I felt so uncomfortable.

2. The doctor was extremely rude snd impatient when I asked for the note to return to work to be adjusted to reflect necessary documentation my federal government employment requires, and even said she couldn’t help me because it was nearing the end of her shift and she had a lot still left to do.

3. I was in immense pain from a traumatic head injury and was discharged, very quickly (could barely walk), without any prescription for medication.

4. Recently received an excessive bill after telling them I have medi-cal so that’ll be another headache I have to deal with.

Absolutely will not recommend or return.

My husband has been in an out of this hospital for months, he was declined for a liver transplant almost 2 months ago, ever since then he has done everything in his power to show he is committed to sobriety but despite all his efforts they're still denying him a second chance. My husband is in a very bad shape and yet they still denying him from the transplant list and keep saying he needs to continue doing rehab when they can clearly see that time is not on our hands. They Drs I have talked to are not very compassionate about it, they just shrugg it off like they don't care. This is my loved one's life. My husband is trying very hard to prove he is committed to sobriety but there's only so much he can do when he is so sick, nobody is perfect in this life, please give him a second chance!. My child needs her father and I need my husband alive. Please I implore you review his case one more time!

Update in Aug: UCLA accepted my payment online (and it shows "the provider has accepted the payment") but keeps sending me bill and a mail notice of "we will take further action if we cannot receive the bill." Are you trying to trap me?

The issue should have been solved in July, what's the reason that your system problem finally become the patient's bill problem. I am really tired of it...

---
I had already paid for my bill, but in July, UCLA called me again, claiming I never paid.

I contacted the insurance company. They confirmed they did pay the claim at the end of June, but said the hospital never accepted the payment, so the funds were not processed.

I tried to help by asking if I could provide a transaction ID to UCLA for confirmation.
The UCLA payment team's answer: "No, we can't use that. You need to talk to your insurance company."

I’m now caught in a ridiculous loop where both sides expect me to be the coordinator, while refusing to communicate with each other.

While I was literally drafting this post, I told the insurance company that I am disappointed and mad. That got someone to escalate my case to their advocate team. And here’s the crazy part: The advocate called the hospital directly. The UCLA payment team suddenly said yes to everything. Everything could be verified, cleared, and approved. Now, I’ve been told the payment will be processed on the hospital's side within a week.
Jinky and Jose took great care of me and they are amazing and made me feel happy… Wonderful people!
Always a good experience

Absolutely do not recommend UCLA Ronald Reagan Medical Center.

My original review is too many words. To read it I have attached it as pictures labelled pages 1-5.

I am a mother of two, and my experience at this hospital was traumatic beyond words. I’ve waited almost a year to share this because it’s still painful, but other families deserve to know what happened.

On July 24, 2024, my toddler had a febrile seizure for the first time. We were taken to UCLA ER. She tested positive for COVID, and her personal neurologist (from CHLA) advised me via phone that she was safe to go home for monitoring as a provoke febrile seizure was the cause. Despite that, UCLA insisted on admitting her—and what followed was a complete nightmare.

🔻 I was threatened with CPS for trying to care for both children:
I was 3 months postpartum with a COVID-positive, exclusively breastfed infant at home. I explained that I needed to breastfeed him, and he had a fever too. They refused to let me bring him in to the hospital and said that if I left to care for him and discharged my daughter, they would report me to Child Protective Services for medical neglect. I had no choice—I felt like a hostage.

🔻 No accommodations for breastfeeding or basic nutrition:
I was given a breast pump, but my baby does not take bottles, and I had no way to get the milk to him. Once checked into the room, they gave me crackers and sugary cereal—no real food for my daughter or I —even though I hadn’t eaten in hours. I was not allowed to leave to get food, nor could staff bring anything from the lobby. My daughter has a gluten allergy and they had nothing for her either.

🔻 Prescribed dangerous medication:
UCLA discharged my daughter with Diazepam and Keppra for epilepsy—despite no epilepsy diagnosis. Weeks later, in Australia, I used the Diazepam during another febrile seizure, and it caused respiratory distress. Emergency responders and doctors were shocked at the dosage—way too high for a toddler. My U.S. pediatrician agreed. I had to give my daughter rescue breaths for 15 minutes until help arrived. Horrifying.

🔻 Delayed discharge and conflicting communication:
We were told multiple times we were being discharged. But we weren’t—staff seemed to be stalling for a full 24-hour observation period without being upfront. A nurse even admitted doctors were "lollygagging.” When I finally confronted the doctor in front of his students, we were discharged 30 minutes later. They knew this whole time I had a covid positive 3 month old at home who was not allowed in the hospital who had also not had my milk for almost a 24hour period.

🔻 Financial stress mishandled:
While in emotional crisis, I was approached about insurance. Turns out my daughter’s name was misspelled, which caused the issue. After correcting it, I asked about financial assistance—none was available, and our plan had a 30% co-insurance. Just what every overwhelmed parent needs in a moment of crisis.

🔻 Ignored by Patient Experience team:
I contacted the patient care department afterward. They promised to look into the counselor who threatened CPS and the medication issue. I sent emails and our $8,940 bill as requested—and was completely ghosted. No response. No accountability. I have my email thread as proof.

👎 This hospital lacks empathy, trauma-informed care, and safe medical judgment.
* They endangered my infant and toddler.
* They created emotional trauma I am still processing.
* They ignored my neurologist’s medical advice.
* They threatened a loving, competent mother with CPS.
* They prescribed a medication that almost killed my child.

I flew to Australia shortly after to recover from this ordeal with family support. Please, if you're a parent—think twice before putting your family in UCLA’s hands.

One of my family members was admitted here and the care has been exceptionally great! The medical team has been amazing  and huge shoutout to the CVICU nurses who treated our family so well during our time here. This hospital and medical center completely changed my life when NO other Doctor was willing or able to help! I am surprised that UCLA medical doesn’t have 4-5 star rating, but people usually write reviews to complain.  I am making sure to share my personal 5 star experience.  I have been to SO many doctors, surgeons, and hospitals for years to try to fix my body.  My condition limited my life in a way that caused me to spend over 6 hours a day in the bathroom.  I had no life.  My anatomy was completely disfigured and I could not perform basic human functions.  I was referred to UCLA because other doctors and surgeons had tried everything with no success.  I had given up hope and I was desperate.  I was finally given a referral to UCLA.  I met with Dr. Michelle Torosis (who is a Urogynecologist and excellent surgeon).  She made sure that I was taken care of from a surgical AND functional standpoint.  She was also very thorough in order to make sure I had the best possible outcome.  The surgeons, specialists, and nurses were SO KIND and understanding.   I have never been to a hospital where every staff member is so understanding, not judgmental, patient, and knowledgeable.  I am an RN, so I am very picky about the standard of care, but I was blown away!  During my surgery and hospital stay, the pain team specialists worked VERY closely with me because I am a chronic pain patient.  They went over and above to help me and they used up to date evidence-based  practice to help me.  All of the different specialties worked closely together to manage my care, so there were no communication issues.  The case managers are efficient, thorough, and very helpful.  They literally set everything up for my outpatient needs, and I didn’t have to worry about anything.  Also, this hospital is not like a regular community hospital or clinic.  You should expect the best level of care.  Let’s just say that I am recovering now and the results of my surgery are above and beyond what I expected.  Dr. Torosis, Dr. Fain, and Dr. Rossette are incredible surgeons and they are so kind.  Most surgeons have terrible bedside manner.  However, this was never an issue here!  As someone who is an RN and has been a patient in and out of other hospitals, I can confidently say that I wouldn’t want to go anywhere else.  Also, the nurses in PACU, PTU, and my floor nurses (Yo and Clara), deserve recognition.  The pain management team is top notch, as well.  Hopefully they all receive the recognition they deserve! THANK YOU, UCLA!

During my PRP appointment at Cedars-Sinai orthopedic office at 8635 West 3rd Street
Suit 990, Los Angeles CA 90047, the procedure for collecting blood involved the use of multiple types of collection tubes, handled in a way that left me quite confused and uneasy:
•	Initially, a yellow‑capped tube (Yellow Bio Tube) was used; however, the blood clotted in that tube.
•	Lab nurse Jackson (who was called in to assist due to my thin veins) then requested a red‑capped tube (Red Bio Tube), but the blood clotted again.
•	Nurse A (tall, long dark hair, Latina) then poured the blood from the red‑capped tube into the original yellow‑capped tube — without wearing gloves and facial mask and talking at the same time (a clear violating standard infection control protocols).
•	When the blood clotted again, Jackson asked for another red‑capped tube. At that point, Nurse A claimed there were no more red‑capped tubes available and brought over another yellow‑capped tube instead.

I noticed the second yellow‑capped tube appeared wet inside and asked why. Nurse A explained that she had just poured liquid out of it. As a result, suction was lost and blood could not be drawn. She then handed Jackson a syringe, but even that failed to produce flow.

At that point, Nurse B (short, appears pregnant) entered and stated that PRP requires blood to be drawn into a red‑capped tube, because it does not contain additives. When I asked why the procedure had started with a yellow‑capped tube and why blood had been poured from a red into a yellow tube, both nurses appeared rattled. Nurse B then contradicted herself, saying, “Yellow is fine. Yellow is the right one. I need those additives for PRP.” This sudden change in explanation made me even more suspicious and concerned.

Meanwhile, Nurse A claimed there were no more yellow tubes, Nurse B went outside the room and, within a minute, “magically” produced another yellow‑capped tube.

Finally, they switched arms and drew blood into that third yellow‑capped tube — the fourth tube used overall.

This sequence of events has left me with several pressing questions:
1.	Was my treatment still effective, given these inconsistencies?
2.	Was my blood contaminated, since it was transferred between tubes by hand — without gloves — and that plasma was later injected into my left wrist?
3.	What are the established patient safety protocols in the facility for PRP procedures?
4.	What qualifications and training are required for Registered Nurses at the facility? The apparent lack of consistency and professional handling has left me deeply concerned.
5.	Are those nurses trained to cover for one another when mistakes occur, rather than correcting errors to ensure proper patient care?

From what I’ve read, the standard of care for PRP blood collection involves using red‑capped tubes precisely because they do not contain additives that may interfere with plasma separation.

The inconsistencies in both practice and explanation — and witnessing blood being transferred between tubes bare-handed — raise serious doubts about the quality, safety, and integrity of the care I received. I left the appointment feeling uneasy and distrustful about the discipline, competency, professionalism, and trustworthiness of the clinic’s procedures.

I’m a bit late in writing this review, but I had an appointment with Dr. Natasha Malkani at Cedars-Sinai last year, and unfortunately, it was one of the worst medical experiences I’ve ever had.

I sought out an endocrinologist to help manage a condition I had already been diagnosed with. I came to the appointment prepared—hydrated and fasting in case lab work was needed—and ready to discuss treatment options. Instead, Dr. Malkani was dismissive, rude, and uninterested in anything I had to say. After asking just a few questions, she told me she didn’t believe I had the condition I had previously been diagnosed with—without offering any alternative explanation. When I asked what she did think it might be, she simply shrugged. I asked if there were any labs we could run to get clarity, and she told me to come back in three months, offering no justification for the delay.

The entire appointment lasted less than ten minutes, yet I was billed not only for a full visit, but also for extended time. It was a deeply frustrating and disheartening experience, and I would not recommend Dr. Malkani—or Cedars-Sinai—to anyone based on this encounter.

For contrast, I recently saw an endocrinologist at UCLA who was thorough, compassionate, and genuinely interested in helping. They confirmed my original diagnosis and are now working with me to find an appropriate treatment plan. The difference in care was night and day.

She had a nurse give me tylenol and a shot for pain. In which, she never mentions that I would take either. She also mentioned that I should continue to go to work and move around so my muscles wouldn’t tighten. However, she’d prescribe me muscle relaxers and pain meds. When the other nurse came with my paper work to be discharged. I believe her name to be Emily Grayson Pott she told me that Tanya Lyn didn’t prescribe me anything. So I went home still in pain for the next two days. It made me question everything because why lie to me when i’m in severe pain. I believe since I was an African American woman she didn’t want to give me proper care or attention as she did other patients that weren’t of my same race. I did go to another ER for a second opinion because the pain is very uncomfortable to where I can’t sit down properly or even bend down. The second ER told me I had a cyst in my tailbone. Which is very odd to me due to what Tanya Lyn Tivorsak mentioned to me that it was my spine. Had I not gone to a second ER then I would’ve probably never gotten the proper treatment I needed. Had she took her time to care for me. I’m truly saddened that she doesn’t care enough for people and also too led me to be in pain with no prescription that she said specifically that she would prescribe me.
Best hospital in the world considering The Billie Eilish was born in this hopsital.

This review is specifically for Nurse Gary in ER. I was waiting in observation to see a physician in a bed in the hallway. Gary told me that I would be waiting to see the physician. 2 hours later, Gary not once checked on me. Mind you, I was there for a kidney infection, and had to ask 3 different people (who kept telling me that they’d get my nurse) to finally get a water from some random woman working at one of the desks, which is important for the antibiotic I was on. And my pain was getting worse.

Thinking it was weird no one checked on me or gave me any updates, I asked again to see Nurse Gary. While I was waiting, I saw him chatting and joking with coworkers. I love that for him, liking your coworkers is important, but please check on your patients even if only to say “how ya doing? How’s your pain? Still waiting on the physician btw.” Gary finally strolls over and asks what’s up. I asked him what was going on because I hadn’t heard any sort of communication after 2 hours of laying in the hospital bed. I make it a point to be polite and pleasant with any sort of care provider because I’ve seen what kind of people they have to deal with sometimes, but he copped a condescending attitude reiterating that we were still waiting on the physician and cutting me off while I was trying to ask questions.

Meanwhile a very ill man in the bed in front of me started puking over and over again. I told Gary I was experiencing more pain but couldn’t handle the man vomiting anymore in the hallway and asked if I could leave because I was about to be sick myself. He said “yep,” not once offered to check on approximately how much longer the physician would be or to check on seeing if he could move my bed to a different hallway.

So I left without any treatment, still scared as I write this review that my kidney infection might take a turn for the worse. I have friends and family who work in ICU and ER, so I understand how difficult a job it is. But the lack of care, attention, bedside manner and empathy from Gary (on top of the man vomiting every 3 minutes) just sent me over the edge. Who knows how much longer I would be waiting for him to check on me while some guy is violently vomiting a few feet from me, and then be made to feel uncomfortable by the nurse’s attitude. It’s a joke that I got that automated text from them in the photo about caring about making me comfortable.

So if I get sepsis, that’s on you Gary. What a waste of a $150 copay, and 6+ hours of my life waiting for someone to give a hoot about my health (literally the profession you chose and get paid to do).

I had the worst experience at this hospital. I have permanent scarring in my lung from being Intubated for too long.. I was over sedated... My ivs hurt and burned they blew out so many viens that the fluid was just seeping into my tissue... My arms were so swollen and bruised by the time I left. My rib was broken during sugery and no one told me. They would make me wait forever for help with the bathroom and I was on diurectics... I could hear everything in the rooms next to me, my room was right off the office so lights always on talking, banging around... The food was sythectic and disgusting.. My friend who is a doctor was atunned, said I always thought this would be the hospital is go to if I was sick, I'm seriously going to rethink it. Of course there were some great staff, but some truly horrible ones with zero compassion. Would be my last resort!

I came to this hospital (Cedar Sinai) located in Los Angeles, CA and I needed a liver biopsy, kidney nerve block and a possible pacemaker. They performed tests and never gave me a report of findings. I have high allergies and can only have morphine by IV and I have CHF. He kept discharging me before taking a test and immediately after tests and would not meet with me regarding results. He took me off of the morphine that works for me and replaced it with a liquid and I am having severe allergic reactions (burning all over my body,  severe pains in my abdomen, etc.). Someone said they may have stolen my morphine. The doctors have tried to discharge me 3 times and withdrew their discharge each time I appealed and said they made a mistake. I am now still in the hospital burning all over my body and doctors are ignoring me. I am Afro/Indian and by the doctors on his team's conduct, I am beginning to believe that they may have stolen my morphine and are causing racial profiling on top of that. I am suing. This doctor is very racist.

I have been waking up the past couple of days feeling like a wet mop and as if a truck has run over me, with constant bed sweating. I am also severely constipated since they substituted my Morphine with this cheap liquid under my tongue. I am constantly dizzy and it hurts for me to walk, and I didn't have these symptoms before.  I told them because I was born with severe allergies that I can't have any substitutes for my pain medicine and that the doctors who have treated me over the past 10 years have compiled a list in the medical systems as to what medications and types of medications that I cannot have that will cause me to have severe allergic reactions and it was ignored. I am still lying here very sick and again today, no doctor has checked on me to even ask what will make me better. I am still having severe allergic reactions and am very dizzy and in pain going on 3 days now and I'm still laying here with no contact from the doctor nor his team This is the second time I experienced this sort of cruel treatment in one year. The first time a real honest doctor made the registered nurses put my Morphine back in my medical treatment and rebuked them for playing the "steal the patient's Morphine game" because that's all I could have.

It deeply pains me to write this review, especially considering how much I once trusted and admired Cedars-Sinai. In the past, I truly believed they had the best doctors, nurses, and care teams. When my father was tragically murdered, I felt they fought relentlessly to save him, and when I gave birth to my beautiful daughter, I was convinced I had the most capable and compassionate team by my side.

But ten years later, after moving back to Los Angeles from Orange County, the difference is staggering. It's hard to ignore how far this institution has fallen, and frankly, it’s terrifying to think that AI might soon be doing a better job than the current staff. The X-ray techs didn't secure me properly with the necessary protection, the nurses were downright lazy and dismissive, and the doctor I saw acted as if my health was more of a burden than a responsibility.

What was even more shocking was the state of the hospital itself. The bathrooms were filthy, and there was zero privacy in what they refer to as “the pit” — an area that’s uncomfortably shared with registration. It felt like I had entered a third-world country where basic healthcare was an afterthought — and yet, I’ve seen American doctors volunteering in other countries, offering better care with more compassion than what I experienced here.

This wasn’t just about a hospital being overwhelmed with patients. This was about a complete lack of professionalism, organization, sanitation, and, above all, compassion. The decline in quality care is not just noticeable — it's staggering. Many of us who were there that day felt the same way: the cold indifference from the staff, the total disregard for patient dignity, and the overall lack of accountability.

I once trusted Cedars-Sinai with my family’s health, but now I dread the thought of returning. It’s heartbreaking to witness such a dramatic decline in a place that once felt like the pinnacle of healthcare. Until major changes are made — and a true commitment to patient care is restored — I can no longer recommend this facility to anyone.

P.S. If there's anything I can do to help bring back the original culture of Cedars-Sinai, please don't hesitate to let me know. It's absolutely critical for humanity to stay connected, to feel, to care, and to demonstrate our ability to deliver with compassion and purpose. Regrettably, it seems as though your team is falling short, and it's time to reassess how we can reestablish a truly supportive and impactful culture.

If we the patients are there it's because we feel as though we need you, and we're trusting you with our health and our lives. Please do better because I know you can.

Blessings🙏🏽

Never ever coming to this facility ever again. The doctor treating me has zero compassion ignored my concerned and gave me attitude the whole time. It's not hard IV pepcid, fluids, reglan, pain medicine. Ive got complex medical issues and have 5 upcoming surgeries.  I hope she remembers me by last name Ramirez and the good Lord will take care of her for making a child of god suffer so much injustice in this world. I've  had a code blue 3 times so I know there's a reason for me being. I will always advocate for myself and others enough is enough the health care system is under a lot of stress and broken.

I will never ever go to cedars….. anywhere but cedars. 4 hour wait times just to get into the ER RIDICULOUS I could be dead in 4 hours….. this has happened multiple times to me at cedars not to mention the nurses and drs are rude and mean I was not happy with my care at any of my visits to cedars

My husband went to a consult today with the cardiologist there at Cedar-Siani. We spent a total of 3 hours waiting for an answer of, we can't help treat you unless you take medications. Long story short, my husband has metastatic high blood pressure that has been uncontrolled now for 17 years. He has been given every medication that is on the market, and he is medicine resistant and allergic to the ingredients. Cedar-Siani was the last place that we went to to get answers. Basically, they had no answers. We spoke with a nice young doctor that was courteous. Then she brought in an attending Doctor Who was very rude and did not have good bedside manner. She let us know that she was very busy and needed to leave. She spoke to us for a total of maybe five or 10 minutes and had to hurry out the door. It was not a very good experience. 😕

The doctors are great. The nursing staff is terrible. The AOD. Is useless. They think they are above all. My children’s dad past and I had my husband with dementia/Alzheimers in the hospital. Now I have been here for over a month 24/7 doing a lot of duties that the nurses should be doing I do. Otherwise you could be waiting at least 20 minutes to 30. This is my beff….I asked them to get my husband a volunteer or a CP to sit in and watch him for six hours so that I could attend my children’s dad’s celebration of life. I was told we don’t do that so that we will just tie him down so he doesn’t remove his IVs or peg tube. I then said you wont let me have all four sides up on the bed because it’s restraining him but you will tie him down if I’m not here.  Doesn’t make sense. They brag about these volunteers and CP and say they don’t have the man power but today I sit here and watch the CP sit at the computer desk for 80 percent of her shift. Really ! Watching on her cell phone,  And they don’t have the Coverage. Mind you I do 90% of the work during the day I changed my husband‘s diapers. I change his linens. I give him his bath. I change his bandage. All they do is come in and help me if I need them to help me turn them on his  side  all they do, and I have been doing this for  68 days 24/7.  I asked to be relieved for six hours. They all go home after 12 and only work three days in a row. I’ve been working 68 and I can’t even get relief for six hours one day really  UCLA is  Is looking better.  I really don’t need to be here after all because you don’t get to see your regular doctors here anyway the ones here that work at the hospital have leverage over them And your doctors have to be invited here by the doctor that had admitted you out of the ER. You don’t have an invite you can’t stop in and see your patience’s. I tried to tell them that I was here in January and that I had a sitter for one day the kindness of my doctors. They said they thought I needed a break and got me a sitter for a day and told me to go out and have some lunch and a couple hours to myself Because I had been in a similar situation again long days staying at the hospital for days in. They had a gal sit part of the day and a camera inside the room watching over my husband. The AOD says to me that that’s not true. We don’t do that. I said don’t call me a liar. I said I know what went on last January, you don’t I’ve been around this place a lot longer than you have, I’m here about every other month. Oh and he’s had the Audacity to tell me that if I wanted a sitter I could pay for one privately I said why in the hell do I wanna do that when I pay you all damn day long and I do you guys’s job?So unfortunately, I am not able to attend my children’s dad’s celebration of life, but it will be my last day at Cedar Sinai. I found out that three out of my four doctors are affiliated with UCLA..

Thank you for helping me with my pain!! Feeling so much better 😊

One of the worst experiences here with Labor&Delivery, Postpartum, Anesthesia, and Birth Certificate registration departments. Staff are rude, negligent and do not respect your wishes. You will feel pressured to do a lot of things that are medically unnecessary and there is a lot of fear mongering tactics they use.

They are clueless and start stupidly asking you to make decisions that your doctor isn’t requiring. The nurses will pressure you to formula feed if your breast milk doesn’t come in soon after delivery.

The baby scales are not accurately calibrated. In turn they will send you off on a mentally challenging journey of telling you your baby is losing too much weight when it’s an inflated number to begin with because of all the IV fluids they’ve pumped you with while delivering. If you have a nurse named Leigh, ask the charge nurse to switch you. She is deceptive and will act like she’s there for you but she’s really just another crappy nurse who will pressure you to do things using the tried and true cedars method of fear monger.

The world needs to know this is NOT a baby friendly hospital because they take massive funding from formula giant Emfamil. They will force feed your child formula if need be. They are extremely pushy and a terrible hospital. Do NOT trust ever giving birth here.

Also, Providence St. John’s in Santa Monica is a better hospital especially with Anesthesia options! Cedars does not provide laughing gas which is something that would have been helpful given my circumstances. Cedars doesn’t make money off of it so they don’t offer it.

I have several OB/labor and delivery Anesthesia consults and I was told given my circumstances with my back they wouldn’t place a spinal block in a specific area and of course the attending anesthesiologist didn’t even try to look at all my back scans and Still placed it in the wrong spot. Causing me excruciating pain for 45 minutes while trying to complete the spinal block (which is 6 needles). My screams were heard all the way to the front of the Labor and Delivery unit from what the nurses told me while I was in the recovery room waiting for my postpartum room.

Lab Tech that came to my room to draw blood was extremely rude when I told her the test they’re trying to get blood from me for was already done. She got very angry and started yelling at me saying she was just doing her job when she didn’t know my chart and didn’t know I had that bloodwork done the day before!!

The people delivering food can be extremely rude when they come back to pick up your trays because you’re asking for more time! I wish I could make this part up. I was breastfeeding and I asked for more time because I wanted privacy and the woman picking up the tray Still shoved her head into my room behind the curtain and rolled her eyes when I said I need more time to eat! And she blurted out “FINE”…

Once it was time for birth certificate registration, my husband and I filled out the forms and added our child’s Suffix. The person didn’t do their job and didn’t add the suffix. And we didn’t see it on the verification letter. Later we found out the suffix needed to be added with an amended birth certificate. These people mishandled our paperwork so much. I had to push on the phone while postpartum to get a manager on the phone. Waited over an hour to get some sort of solution! Triple check everything they give you including all the fine print!!

AVOID giving birth here as much as possible! I went out of pocket to give birth here and none of it was ever worth a dime for the mental and physical abuse I endured and the trauma/PTSD I now have from giving birth here.
One star because eazy-e died here

It's 2 in the morning, we've been in the ER for 7 hours. They are saying it could now be 10 and when we checked in it was 5. I drove from San Diego to help my dear friend who at only 46 with stage 4 lung cancer. She is coughing and throwing up blood repeatedly for hours and has a severe headache and no one seems to care in the slightest. I have never seen nurses and doctors have less compassion in all my life. Please don't come to this hospital if you have an emergency. This place is the worst ER I have ever experienced in my life.

I hope to never have to visit Cedars-Sinai Medical Center again for medical reasons, but I can’t thank the team here enough for the exceptional care I received. From the moment I walked in, I felt safe, secure, and supported. The staff is not only professional but also incredibly compassionate, which made a stressful situation much easier to handle.

The doctors took the time to explain everything clearly and reassured me every step of the way. The nurses were attentive and kind, ensuring my comfort and answering all my questions. The facility itself is state-of-the-art, with clean, modern spaces and an overall atmosphere of excellence and professionalism.

If I had gone anywhere else, I’d probably still be freaking out, but Cedars-Sinai provided the level of care and expertise that makes it stand out as one of the best medical centers in Los Angeles and beyond. They are truly lifesavers, and I can’t recommend them enough for anyone needing top-notch healthcare.

“In its letter to Cedars-Sinai, the federal office said that it examined records of 38 patients who had suffered postpartum hemorrhaging. In 14 of those cases, the treatment concerned investigators as "potentially deviating from protocols" partly because of race, the letter said.
In one instance when a Black woman suffered postpartum hemorrhaging, "management of her bleeding appeared severely delayed" and out of step with Cedars-Sinai guidelines, the letter said. In contrast, a white woman with similar signs of hemorrhage "appears to have received care in line with the guidelines." - Los Angeles Times (Federal review ‘raises concerns’ about care for Black pregnant patients at Cedars-Sinai, Nov. 20, 2024)

Each and nurse and doctor have been very attentive to my every need. They discovered a problem wrong with me and called and told me to return to the hospital immediately for services. The only downfall was that I had to wait in the long line again. The service overall was helpful and supportive!

Anyone scheduled for a pre-op “Fibrin Glue Patch” and was told that something happened with insurance so you’d have to check in with Admissions in advance of your procedure?
