the ambulance service is nice, but felt isolated and not heard by the doctors and nurses about my procedure concern. They pursued the invasive surgery than the optional one that can provides both diagnostics and treatment.
I’ve been doing therapy and the staff is good.

My husband was seen in the ER at Houston Methodist on Fannin yesterday, and we left feeling completely dismissed and deeply concerned about the quality of care he received. After eight days of unexplained high fevers, we came in hoping for answers and help. Instead, we encountered a number of issues, starting with a major patient safety concern.

At one point, my husband was taken to a room because they said he was being admitted, only to later find out they had mistaken him for another patient. That is completely unacceptable and incredibly alarming.

To make matters worse, the ER doctor, Dr. Benjamin Godfrey, was rude and dismissive when I began asking questions. I was simply trying to advocate for my husband and understand what was going on. He has been sick for over a week with no explanation, and we were told everything looked “normal.” When I asked if he could be kept for observation, Dr. Godfrey cut me off mid-question and abruptly said “no,” stating we didn’t meet criteria, without offering any meaningful explanation. He was short and condescending, as if my questions were a challenge rather than a concerned wife trying to help.

I also asked if more testing could be done since we still don’t know what’s causing the fever. Even he admitted he was concerned about the unknown origin, yet said additional tests weren’t necessary. How does that make sense?

We left with no answers, no treatment plan, and a complete loss of trust in the care we received. Between being confused with another patient and being treated like our concerns didn’t matter, this visit was unacceptable. Houston Methodist is known for excellent care, but this was far from it.

I don’t know if this hospital has some sort of weird policy for their doctors to only take care of people who have more money to offer or better insurances. My brother has United healthcare and went into to get checked for throat pain of 3 weeks. The doctor (an older male) did not even look into his throat but instead put a flat wooden stick in his mouth to see if there was a cough. No cough. Didn’t even ask for my brother for any other side effects he was having. They dismissed him home with pain medication and nothing else. 3 months later my brother is up in Pennsylvania, throat pain still going strong and now bumps all over his body. After checking into a hospital there with little money to offer, these doctors went above and beyond to find out his body was fighting an infection he had for 3-4 months, which is now finally going away after they prescribed him the right medicine, his throat pain is almost gone now and the bumps all over his body (he had for a month) are gone. Somehow Houston Methodist looked over this infection and if it weren’t for him checking into that hospital in Pennsylvania, things could’ve turned out worse. Now I would like to know how small town doctors in Pennsylvania were able to spot an infection in the body that “the best hospital in Houston” couldn’t even find? Didn’t even put ANY efforts in checking my brother and actually finding out what was wrong with him and dismissed him with a strep throat. Even LBJ is more willing and helpful than Houston Methodist. Either some of these doctors are not educated enough or this hospital only helps whoever has more money to offer. I will spread the word that Houston Methodist doctors do not care or try, and things get dismissed. Please RECONSIDER before going to Houston Methodist hospital.

My spouse recently had a procedure at this hospital, and we were very satisfied with the entire experience, from check-in to discharge. The staff was attentive, professional, and made sure he was comfortable every step of the way. During the procedure, RN Jennifer stayed with him the whole time, which gave him great peace of mind. Once he was moved to the recovery area, RN Gissel provided excellent care and made sure he was well taken care of. We’re truly grateful for the kindness and dedication to their ICARE values of the entire team.

Definitely the worst place I have ever been to in the last 6 months. Just exactly like other big corporations can’t take care of everyone, however, I’m not looking for special care or something, they can’t even do their jobs right. Firstly one of the doctors I saw, absolutely awful, he’s late for my appointment(I waited for 40mins), and he only saw me for 10mins or so, he left without saying anything; secondly I wanted to see another doctor who’s recommended by my PT for 2nd opinion, I was told since this doctor was in the same medical group they had to report to their management then get back to me, and they never; and the last, after nearly half a year, I got the bill from them that I still have to pay some since my insurance only paid a certain amount, don’t you guys have to check when a patient schedule an appointment, at least other place will tell me whether the provider I’m seeing is in/out the network. Plz don’t say I’m an adult and I should know better. I’m simply just a patient.
I am disgusted with this organization is doing to Dr.Mary Talley Bowden. Watch her interview on The Joe Rogan Experience and you will understand why I say this. I will never be going here in my life.

I just want to express my thoughts about this hospital I would definitely do not recommend. A year ago today my mother passed away on Father’s Day . I never had the courage to right a review until today. I just gotta say the care in this hospital is the worst .!!! I work in Willobrook Methodist and when my mother was there better care she received. My mother was in Hospital on Methodist fanin almost over 2 months . I spend most of time arguing with nurses and director  on how the nurses wouldn’t not come and check on mother not come do her bad she was in icu she developed bed sores because nurses wouldn’t not rotate her every 2 hours like they was supposed too. My mother passed away and I spent most of time arguing with the staff on how to care for a patient in ICU. My mother was intubated but was able to write and tell us nurses were mean to her. It is so disappointing that we trust this doctors and nurses but yet end of day the care is horrible. I took notes names etc daily on who I spoke too etc WORST HOSPITAL!  One day they say she’s ok next day they say her liver dead honestly this was the worst experience ever losing my mother . I also think yall should train nurses on when putting patients on RESTRAINS ON HANDS  THEY SHOULD LOSEN THEM UP SO BLOOD CAN FLOW MY MOTHER DEVELOPED BLOOD CLOTHS ON HANDS BECAUSE NURSES HAD THEM SO TIGHT. A PERSON HAS ARE RESTRAINED ON BED FOR LONG TIME YES THEY WILL DEVELOP BLOOD CLOTHS SO THEY NEED TO LOSEN THEM UP AND KEEP AND EYE ON THEM .

My brother ended up in the emergency room at Houston Methodist in April 2023. What we thought would only be an overnight stay turned into almost a full week. I flew out to be with him, and we were both so impressed and appreciative of everyone involved in his care. The doctors were thoughtful and trying to get him on the best path moving forward, the hospital itself tries to make things as comfortable and accessible for patients' families as possible, and the nursing staff was incredible! The nurses and NAs were so responsive and attentive throughout their long shifts; my goodness, they work hard, but their care was always exceptional. The hospital is truly patient-centered, and I was so grateful my brother was in such good care during his stay there. Thank you, Houston Methodist!

I just had a knee replacement at Methodist hospital downtown.  I was only there from 6:00am - 5:00pm. Everyone person - nurses - PA - Doctors - that were there for me were EXCELLENT! Even after my surgery and the following weeks afterwards I have still been contacted by Methodist to ask how I am doing and to give me lil pep talks - which I needed -as this is a difficult surgery! Cannot say enough good things about Methodist Hospital!
Reports and documents have been requested from the international office with no response

Wish I could give 0 stars.
Disgusting place just like the attitudes of the nurses!!! Never again

I exclusively go to Methodist Hospital and Methodist doctors because I know that they know their job, they’re well trained, and they are very patient centered. Methodist is absolutely above all the rest!
I recently had injections to my neck. I had a great team of professionals. I was kept comfortable and informed every step. I highly recommend this facility.

Although finding my way was confusing because it is such a large facility….everyone was kind and professional.  My care and surgery were excellent and I was kept comfortable.  Everything was very clean and sterile. They posted updates on mychart and I was able to do a virtual check-in and online registration and completion of forms which was convenient.

My husband has been receiving treatment for bone cancer at Methodist Hospital on and off for the past 11 years. He’s been hospitalized three times just this year. Throughout our experience, I can’t say enough good things about this hospital. Whenever he presses the call button for a nurse, the response time is always under five minutes. We’ve consistently been surrounded by a compassionate and attentive team.

I’m honestly surprised to read any negative reviews about this hospital. Over the years, there have been a few minor oversights, but nothing major. This is completely understandable, as no one is perfect. Overall, I give Methodist Hospital a solid 5 stars. The staff works tirelessly to provide excellent care and, in our experience, they never fall short.

I had a tumor ablation in my right kidney. Was told it was removed and no biopsy taken although I am a cancer patient. I started new doctors at MD Anderson in early Feb. 2025
From my initial meeting I have gone thru a serious of test of the , bladder, prostrate, and kidney. I was asked by an MD Anderson doctor what was done. I told him a tumor ablation in right kidney.  He said the radiologist missed the tumor and killed the cells around the tumor. So disappointed in your team. You should have done a c-scan follow-up on the ablation. Nothing was done.
He was a very young fellow… he may need additional training.
Cafeteria food was terrible had the Barbeque and the sausage and green soup. There was no love in the food#no no flavor.
As usual Methodist Hospital and surgery center nailed it again. Thank you Dr. Kevin Varner and staff for the excellent attentiveness, care, and surgery outcome.

The general attitude and fast attedance for a kidney stone situation was issued were professional addresses with highly medical clarity and a guided path of medical in hospital and out hospital actions to follow. We are thankful for this as well as the fast information system of results and follow-up with pharmacy.

It could improve the dietary options for transplant patients for lower sugar and healthier options when it comes to breakfast, lunch, and diner options.

Nurses, doctors, and physicians at ER and in Room were kindly, friendly, and professional.

You should expect an appropriate time for lab, scans, and other results. It depends on the number of patients.

I recently and purposedly sought out a recommended surgeon, Dr William Hadnott, III, and have completed 1 of 2 hip replacements at your Houston Methodist Hospital in the Houston Medical Center. I'm just two weeks into recovery, and so far, everything is progressing according to plan.
I'm very thankful to the surgeon, his staff, the hospital and their staff for everything they have done to make my total experience nothing but a wonderful successful experience, given the type of expected pain and recovery that comes with it.
Updated 05/19/25
At this time, I'm one week into the recovery of my 2nd of 2 planned hip surgeries.
I'm totally pleased with the outcome of both surgeries, and eagerly await for my post-op office with Dr Hadnott later this week.
I'm so pleased with my daughters' recommendation to choose this doctor and his choice of Houston Methodist Hospital for this outpatient surgery procedures.
Kudos to all involved!!!!

Dr. Thekti is a fantastic  throat doctor with Margarita RN on his team.  They exude professionalism and confidence in their care to the highest degree.  Seeing the two of them work effortlessly side by side puts a patient immediately at ease.  Sarah Schuyler

They are scammers. I went for my annual checkup the other day and they charged me a ridiculous total of $4859 for just a urine and blood test. Even with insurance it is $1,210. Very ridiculous. Not recommended.
Not sure what sort of medicine they practice here, but its not from the 21st or even 20th century.
They know how to make you feel comfortable thru the whole process.

Patient care has gone down tremendously!!! Extremely slow care, and when I was in the hospital they were such in a rush to discharge me and wrongfully discharged me! So I called the authorities at the hospital and told me to come back to the ER and when I got to the ER, the nurses were EXTREMELY slow! No sense of urgency whatsoever! Poor poor care!!

Why on earth did they send a PAID bill to a debt collector? They took over a year to notify of the bill for the first time - insane by itself. I paid it within a month and now they're sending a debt collector after me for something I paid off within one month of receiving? Absolutely insane.

I've been logging into MyChart multiple times as I was still a patient here. This bill did not show up on my MyChart until MARCH 2025. 14 Months after my treatment. I paid it April 15th.

Why in May am I getting harassed by debt collectors over this?

I recently had a trip there and was administered care by a Ms. Sanchez. I previously held a position in the medical field so I’m aware of how proper care should be given. She was very attentive and helped me feel comfortable while receiving a set of vitals. I could tell she was not only experienced but personable too. Thank you to her and the staff for making the entire experience easy going.

HORRIBLE is one word to describe my experience at Methodist today. I came here for a doc appointment. The place is huge and chaotic. There is a lot negative I can say but I want to highlight the worst blood draw I have ever had.

The phlebotomist made a super tight tourniquet and left it in place throughout the entire blood draw and did not at the end apply pressure. My palms were turning red and throbbing. When I came home and removed the bandage I saw a lot of blood on the bandage and a hematoma.

I have tried to capture the progress of this from when it was done over the next 2 days. The place she poked is bubbling up.

===============================
Please take a look at the very automated and sterile reply to poor reviews. It tells a lot about how much this place cares for patients, the business of medicine!

Houston Methodist Hospital earned 5 stars!! The surgeon (Dr. Ahuero), the antagonists, nurses, and support staff were all very compassionate and professional! They all worked together very well as a team! My team did a great job explaining everything to me as well as my wife! The facility was very clean and all of the equipment was new and pristine. Outstanding experience! 5 star experience! Great job Houston Methodist Hospital Team!
They don’t look at the look at the whole picture
My favorite is always a Methodist hospital.

I manage my medical and my husbands. You are not set up for this to easily happen. I’ve attempted to set this up with customer service my chart several times without success. The devices are an obstacle as I do not always have access to his phone. Your customer service for my chart is inept. I get the Hippa requirements, etc. I’m in your hospital as I write this with husband having an MRI and there isn’t a single person in your support staff that can help other than give the phone number for the unhelpful desk. Which I’ve called again to NO avail.
I’d like to accommodate your desire for me to use my chart but until it becomes easier, I’m done spending my time with your broken system. I have hours invested on several different occasions. Your doctors are exceptional. The west hospital is excellent. Your clerical support staff need training and awareness. I’m not the only one w/ this problem. Most women manage their husbands healthcare. I don’t understand why you put customers thru this nonsense when they are sick and stressed already. 🤬

Their policy about child birth is absolutely ridiculous!!!! My son had his 1st baby here and I had to get out and then wasn’t even allowed to see the baby for over 2 hours after he was born. I didn’t mind letting his wife’s mother be present during the birth so considering that she will be in the room the whole time, this is complete crap. How is it up to you who is present when their child is born. They should have at the VERY LEAST allowed me and the other grandmother to rotate out once the baby was born ESPECIALLY since I’m the one that needs to make the hour drive to their house and take care of their pets and mine. My other son has 3 children and I have NEVER had this experience. I was able to either be in the birthing room WITH the other grandparents OR allowed to see the baby right after it was born. This will NEVER be the hospital another one of my family members is born at!
So I was actually here for an emergency room visit, and the amount of disrespect I had afterwards was insane and I would never recommend anybody to ever come here ever again.

To Whom It May Concern,

My name is Courtnie Riley, and I am writing to express my deep concern and disappointment regarding a recent interaction I had with a member of your Case Management team at Houston Methodist Hospital in the Medical Center.

I received a call from Gail, who identified herself as the Director of Case Management on 4/23/35. She provided information that was both inaccurate and dismissive. Despite previous conversations with other hospital staff who indicated that the medical team would explore my mother’s condition further to identify the underlying pathology behind her repeated hospitalizations, Gail abruptly informed me that we needed to come pick up my mother and handle everything on an outpatient basis. We do not believe that it is safe for her to be discharged at this point, and we are simply asking for a comprehensive evaluation before making such a serious decision.

Gail continuously interrupted me, spoke over me, and engaged in unnecessary banter when I attempted to express my concerns. As a concerned daughter advocating for my mother’s health and well-being, I found her tone and behavior to be rude, condescending, and completely lacking in empathy or professionalism.

When I asked to speak with her supervisor or even just to be given a name and contact number, she refused. She instead told me to speak to someone in guest relations, even after I made it clear that I wished to speak directly with her superior. She then hung up on me. I attempted to call back, and she still would not provide any information.

If I had to rate my experience with the Case Management department based on my interaction with Gail, it would be a 0 out of 10. Her conduct reflects poorly on the hospital and undermines the trust families place in Houston Methodist during vulnerable times. It is not just what you say—it is how you say it. And in this case, Gail’s approach was completely unacceptable.

I strongly urge hospital leadership to review this matter and hold staff accountable for the way they communicate with patients and their families. I am still requesting to speak directly with Gail’s supervisor and would appreciate a follow-up on this issue.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
C Riley
I look forward to going to see my Physicians!

Encountered a nurse with a power complex. 4/19/25, about 5:30 pm- 9th floor, Alkek, cardio, intermediate care. Went to visit a loved one, this one nurse asked me a million questions as if she was related to the patient before telling me I wasn't allowed to visit because the patient was in isolation. Which was strange because the patient had been receiving visitors and there had been no changes in their health status. I also saw other rooms in the unit and people WERE VISITING. The entire unit is deemed as isolation I later learned. I was allowed to leave items I brought to be delivered to the patient. I called information later just to confirm visitation policy and was told no more than two visitors at a time and no children. Patient had no other visitors at the time as we video chatted on my way out of the hospital and patient also didn't understand why I was denied. I didn't get the name of the nurse so I couldn't follow up with a complaint to patient advocate services. I called the next day to try and pinpoint who I spoke with, no luck. Even with providing time of visit and patient room number. How do they not know or have record of who was assigned for patient care? In the future I will be sure to document names.

Enjoyed my hospital stay. Amazing ER team, great observations unit nurses and the food services staff were great. I was a patient for 3 days and all testing went smooth until I had a pet scan. The Cardiac Pet Scan team was a nightmare! They were totally unprofessional, unethical, rude, and disrespectful. Worst experience and treatment ever.The cardiac Pet Scan nurses were arguing with each other. Mrs B or V was disrespectful and unprofessional! She argued with me and got in my face. She kept telling me to just deal with the test and I'll be okay despite discussing medication for claustrophobia. They were so unorganized and rude! I can keep going about it because it was horrible!
The staff were incredible!  I had two procedures and could not tell that I had anything done.  It could not have been a better experience!
Can’t reach anyone on the phones

Dr. Catague was excellent! He saw me right away no long wait at all, which I really appreciated. He was very prompt, professional, and thorough. Big shoutout to Krystal the nurse she was absolutely fantastic! Friendly, efficient, and made the whole experience even better. Highly recommend!
Staff and Drs have always been wonderful. Facilities are comfortable.  Valet parking line is a mess though.  Avoid that entrance if self parking. .

This review is for Houston Methodist’s Billing & Customer Service only. The billing for services received at this hospital can be a nightmare. They won’t let you receive care unless you pay your estimate upfront which is understandable but good luck having them fix anything.  If it’s not in their normal checklist to check it can be frustrating. My patience in trying to get a problem fixed has been going on for almost two years now.
Also, lab services received at their doctor’s office in the Med Center have a different billing department and the balances don’t show up in MyChart. I had to flip back to receiving paper bills because the billing in MyChart is confusing and surprise bills from doctors that practice there but have their own billing service. This is due to my ignorance because I assumed they use Epic/MyChart like the hospital system I went to In Illinois and that all my charges would be centralized in one place to view & pay.

Nurse Kennedy on the GI floor was one of the best nurses during my hospital stay. I'm not sure if she will ever see this review, but she made a huge impact on me and my wife during our stay & through this Cancer Journey. We will forever remember her name & face. Thank you Kennedy!
Robotic prostatectomy. They think they got it all. 1.5 wks out and I am going back to work. No pain. Great care.
Nurses are really unresponsive waiting 30 min to an hour for a response each time you call them, giving meds over an hour last, surgeons are great but maybe want to recover elsewhere

Gave me wrong medicine
! Stay away from here
charged me 50$ for parking(I parked there for 5 minutes, very poor management, didn't like it

My recent surgery for a left bicep and distal tendon repair at Methodist Hospital in Houston was nothing short of exceptional. From the moment I walked through the doors until my discharge, I was treated with extraordinary care and professionalism at every turn.

The pre-surgical team was remarkably thorough in their preparation, answering all my questions with patience and clarity. My surgeon demonstrated both technical expertise and extraordinary skills, taking time to explain the procedure and expected outcomes in detail. The anesthesia team was equally impressive, ensuring my comfort while carefully monitoring my condition throughout.

Another thing that truly sets Methodist Hospital apart is the nursing staff. Their attentiveness, expertise, and warmth made a potentially stressful experience remarkably smooth. They anticipated my needs, managed the entire surgical process effectively, and treated me with dignity and respect at all times.

Even the administrative staff handled insurance matters and scheduling with efficiency, care and kindness.

The facility itself was immaculately clean, comfortable, and well-organized. Every aspect of my care appeared to be coordinated seamlessly among all departments.

Methodist Hospital has clearly cultivated a culture of excellence and compassion that permeates every level of care. My experience exceeded all expectations, and I'm profoundly grateful to every individual who contributed to my successful surgery and recovery. I would not hesitate to recommend Methodist Hospital to anyone seeking exceptional medical care in Houston.

Came into the ER with a bad case of kidney stones, the waiting was the hard part but definitely worth the wait all the nurses and staff once admitted into the hospital were great as well as the doctors and surgeons food provided was also pretty good!

Poor standard of care - go somewhere else. I ended a vacation to Dominican Republic early to go to the ER here, because I wanted quality care. I would have been better off doing to an ER in DR. It took me 7h sitting in various waiting rooms just to get the appropriate blood tests. They decided to admit me and so far I have been waiting an additional 30h for a room, with no end in sight, so in an uncomfortable chair with about 10 others in the fluorescently lit windowless room. The doctors are spotted about as frequently as big foot and have zero empathy, and the nurses have no autonomy for basic decision making.

We absolutely love this hospital! My dad recieved the best care from Alkek team 8th floor. Dr Amit Patel, Dr Zuniga his ID doctor were outstanding. They all took such good care of my dad. From the secretary to the charge nurses, shout out to Donna and all the amazing nurses too many to name but they were fantastic. Special thanks to Maria and Conseluo who are nursing assistants who helped my dad eat . Thank you to the social worker Jummi and anyone I may have forgotten.

I have been calling to reach the doctor for three weeks but was never able to reach anyone from the office. The call was always transferred to the message center and never gotten a call back after leaving multiple messages. Even worse, the office still the CT scan CD which was never returned to us.

I understand why Houston Methodist has received high ratings. They are truly the best hospital of all. The Staff, Nurses and Doctors are very professional and caring for the patients. For my health needs, I chose Houston Methodist.

I felt at ease from start to finish. Everyone was so kind and made sure I was comfortable and understood everything the whole way through. I had a mastectomy on my right breast and I have told several family members it was the easiest day. It was an extremely positive experience. 11 out of 10.

Father went for a procedure he was treated very friendly like a grandfather by a grandson. Anesthesiologist very informative on medication for sleep and mannerism was great. Doctor and nurse same. Whole team very caring all while being very efficient and thorough. I appreciate the caring workers including the transportation personnel and the valet team. Hats off to methodist.  Keep up the good work caring for others.  It is recognized.
Everyone was kind, professional and attentive the day of my ankle surgery. From now on, The Methodist is my go to hospital for anything.

I’ve never been around an *entire* staff more helpful. I walked in from the parking garage, looked at a map, and immediately a staff member passing by asked if I needed help getting anywhere. My parents mentioned the same thing when they visited me in the hospital, that a stranger asked if they would like help with directions. So incredibly impactful at a place and time when even the smallest act of kindness means so very much and is so needed. This must be a policy that is encouraged from the management. Good job.

I am currently a patient here in room 1808, I came to edit my review. Social worker replaced my charger which I am grateful for. Her and the nurse management apologized and help my stay here remain comfortable, safe and secure. I had an issue with one night shift nurse(Older causian lady) but management came and swap nurses & they made sure my stay here was comfortable!

I love the team of doctors and nurse staff that were on board with me. Everyone did everything In the power to make sure I’m doing better. I am grateful for all the drs that help me up til this point & they still are currently.

Thank yall so much for caring and for the help. Yall are making sure my chronic issues are being treated . Thank you so much

I was not taken seriously nor given the proper medical or legal advice. No police report was filed. My blood and CT scan results were never reported to me by a physician. I saw one doctor during the three times I was admitted, and I was never discharged. Instead of addressing my concerns, they covertly tried to admit me to a mental health clinic—having me change clothes, put on a diaper (which I refused), wand me, and state clearly, “We are not admitting you into the hospital.”

I was “seen” by numerous nurses and “police officers,” yet across three ER visits, I was not helped. My condition—severe sleep deprivation—only worsened. Despite repeatedly stating that I was being trafficked, I was denied the help I needed. A department doctor even told me, “You will never get sleep medication at a Houston Methodist hospital.”

I eventually began violently hitting my head against the wall while a myriad of people watched and did absolutely nothing. A nurse detained me, throwing me into a room, though they did release me when I asked. I repeatedly voiced my issues—again and again—to people who did nothing. Then, I was simply allowed to walk out, having received no actual help, only endless dismissal and condescending attitudes. I was forced to follow up with my GP just to get the medication I needed.

The first night I left, I asked a nurse for something to help me calm down and rest in the hospital before taking any kind of psychiatric evaluation. They refused. I was then told, “You will be discharged from this hospital if you do not take a psychiatric evaluation. If you do not take this evaluation, you will have to leave.” They refused medical care for over five hours despite clear evidence and a diagnosis proving that the issues I was reporting were real.

They left my blood tubes in the room with the trash. They had me sit in a chair for most of the time—I had to ask for a room with a bed. At one point, I had to threaten to call the police just to stop them from trying to admit me into a psychiatric ward.

Unfortunately we did not have a good experience. My husband had a procedure on his kidney for cancer. He fell that night in his room after telling the nurse something wasn't right. She did not listen. Then discharged the next day with no discharge orders or wheelchair out. Filled out survey after with complaints with no response. The doctors were great. Hospital experience was not.
Amazing nurses, doctors and support staff.  They all made my experience as comfortable as possible.  Very caring and attentive.
From my surgeon to the aftercare team, all went past being exemplary to being exceptional in the quality of emotional and physical care they provided

Had reservations about this hospital initially but all doubts were blown away by the astute professionalism exhibited by every staff from receptionists ,nurses , doctors and porters without any exceptions. Truly impressed and appreciative for the high standard  of medical care shown to me .

I realized that my doctor didn't really care about my health when I lost my insurance and would not refill my meds that aren't supposed to stopped suddenly which caused other issues. He didn't even give me a chance to get more insurance. So, I have been ok with natural life changes. So I advise you to
get a second opinion before just letting any doctor prescribe you meds. As long I was seeing him every month, I could get whatever I want. From Monjaro to Xanax
Great overall professional service!

It is ashame that I  have  to  go  to  the  Medical  Center to get the service I received.  Just make sure older people know how to manuver through the traffic  especially  if it is their first time to your facility. Better yet, build a facility  on the northside . PLEASE!!!!!!!

Husband was admitted from the ER, but the waiting time to get a room is extremely ridiculous 130am Sunday was told he was going upstairs, it's now 2:30pm Monday, 13 hours waiting for a room that is still not ready.

The staff was amazing. This hospital is so organized.  It seems everyone enjoys working there. After my surgery and days following I did not get any food. Even when the doctor said I could eat. I was released and returned a few weeks later due to having two strokes. Most likely caused from my surgery. Again no food
Both times I did end up getting a little broth. I was not on any diet restrictions.

Houston Methodist is the best hospital I have ever been in and don’t plan on going anywhere else!
All of the staff, from the doctors and nurses to surgical staff were so courteous, knowledgeable, friendly and professional! Everything was fully explained and I was very comfortable.
I had a 14day hospital stay and my experience was AWESOME all of my nurses were GREAT💕

Everything exceeded my expectations. The only negative is the cost of parking. I purposely had relatives drop me off & pick me up after my surgery. The entire staff is compassionate, caring and emphatic.
I love this place very welcoming

My brother had to be put in ICU after an emergency surgery. We had the privilege of having a nurse that was so amazing. Any questions I had she was able to answer. She helped me and my mother understand what we couldn't understand. She explained what she was doing, what she was giving him and would continuously check on not only my brother but on me and my mom. She had very kind words that would comfort us. We was so blessed to have this nurse for 3 days and still we are here in ICU. But I had to share this to everyone.Nurses like her need to be recognized. She was one of the best nurses I will never forget. Thank you  Ashly Chapman you are a amazing nurse.

Recently had eye surgery, Dr Pandit and the staff were absolutely amazing. From check in to check out. Staff made me feel relaxed and comfortable. They know patient care. Thank you Dr Pandit and nursing staff.

I had a hip replacement. The Doctors treated me great and answered all my questions. Everyone treated me as if I was their favorite relative and wanted the best for me. A shout out to Drs Park and Nguyen. The nurses and attendants were great!  Here are some that I remember: Adam, Patricia, Gina, Atilla, Scott, Shelby, Laura and Susan.  Thank you from the bottom of my heart!❤️
Houston Methodist is the place to go when necessary. Best all around.

I was recently admitted to the hospital and I am impressed with all employees that work at HMH.  The ER department has excellent ER Staff.  I witnessed compassion not only with me but every person that was there. The food offered is also great.  Thank you HMH.
Great experience having neck surgery here.

My experience could not have gone better! There is a culture of care and compassion at Methodist Hospital that is evident in everything they do. If you see a Methodist Hospital employee in the hallways, they reach out to help – unsolicited. They genuinely care. The hospital staff communicate every day, before and after surgery. The level of communication is appreciated and is extremely useful and helpful. While I cannot remember everyone by name, I do remember Susan in the surgery recovery, Joy, my nurse while in the hospital and Meghan who greeted us as part of the names I remember. While I may not remember all of the names, I do remember the super service provided me by the first person who welcomed to Methodist to the person who helped me into my car as I was discharged! Highest accolades and thanks to all!

Pathetic patient health care.
Very lethargic in responses .Sorry to say,I have had one of the worst  experiences there

My sister lost her life because she needed an ICU bed and they didn’t have any. She was forced to receive care in the ER until 2 days later when a bed became available in the ICU, by then it was too late as her health had already begun deteriorating due to the lack of intensive care she needed but was not given in the ER. She was 36. Methodist is responsible for her death and nothing can change that fact.
Wonderful hospital. My mother was taken care of very well in the stroke unit

Methodist Hospital price gouges for procedures, and as such are part of the healthcare system crisis in America.  The fair pricing for the oncological surgery procedure I needed in August 2024 in Houston was around $13,880 (this includes surgeon, facility, and anesthesia).  Methodist was charging $70,392 (this is what they report to insurance companies) with a self-pay discount of 50% $$35,196 - which is what you pay if you pay for the procedure yourself.  Even with the 50% discount, the amount is more than double what fair price is. I gave them 2 stars because you could tell the individual employees were really trying to get a better discount so I could get the surgery and they cared, but when they went higher up the chain the main person said "this is what the hospital charges and if she can't pay it she'll have to go somewhere else." I went with Baylor St. Luke's which offered fair pricing. They have a brand new facility and I really loved my surgeon and staff. She is very intelligent, competent, and has a very calm demeanor (Dr. Hoppenot).

I don't have regular health insurance, I have a medical sharing plan called "Sedera" offered by my workplace.  They are trying to be a solution to the system, the only thing about using them is that you need to do a lot of legwork and obtain quotes from these facilities if you need something paid upfront (and they'll only reimburse fair pricing, not price gouging), or you also pay for smaller office specialist visits then they reimburse you, so I've been able to really see the underbelly of the medical system trying to get all these quotes for my surgery.

Thanks to an admission by Methodist hospital, first of all the care I received from the  doctors and staff was amazing,, but honestly it saved my life. Dr Redko, pain specialist, was able to remove my baclofen pump, which should never have been placed to begin with
After that I found Dr Echo, plastic surgeon, who found the etiology of my problem, which has been misdiagnosed by so many doctors for 2 years, and was able to perform the surgery that I needed. I am a physical therapist for 45 years, most doctors don’t listen to their patients. All the doctors in the Methodist hospital and system, in particular Dr Redko and Dr Echo, who i met, did listen to me I also want to compliment the office staff of both Dr Redko and Dr Echo
As a medical professional I want to thank everyone!

My procedure was outpatient. Not being familiar with the Medical Center, we were able to navigate the traffic to our destination. Valet was readily available and showed up on time for check-in. From check-in to checking out, my experience with staff was stellar. Everyone was welcoming and made sure I was comfortable. The hospital system has an electronic system, My Chart, that has been a great help with my procedure and receiving updated communications via text and email. Has been a great asset for time management. I would recommend this hospital to anyone who may need this kind of medical care.

Patient care and service was excellent in the cardiac units and the family accommodations were excellent as well. It’s nice to be in a hospital where doctors, nurses, and staff are praying for you and truly care about the patients well being.

Absolute trash! Their system is designed to nickel and dime you to death, literally. They send you to every specialist for problems you are not having and then send you to collections a week later over bills you paid or were unaware of. The "intake, indoctrone" doctors that you meet upfront  refer you to everyone to bleed you dry of funds. Heaven knows don't ask for a allergy shot while seeing a primary care because they will refer you forever to other doctors within methodist draining your pockets dry. I had a ultrasound on my liver a back in September and just now a specialist opened up in January. Herman Memorial saw me the next week. Good job Methodist....you only care about money and  not your patients well being. Avoid them like the plague!!!! If you fell for their lies, do as I did and report them to the Texas Medical Board for a full investigation into their unorthodox practices.  Absolute TRASH!!!

Dr. Huang was recommended to me by a relative who was very impressed with the outcome, (similar to my problem).  My outcome was excellent and I was dismissed from home-health care in one week.  My only complaint was the long wait for the surgery......which was not really the fault of the Dr., but there were some needed supplies not available for a quicker solution to my problem.  Delmar (Dr. Huang's PA) was extremely efficient in answering my questions and needs through my portal........even when she was supposed to be on vacation!  I am very happy although I'm a little leary of the monetary "outcome".  Still waiting but am extremely pleased with the outcome.  Methodist seems very organized and I was never kept waiting more than a few minutes at each appointment.  Thanks and Happy New Year!

The new schedule of the out patient lab is NOT patient friendly at all! What used to be a schedule that opens at 7:00 AM is now moved on hour later at 8:00 AM. The impact of this hits working patients who need to go to work after a lab work. I go for out patient lab every 6 months and it was always a convenient schedule to be there early before they open and be the first few after they open at 7:00. Now with the new schedule, and considering the influx of patients, I need to call off work for half a day even if I go early at 8:00 AM. Even the lab techs don't want the new schedule. They become over worked! Apparently, Methodist instituted this new schedule to "save on cost" and make the bottom line look better. Shame!

Sugarland Methodist has always treated lil old ordinary me as a Queen during my less serious to major hospital visits.   My care team always provided clear expectations and care addressing my needs.  I wouldn't want to go to any other Hospital.  The doctors have saved my life twice!  My family all uses Sugarland Methodist also.
Doctors not professional. Nurses, excellent .

Just for the record and to keep the discussion about how Hospital and Insurance services work and make the money$$$. I had a problem swallowing. Went to the Houston Methodist Hospital as recommended by telemedicine. I arrived at 2:00am, the nurse did blood work and CT scan, but the doctor never came to see me. From 6:00 to 7:00am they said that there was a shift so another doctor was signing in. After asking a few times where is the doctor they said that the shift takes time and that the Dr will come to see me eventually. The Dr. Came to see me at 10:00am (8 hours later and because I kept asking). They gave me medicine and I was able to swallow at 11:30am. But, the Dr. wanted to do an endoscopy to make sure nothing was in the tract. After the endoscopy, at 4:00pm I ate solid food. I was able to swallow since 11:30am when they gave me the medicine. But then they put me again to wait in a room and they came at 7:00-8:00pm to tell there is another shift and that the Dr left and that know I need to wait until next day to be discharged because the Dr is not here.

There is no communication with the patient about the real intentions. They just say you need to wait or there is a shift happening. Im ready to leave since 12:00. They wanted to do the endoscopy, ok, Im ready to leave since 4:00. Why are they retaining me. Will this overnight stay be free????

This is unacceptable!!! There is an obvious intention to leave people more time than what is needed to be able to charge more. Who is protecting us, the normal citizens?

What a horrible place to get taken care of. Nurses are horrible. My dad was there 3 days and never had his pain gone. The standard of care of hospitals and ER is to get you out of pain and that was never accomplished. If you don’t have health care insurance you will not get taken care of. Pain and suffering is all that happened in that place and nobody did anything to get my dad some relief. Once discharged I asked for them to take him on a stretcher to the lobby because he was unable to to walk, seat or anything other than lay in a specific way & they denied him that even after speaking to a supervisor. Don’t come to this location. Wouldn’t recommend it to anyone. They are careless and don’t pay attention to patients needs.
Excellent experience all around!!!

Its getting very annoying not knowing how much my CTA is going to cost me before I come on Dec. 31. I have called 10X bouncing from different depts and numbers from Finance to Billing to Finance. You have wasted alot of my time. Perhaps I should charge you my hourly rate for waiting and put on hold!

No one wants to be in the hospital, but I would definitely recommend Houston Methodist over Memorial Hermann, St. Luke's, etc. The nurses and doctors there were easy to talk to and treated me like a human being.
They were very helpful, knowledgeable, professional.    I am very thankful for their immediate attention.   Thank you

Satisfied with the care but be prepared to be screamed at and solicited by homeless people out front. Don't expect much help from security. Even talked to the security supervisor at the time with no results. Was told I can defend myself anytime I feel threatened.

Houston Methodist Hospital Texas Medical Center for my Colonoscopy. Staff was very professional, helpful, considerate, and showed knowledge and compassion. Thank you to
Jones 7, preOp team, and Pacu team, as well and Dr Kalakota and her team, and Anesthesia, Dr Herrera and CRNA, for taking great care of me.

The care of my mom received at  this Houston Methodist hospital is very amazing!!  Her room that they give her is absolutely, beautiful and clean! everyone was incredibly friendly , kind and respectful to her. Her doctor & nurse explained everything clearly, leaving her feeling completely confident in her new liver transplant. I would highly recommend this hospital to anyone for those who need a liver transplant!.

The entire staff at his location is dedicated and supportive, but nurse Ruth Castilleja at the lab department definitely stands out. She is not only kind and professional but also incredibly knowledgeable. I definitely recommend this Hospital to anyone seeking excellent care.

I had went in with chest pain I was put in the hall way for more than 16 hours never seen by a doctor the nurse kept telling the is they are only a couple of beds away and nothing for more then 10 hours then I told them my left side is going numb they told we will let the doctor know one hour later nothing so I had to dragged myself out to get to another hospital

Came into the ER under doctors recommendation and they literally forgot about me in the waiting room. Thankfully I didn’t bleed out internally while I sat in their waiting room. Now I’m admitted and they are doing nothing that I couldn’t do at home, only this time it costs thousands of dollars. In Texas Medical center and has great medical facilities. Big campus with a few hotels inside the campus too and some restaurants.

I always feel personalized care each time I go to the Methodist Hospital for doctor's visits, or procedures and tests. The doctors, nurses and all staff are attentive to your needs, friendly, polite and respectful. Excellent care always!
One of the best, most reassuring hospital visits ever in all of my 78 years.

I have to take the time to write this review about my recent admission and experience at Methodist Hospital Medical Center. The Jones 10 Neurosurgery Division is top-notch! I was suffering from a medical issue that could have cost me my life. I was on my hands praying to God and Christ, and that along with the team at Methodist Medical Center is what saved me. The care and attention to detail, and the reassurance they provided was so sincere. I want to mention some names from the team; Janet, Debbie, Ed, JR, Kisha, Olivia, the lovely lady from the Ivory Coast, Dr. Alsafadi, Dr. Fisher, Dr. Coburn, Dr. McCartan, and those of you that I did not even mention. You guys rock, you deserve a pat on the back, and you helped save my life! I will never forget the care that you provided for me. I am still recovering, which is to be expected and the Methodist team got me this far. The rest is in God’s hands. Thank you from the bottom of my heart, Methodist team! Tamawna

I recently underwent robot-assisted, minimally invasive thoracic surgery for a hiatal hernia at Houston Methodist Hospital in the Medical Center, under the care of Dr. Min Kim, MD. My experience was truly exemplary from beginning to end.

Dr. Kim and his team displayed remarkable expertise, providing a thorough and comprehensive understanding of my condition while ensuring that I felt confident and well-informed throughout the process. The level of professionalism and care extended by the hospital staff was exceptional, transforming what could have been a challenging and intimidating experience into one that was seamless and reassuring.

Every individual I encountered, from the welcoming check-in staff to the nurses monitoring my vital signs, the transportation team, the anesthesiologists, the surgical staff, and the post-operative care team, exhibited the highest standards of excellence and compassion. Their meticulous attention to detail and genuine concern for my well-being made an indelible impression.

The hospital environment itself was so meticulously maintained and accommodating that, at times, I forgot I was in a medical facility, it felt more like a first-class hotel experience.

I extend my deepest gratitude to Dr. Kim and the entire team at Houston Methodist Hospital for their unparalleled dedication, professionalism, and kindness. Their efforts ensured a smooth and successful recovery, for which I will always be profoundly grateful.
What a great staff and Dr. Thompson is caring, prompt and professional!

I found the staff and team offering care to my Mother-in-law to be top notch. A special shout out to Jan, the Nurse for the shift I sat with mom. Also, Manji- CNA and to Albert who took meal orders from Dietary and Nutrition.

Excellent care. Attentive to needs. Always pleasant. Fastidious in handwashing.
Conscientious in our questions and notetaking.

Explained procedures and preemptive in anticipating needs
All the staff was very helpful and informative.

Amazing outstanding job nurses & doctors quick fast knowledgeable ,patient and understanding very professional on the needs of patients ,very thankful for making my daughter visit warm welcoming.I highly recommended Houston Methodist Hospital.

Visited the ER. The woman who checked my vitals (twice- once when I got there and once after a ct scan), the physician, 2 nurses I interacted with and the guy who wheeled me back from and advised me on my ct scan was phenomenal. I got here around 2-2:10 this afternoon. Im still here at 5:20 but  I’m almost out of here. I have been here before but only at night. My experience today with the “day shift” has been very pleasant. Night shift usually takes longer to get through the process and the staff seems to be a bit more rambunctious (at least when I’ve been there it was like that). I do not like going to ER but if I have to, I will always come here. I’ve watched the staff with all walks of life today and it’s a beautiful thing to see they care for us each equally and as an individual. Never a one size fits all thing. There are always bad apples but today, I’ve haven’t had the displeasure of seeing or hearing any. Very grateful for the staff that cared for me today. Keep up the good work and thanks for what you do.

other than woman at desk being slightly rude to my mom which I’m assuming was really unintentional giving the circumstances and one woman repeatedly asking me if I smoke weed unprovoked assuming cause I’m young and black (when I gave birth to my first son DESPITE BOTH OF OUR SYSTEMS BEING/COMING BACK CLEAN) the overall staff here was nice and caring everytime I’ve went here!

I am still speechless with how the psychiatric department handled my case in the ER. Reading back on my chart/notes the doctors are highly unprofessional and don't have a single clue what they're doing. The volunteers can help you out more. Excellent health care system. The only place I'll go. Superior Doctors, Nurses, staff, and facilities.

would like to recognize Janet, my nurse in the Emergency Department tonight, and the Neurosurgery team for their exceptional care and advocacy.

I came in with severe back pain following a spinal fusion in April, and Janet went above and beyond to ensure my concerns were heard. She took the time to understand my history, communicated with the attending physician, and worked to involve Neurosurgery when it mattered most. Once Neurosurgery became involved, they truly listened, reassessed my situation, and made sure I received the MRI I needed.

Their teamwork, professionalism, and compassion turned an overwhelming and painful night into a positive experience where I felt genuinely cared for and supported. I’m deeply grateful for both Janet and the Neurosurgery team for advocating on my behalf and providing such excellent care.

Very wicked organization. This place literally will go out of their way to destroy it's students lively hoods, professional licenses, and background by filing ridiculous lawsuits for misunderstandings of their property not being returned. Very helpful customer service! They really do protect their patient info! It was hard for me to cancel an appointment for my mother, since I had no power of attorney! So be assured, they do protect their patient's health rights! Nice!
UM took over our local hospital (Sparrow Lansing) and turned the whole area's care to crap. Everyone here is struggling. Hope they don't do this to your area.
Sent me to collections for 1.33 cents. Healthcare is ok but seriously? Why not reach out versus send to a debt collector
When all hope was gone, and my world was falling apart, this place saved my son's life! I could never put into words about how good these people are. Our experience was and still is wonderful.

The doctors and nurses here have hurt me and my newborn children I'm still emotionally traumatized I've tried putting my story on here  but Google won't let me they need to be accountable for what they've done to me and two of my children.  I am permanently damaged and I could have lost 2 of my kids because of them they've also neglected me during an emergency when I've desperately needed air and they waited until my insides were on fire and I was seeing Stars before giving me oxygen they almost cooked my newborn baby alive after I told  many doctors and nurses I think the incubators too hot and then a nurse finally came and apologized to me for the neglect, with my first child he should have been an emergency C-section they tore me completely open I am permanently damaged down there and I'm still having issues and by the time they pulled my son out he was completely purple if he was in there any longer he would not have made it, they've damaged me and almost killed two of my kids , I knew something wasn't right when they were trying to get me and the father of my third child to leave something told me that if I left I would have came back and she would have definitely been cooked alive and wouldn't have made it in their care I wish I could put all the details of my story on here, but they are awful they've traumatized me and they've hurt and mistreated me in my babies let's speak up let's hold them accountable they don't have the right to hurt us or our children especially when we come to them trusting them with our lives. Mothers speak up protect yourself in your newborns listen to your gut listen to your intuition and if you are having a severe asthma attack in your on the brink of passing out you're better off traveling somewhere else because they will let you black out before they give you oxygen because they feel it's necessary to ask your birthday several hundred times and your address several hundred times even when you start screaming for help in oxygen they ignore you and walk away and it takes a lot when you're low on air to yell for help someone help is in front of your face and they're not doing anything
Michigan Medicine is focused on the PATIENT. They spend time to know the patient. The use best researched treatments. Michigan Medicine is outstanding.

Utterly inept. I've been disabled and visiting doctors regularly for 3 years. My experience at this hospital was nothing short of mind-boggling, dehumanizing. I was diagnosed with things like fibromyalgia without ANY proper examination. I actually suffer from malocclusion that requires surgical intervention, and the doctors who can help me have been so cryptic and non-scientific. I can't say enough about how traumatizing my time there has been, and continues to be, as my body completely breaks down. I can't imagine how they can claim to be one of the top rated hospitals in the US, unless by "top rated" they mean they only take the easiest cases (it's a for profit gig after all). When I think about the things some of these doctors said to me it makes my blood boil. I don't have much of a choice, though, since I now rely on Medicaid and can't drive long distances. I wish I had other options. This health system has absolutely done more harm to me than good. I even had a surgeon use the Hippocratic oath as a justification for DENYING me medically necessary treatment. And it goes on....
Prompt appointment times!  Very people friendly staff with utmost professionalism:)
I voted for this. The winds of change are blowing.
U of M Health provides excellent care both pre op and post op care.
The ketchup dispenser in the cafeteria has been out for 8 days now. Thats unacceptable and weird
Doctor wrote off my lower back pain as period cramps. My urine test that was reviewed showed a kidney infection  but that was ignored. Was hospitalized for shock later that week.
Ignored an urgent referral for weeks despite multiple attempts by my doctor and myself to communicate. My symptoms worsened until I was hospitalized (at another hospital) never going here again.
Never had an experience there where they didn't mess up and make me worse in some way. Referrals from my family members have been ignored.
University of Michigan Health The best hospital I ever go

This has been an awful experience! Go to Michigan they really help everyone says… until they don’t. From the time in the ER where the triage took 3 hours to being put in the hallway all night. To bring admitted to a hallway and staying in the hallway with open beds to them pushing me out the door after telling my daughter that she has a ticking tome bomb in her head! No options just it will be discussed and we will tell you how this will be treated!

Don't come here if you actually want a team that cares about their patients. The "physical therapy" team is a complete joke, they don't listen to the patients, even if the patient is talking to them about thier current physical condition.

Being forced to lay in bed for over 15 hours, when you are supposed to be moving the limb that was operated on is ridiculous!

The medical doctors even talk smack about how horrendous the physical therapy team is...

Run away if you have anything other than a cold.

I have been to this ER and hospital with loved ones more times than I’d care to admit. Wait times can be long, but there is no other hospital I would recommend higher, and I have been to the majority of them. We are always treated with respect and kindness, and receive top notch care every time. The entire team is nothing short of wonderful. I honestly question anything less than a 5 star rating.

I'm only giving three because my nurses and physical therapy people were so wonderful. He did a crappy job with my stoma now years later thinking it would be a better outcome now that the ostomy is permanent. My stoma still isn't right, is more towards the top instead of more in the middle. When they closed me up they got the muscle of my buttox i also needed a transfusion which almost put me into shock. Now I've been home a week and my stitches have opened and I'm afraid to go back but living in Flint the hospitals are not what they should be. I don't like Dr Byrne and i think he needs to retire. He's the only reason i had a bad experience. Plus he didn't tell us things until i read my summary from his notes during surgery.
Do not expect the hospital staff to notify you when your loved one is out of surgery, you will need to constantly  to the desk and inquire while several staff members do nothing!

The University of Michigan hospital is a awful at communications.  Through the worst portal in the United States to good communications with doctors.

There website and those who work there have bad communications and in that field is also bad.

UM Hospital saved my live in 2007 after a brutal car accident. Dr. Soo Young Park was the lead surgeon. Crushed my left lung, tore my diaphragm, fractured my pelvis, tore my intestines in four different places (each of those can be a fatal injury in and of itself), crush my spleen and it had to be removed, and a whole lot of other stuff too. 17 days in the ICU, 9 of which i was in an induced coma. When i woke up, the first thing i saw was Dr. Park’s face. She looked down at me and said “Ryan, you should be dead right now.”. They couldn’t believe that i pulled through. The nurses were calling me the “miracle kid”. I truly believe that if I had been taken to a different hospital, i would not be here typing this right now…
They called CPS saying my son hadn't been there in months even though he was there 3 weeks ago if you don't listen to them and do exactly as they say they will call CPS on you even if you show up

This hospital fixed my eye up the best experience ever I only give four stars because of wait times in the ER. After my son sat at Hurley Hospital in Flint for 18 hours without seeing a doctor, we requested a transfer to U of M Ann Arbor.  UM accepted the transfer request and he was taken by ambulance.  He was in the ER less than 10 minutes and was taken back to be treated.  Within 1.5 hours he was seen by the surgical team and treated.  I cannot say enough about the entire UM staff from check in to check out and everyone in between. There is a reason UM is one best hospitals in the country, and now I see why.  Thank you very much for taking such incredible care of my son.

Treated me the best. I don't understand the negative reviews, but maybe when a lot of people pass through things happen, I would definitely recommend them. They it seems like they really cared about you and they almost the whole place treated me like I was their family or something. It's very amazed at the service.

I waited for two years to get in to specialist for a procedure/test that is not able to be done around my area. My doctor wanted me to have an ERCP with manometry. The doctor up here decided to do two other test instead, And found things on those test that he Dismissed. As well as dismissing my excruciating right upper quadrant pain that I’ve been suffering with for about three years now. Now I have a $4000 bill and the only thing they offered me was a referral to behavioral health gastroenterology…. And that’s for people who have fake pain and my pain is not fake. I had such high hopes and was so very disappointed. I thought U of M was the high standard, but I Was completely dismissed and ignored and gaslighted. Never again.

The care you will receive here is unmatched. Completely private for a public hospital. Most up to date technologies, research based and test driven makes the level of care you receive here completely non-comparable to anything i’ve ever seen. As far as Michigan goes you’re not going to receive better care or find more specialized treatments than any other hospital/clinic. I’m a new patient but my first impression has blown me away. Sure people complain about silly things like, potatoes.. lol not sure how that warrants a 1 star haha. But as far as I’m concerned the only review you should read are about the care. Simply not going to find better equipped or more knowledgeable care takers. They really know what they are doing. I like to call myself a smart cookie not anything crazy but I really enjoyed seeing the process behind my visit, not that I’m excited to return haha but if I have any choice I will be returning here. Worth the drive.
Dad brought in by ambulance with heart issues. Still waiting in the hallway as we speak. You could code here and they would still forget about you.

I owe my life to Dr. Bixby, Dr. Maginau, PA Tim Higgins and the staff in the BMT floor of Mott Women’s and Children’s center.  I was DX with a very rare subtype of AML in 2011.  After 3 failed rounds of chemo I had the choice of them keeping me comfortable until I passed or take part in a clinical trial.  Since either could kill me why not try one more chance so I chose trial.  Dr. Bixby and his team contacted the top 5 hospitals looking for a trial and they all agreed that one gave me the best chance.  My younger brother was a perfect match for a BMTso I had a big piece of the treatment there.  The hospital that had the trial and U of M partnered to start the trial.  I started the trial Chemo on Thanksgiving. My BMT was 11/30/11.  17 days later I got home in time to have what was likely my last Christmas with my family. A few days later I had another Bone Marrow biopsy to see if the trial worked.  January 6 I went in to get labs and my recheck and got the news of how the biopsy came out.  The BMT Dr. said he couldn’t believe he was telling me this.  I was 100% disease free, 100% my brothers donor cells and the chromosome that had split with both halves making blasts had been killed!  I was the first to ever survive the Trisomy 2 mutation.  I have now had 14 more years with my family.  I have lived to see my sons become men, have careers, build homes and become a Grandma 4 times!  God is so good!
I had care for removal of cancer tumors and a liver transplant. I will always be grateful for the doctors, nurses and all the people I meet there. God Bless them all.

I’m writing to express my deep concern and disappointment with my mother’s recent overnight visit to your hospital. Unfortunately, this experience along with several previous encounters has left us extremely unsettled.

My 70-year-old mother was admitted for a 3-night, 2-day stay to monitor her response to a new heart medication. She has a history of irregular heartbeats, and over the last two years, her heart health has declined significantly, partly due to medication changes. Initially, she had an extra heartbeat. Now, her heart has weakened, despite treatment.

During this visit, her care involved multiple doctors, including Dr. Rodger (Sr. Resident), Dr. McLaughlin (Attending), Dr. Armson, and Dr. Arps/Joly (EP). My concerns lie in the inconsistent approach they took. My mother was given different blood pressure medications (Dyazide and Triamterene), which deviated from what she takes at home and led to her heart rate falling into a dangerous zone.

She was started on Sotalol, which quickly caused severe side effects, leading to its discontinuation. The next choice was 800mg of Amiodarone an extremely high starting dose rather than starting low and monitoring her body’s response. We were told that the higher dose would allow her to be discharged with medication, while the lower dose required another overnight stay. That rationale makes little sense to me, especially when her safety is at stake.

The constant medication switching and what feels like “medical guessing” has caused great stress and uncertainty. We stayed longer than we were told, and no real solution was provided. I’ve sought second opinions, but nearly every provider refers us back to U of M, which is said to be the best. Yet our experience does not reflect that reputation.

My mother deserves a clear, safe, and consistent care plan. We deserve better communication, more thoughtful treatment decisions, and a medical team that truly listens. I hope this feedback is taken seriously for the sake of all patients, not just my mother.

Did not get my potato wedges with my food I had ordered while visiting. Not to mention only three pathetic pickles for my sandwich. What’s a guy supposed to do with only three pickles and two halves of a sandwich.

I have never had such a terrible experience at a hospital in my life. This was my first time visiting U of M Hospital, and I will not be returning.

I’m truly shocked that a facility with such significant resources has an emergency room that feels so undersized and overwhelmed. There are over 60 patients admitted, and yet there’s no space for us—many of us are left waiting in hallways and crowded waiting areas, with more patients continuing to arrive.

I’ve been here for nearly 10 hours without receiving a single medication or treatment. Despite being told I need to be admitted, I haven’t seen a doctor since 11:00pm, and no one has reviewed my test results with me. The conditions are not only chaotic but also visibly unclean.

I'm honestly struggling to understand what makes this hospital so highly regarded. U of M, you should be ashamed of how poorly your patients are being treated.

U of M is very misleading when it comes to billing. If you are looking for an outpatient procedure or any procedure that can be done at an Ambulatory Surgery Center (ASC),  DO NOT DO IT AT U of M unless you want to pay your out of pocket maximum.

U of M will NOT code it as an ASC for insurance purposes and will bill you the cost of hospitalization which is a very substantial dollar difference. Your paperwork from U of M will say it's being done at a ASC but they will say it doesn't matter, they consider all of their services to fall under hospitalization. Under my specific insurance plan and the outpatient surgery I was doing, the cost difference was $250 (ASC) vs. $33,000. U of M let me know 10 days before my scheduled procedure what the cost was going to be; we have been waiting a year to do this surgery so cancelling/finding another ASC to do this was unfortunately not a solution to us. This surgery was fertility related. U of M said they would take my complaint and let higher up know because I was right and agreed that it was misleading however, they couldn't do anything about it because that's not how U of M bills. So disappointing and discouraging, I really feel it's a scam and not many know that this is a thing to look out for when it comes to insurance, billing, etc. Trinity Health does not do this, they bill it correctly and bill it as a ASC vs. hospital.

It has been a whole night, they can't find a room, they forgot to feed him until I had to call and throw a fit.  It is not a good hospital, but it is the closest to my FIL.  Next time we go to St. joe's.

My recent visit with my son has been less than pleasurable. At 2:30am my son was taken to the ICU, Im a single mother with another child who is 6 years old. We arrived to the ER at 4:00pm. Once he was taken to the ICU, I was repeatedly questioned about leaving or having someone pick her up and how I need to understand that if she stays that night it won’t be acceptable in the future. While I understand the policy, It was 2:30am! No one in the ER even let me know he was being admitted until I asked what was going on at midnight, so it just seemed highly unreasonable to be pressuring an obviously tired mom with a sleeping 6 year old and a child that is moving to the ICU to leave or find someone to pick up my 6 year old so late in the night, then once the exception was made rather than just letting me know she can stay for the night, I was asked again “so there’s absolutely no one who can pick her up”, well she can stay to night but moving forward this can’t happen again. #1 I’m not a child, #2 what shouldn’t happen again is the sheer lack of communication, If the care team actually took the time to stop and explain what was happening perhaps I could have secured someone earlier. The whole visit, I had to request updates, the care team would come in and act like I wasn’t there with the exception of the PICU doctor Steve. My son was barely given a pillow or blanket during his first 8 hours there. Because he was heavily medicated, and tired, he had an accident and rather than putting the blankets in the soiled area, they were left in the chair where visitors sit. When I brought this to the supervisor Rachelle, she said but they weren’t touching him….. There were multiple condescending remarks made by the care team and when I spoke to her about the incident with my daughter, she thought it was acceptable to tell me to get it out of my head that I’m being judged and I just need to let my guard down. My son has come to U OF M on many occasions and I’m generally happy most times but on this occasion the behavior and care was simply lackluster. I’m unsure if there is a staffing issue, perhaps people are overworked but respect while doing such an important job should not be compromised.

I gave a 3 because most visits have been good but after reading some of the most recent reviews the core values of this facility may be going downhill.

I really thought coming here was gonna be a better experience especially since google said this is the best place to go too for lupus. This emergency room should be ashamed of themselves. They suck. WORST hospital and will never go here unless life or death. Getting bills they seemingly can't reconcile a year after a botched dislocated shoulder that they didn't fix properly and should sue really

My father was diagnosed with stage 4 oral cancer at this hospital in January 2024. At the time, aside from some difficulty opening his mouth, he was otherwise in good health and full of life. Sadly, he passed away in June 2024—just five months after starting treatment here.

According to his death certificate, he died due to respiratory failure. But as someone who was by his side every step of the way, I truly believe his health rapidly declined after he began chemotherapy and radiation therapy—treatments that, given the severity and progression of his cancer, were unlikely to improve his condition. Yet, these were the treatments strongly advised by his medical team.

I understand that every illness is complex and outcomes can be unpredictable. I also believe in God’s plan and that some things are simply beyond our control. But I also believe that in moments like these, the guidance and decisions made by doctors are critical. In my father’s case, I feel that he was given the wrong advice—treatments that did more harm than good. Watching him suffer through the side effects of aggressive therapy, only to lose him shortly after, was heartbreaking.

I’m not a medical professional, and I don’t pretend to have all the answers. But I share this in the hope that it encourages reflection among those in the medical field. Please consider each patient’s quality of life and unique situation when offering treatment recommendations. Sometimes, the best care is not the most aggressive option—but the most compassionate one.

This experience has been incredibly painful for our family, and I hope no one else has to endure the same.
As a CT tech myself, this is the fastest ER I have ever been to! Top tier
Great hospital and ER!  I saw Dr. Foley for an emergent, legitimate issue and he was caring and even brought me a sandwich!  Clean rooms too.  Will hopefully not have to come back.

Very bad experience waiting in the emergency room about 12 Hours crazy corruption going down In the emergency room pile up from That's from the entrance till The end of the hall I will not recommend it Anyone to go to this hospital

medical facilities should be run.

I am here in NYU hospital writing this review my son had a popcorn kernel stuck in his ear I took him to Long Island Jewish two of there locations no help I had to leave with the kernel they gave me an appointment for three weeks to come an get it removed I took him to NYU they saw me in 30 minutes an took 5 minutes to get the kernel out they are angels showed me an my son great care I will always recommend this hospital if your in need of proper care GO TO NYU on 1st ave .

I AM SO HAPPY TO HAVE BACK DISCECTOMY SURGERY HERE AT NYU LANGONE HEALTH HOSPITAL.I WAS TURNED DOWN BY MORE THAN 14 DIFFERENT ER HOSPITALS FROM PA THROUGHOUT NY.

I FELT I NEEDED SURGERY REALLY BAD.

I WASN'T ABLE TO MOVE MY LEGS MUCH AS I USED TO BEFORE MY ACCIDENT IN MARCH 2024.

I WAS ALWAYS IN CONSISTENT SCIATICA PAIN.AT ONE POINT, I THOUGHT I WAS NOT GOING TO BE ABLE TO WALK FOR THE REST OF MY LIFE.

PEOPLE, COMPLAIN A LOT ABOUT THE MONEY & BILLING BUT WHAT CAN I SAY.HEALTH IS IMPORTANT & LIFE IS MORE IMPORTANT, SPECIALLY IF YOU HAVE LOVE ONES THAT DO MATTER TO YOU.

LIFE, YOU ONLY GET IT ONCE IN A LIFETIME & MONEY CAN'T BUY A LIFE.SO, I TOOK THE OPPORTUNITY REGARDLESS OF THE COST & FOR ME IT WAS WORTHY. I AM GRATEFUL FOR GOD BLESSING ME BY PROVIDING ME THE STRENGTH TO COME TO NYU LANGONE HOSPITAL & HELP ME WITH MY LUMBAR BACK SURGERY.

THE BILL WILL ALWAYS BE HIGH BUT ONE LIFE IS PRICELESS...

THANK YOU!!

DR.ERIC OERMANN (NEUROSURGEON),TEAM OF MD'S, NP'S NURSES & CHAPLAIN FOR YOUR SUPPORT DURING MY SURGERY & STAY AT NYU LANGONE HOSPITAL.
