NEW REVIEW (OCT 2025):
I recently went to Penn in the ER. The wait was not bad they got me back in about 20mins despite the waiting room being pretty full. I was in the ER then the ICU then a regular admitted room and through all of that every Dr and nurse that treated me were all amazing. They were very compassionate and sympathetic they gave me excellent care and resources. I Don't remember everyone's name but Luana🌟 the Er nurse was amazing as well as the Dr in the Er I forget his name though sorry I think it began with an N like nicosta or something close to that he was so sympathetic. And the Drs and nurses when I was admitted were so wonderful, Stephanie🌟, sarah(?), Alex🌟, Agnes, Joana(?), and Luke🌟 the medicine Dr was amazing he really listened to my needs and accommodated me accordingly I never felt overlooked or under treated during my stay like I have at other hospitals. Jennifer and Jeff were so helpful as well. Even though Penn hospital was at capacity while I was there you would never know it by their treatment. It's worth going out of ur way to go to this hospital if u Don't live nearby because u will get better care and they are ahead of other philly hospitals with their cutting edge research and treatments. You will get better care here than other philly hospitals like Nazareth and Jefferson and even templei have been to all of them in the past year and I choose to go to Penn even though its out of my way to get the best treatment and the best care from their team of Drs and nurses. I apologize to those whose names I forgot.

OLD REVIEW (FEB 2025)
Whatever you do DONT let them "hold" any of ur valuables because it's likely you won't get them back. I gave them my money, cards and a few other things to lock up and keep "safe" only to find out at my discharge that they "couldn't be found"🙄🤔🤨
And I'm really upset to have to give them only 3 stars because of this issue because most everything else was good. I came in thru the ER and they got me right back despite having a full waiting room because I was having chest pains and shortness of breath I was afraid I had a heart attack. Immediately I could see the place was very clean which says a lot because this hospital is HUGE so that's no small task to keep clean. The nurses, CNAs and Drs were good i wish could remember all their names but I was there for almost 2wks and saw a lot of them Davida RN, Kylie RN, Margaret RN, Keisha? CNA, Annabelle the social worker, and there was a couple Drs I can't remember their names but especially one asian Dr on the addiction team I had long conversations with he really took the time to try to understand what is going on with the current drug epidemic. I'm sorry to the ones whose names I forgot.  The food was great, I actually GAINED weight there instead of losing weight like usual during hospital visits. The food services workers were top notch especially Joan (I hope I'm spelling his name right) and miss Vera were both very friendly. Joan even took the time to assist a nurse with a patient who was having a bit of an episode. He deserves a raise because he goes above and beyond.
They could be a little more giving with the amount of pain meds they give out but that's all hospitals anymore really. I would have given this place 5 stars if if wasnt for my belongings being "lost" 🙄😡
Not a place you want to be, but if you have to be in a hospital, this is the one. The doctors and staff at UPenn are amazing —  They made a difficult experience much easier, that's for sure!

I had hip replacement surgery with Dr. Cara Cipriano (highly recommend) in the Pavilion Building and my overnight room was in HUP Main building. From the check in to discharge all of the staff were exceptional. The care of how a patient is doing is felt consistently. The 6:30am check in time I was met with the most cheerful Pre-Op nurse Philippe as well as all who prepped me.

I had a nice room with a window and was surprised at how quiet it was. The nightshift nurses were amazing a I felt the care I was given through a hard  night was so specific to me. The PT and OT who came the next morning were patient and I felt safe learning to walk with the fresh hip because of their support.

The Patient Portal that Penn Medicine uses is easy to navigate and very responsive to questions sent in. I am grateful to have healthcare like this accessible to me and wish everyone had it.

The only thing that would have enhanced my peace is if there was a  general masking policy for all when going into patients rooms. I am immune compromised and they had a sign on my door and in chart but not everyone who entered saw it. All were happy to comply when I requested masks be put on.

Stir clear of this health system.  They will not schedule you with a family doctor's recommendation for 9-12 months in the future !!!!  Jade from Dr. Ginsberg's office took 2 seconds to tell me that both him and Dr. Kochman did not have availability until 9-12 months. Do not use Penn go somewhere else, it just might safe your life.
Love the nurses at SICU (Cheryl and Tyler). My dad is there now recovering from just a very recent procedure. Praying and thanks nurses

I really love the hub hospital I've been treated
There for over 60 years.

I did not know and she tried changing up my entire seizure regimen when I’ve been stable and not having seizures for almost a year. I’ve had epilepsy for 22 years and this doctor was Completely ignorant, un knowledgeable and didn’t even care about. My history. Only seemed to want to take over have control and switch everything up, which would have me going back to having seizures. Her name is Catherine Kulick- Soper.. HORRIBLE!!! She even called the pharmacy and inactivated my prescriptions. If you’re a Neurology patient you know how long it takes to get seen by another specialist somewhere else. Unfortunately, I’m leaving Penn for this reason but they probably won’t care. I’m just a number. I am writing to express my deepest gratitude to the entire medical team in the Observation Department (EDOU) where I stayed for four days recently. The care I received was exceptional, and I am truly appreciative of everyone's help during my stay.

I would like to extend a special commendation to my nurse, Amy Cornal, RN. Her care was exemplary in every way. Not only did she provide excellent medical attention, but she also showed a level of compassion that deeply moved me, especially the night before my stress test.

Understanding that I would be fasting, Amy created a detailed plan to ensure I would be as comfortable as possible and avoid hunger and headaches. She thoughtfully brought me coffee and a sandwich as soon as it was medically permissible. This gesture was so kind and considerate, and it meant the world to me.

Amy consistently worked hard and went far above and beyond my expectations. She is a wonderful representative of the high standards of your hospital. I would give her performance five stars—or even ten stars if I could!

Please recognize Amy for her incredible work and compassion. Thank you for fostering an environment where such dedicated and thoughtful professionals thrive.

Sincerely,

Ms. He

Emergency room staff was nice but one of the nurses strangely felt comfortable enough to tell me how she used to work across the street at Children’s Hospital and she hated how the children cried so much. “It was so annoying” Is what she said that rubbed me the wrong way, but that was at the pavilion ER when they transferred my mom to the old building across the street the nurses were impatient and ignorant. They don’t know how to talk to people, especially people who are sick but when the nurse called me, she was trying to play nice. I don’t like that I don’t know if I really trust them after this visit. I don’t know if them shifts be too long, but some of them needs to go home and take a nap and rethink if this is what they should really be doing Because I’m going to act up and give that same energy back to them about mine Maybe they should go work at free clinics I don’t know but get it together. I was expecting so much better.

Sitting here at the Emergency Department and this is definitely an unorganized operation. As soon as you walk in, you’re greeted with an extremely small waiting room for a Hospital of this size. Crammed packed like sardines in a can. There are flies everywhere. Receptionist and staff yelling names. No type of patient confidentiality or HIPPA protections. They’re asking personal medical information in plain open site. Treatment area is also open to all(unless they have you in a room) with no sense of  privacy or urgency. These Red chairs they have people sitting in waiting for Labs in the hallways is unacceptable. For this to be a new facility, they definitely didn’t plan their Emergency Department properly. It’s giving public Hospital vibes. Penn medicine needs to do better. Definitely not impressed.

The Dr said he just had a chance to look at some of my test that was performed yesterday evening Not one time was i placed on a Cardiac monitor although I complained of chest discomfort. Absolutely ridiculous.

On July 30th I had major abdominal surgery at U Penn Hospital in Philadelphia. I should note that the first visit to Penn for me and my situation was really incredible. I spoke with 2 specialist and one transplant surgeon in the Liver transplant division of the hospital. I also spoke to the many assistants and PA’s of those specialists. They were all great and within a few hours of meeting me put all their heads together and came up with a game plan for me and my family. They were awesome. Getting back to the surgery, I was told everything went great and to just listen to your doctors and nurses. Well that I did and it was almost painless. I would personally like to thank my physicians and their teams, please forgive me for not knowing all the name. . Dr Hoteit, Dr Abt, the RI doc who consulted with us in the beginning. And all their team members, especially Leah. Also want to thank the Anesthesiologist and his team also. I had an epidural placed and it made all the difference in the world. Now to the people who cared for me from Wednesday to Saturday every minute I was in there. Jean was who I woke up to and she was literally a site for sore eyes.  Here are the other competent, professional nurses I had were Andrew, Angela (2 shifts) and Mia. Obviously they are all different people but all of them were really compassionate, professional and committed. I retired from emergency services and my daughter is a nurse. I was so happy to be treated by people who I know have been through the ringer many times still have the kindness to do the job with a smile on their faces and that desire to help and serve others. Can’t say enough, it was awesome! Also can’t say enough about the hospital itself. It’s a state of the art place and the rooms are amazing and spotless. Anyway just had to put my two cents in on this and thank you for making a really nerve racking situation go as smoothly as possible for me and my family. Thanks again!  Respectfully Ed Shiffler

I had appointment with Dr. J. Lee (ENT) in January of this year for a history of sinus and sinus related problems. I’ve had 4 prior surgeries with no success. During the visit, Dr. Lee told me that I had no sinus problems and to see a neurologist. However, he prescribed $125 sinus medication, which made no sense to me, and wanted to come back in 4 months?
Subsequently, I was diagnosed by a different doctor with Wegeners Disease. Wegeners traumatically affects the sinuses which is the root of problem. That trip to Penn cost me $400 + (missed work, travel expenses, co-pays, worthless prescription ). I was rushed through like on an assembly line and treated as a joke. A simple blood test and a bit of concern would have been helpful.

I hope an administrator sees this. If i could give a 10 star rating i would. l have struggled with Diabetes for several years. I had terrible physical reactions from Metformin, Ozempic and now Mounjaro. I chose to go see an Endocrinologist at Penn because I believed then as I believe now that Penn Drs are the best. Dr. Chu is my Dr. She and her staff are extremely attentive and contact me as needed via MyChart. They are very prompt to  respond when I send them a message. I am extremely pleased to be their patient. I am so happy with my Penn Drs that I drive an hour from Delaware to see them

We were told our mother was going to the “Hilton of hospitals “ let’s be clear not all shiny  equipment and fancy tvs will ever replace basic nursing skills or communication.
Unless you live in the hospital room with your love one the care team does not contact you with updates. You have to call everyday wait endless hours on hold just to be told your family member is fine. Meanwhile they are calling a rapid response on your love one and nobody calls to tell you . We were fortunate enough to only be an hour away and got there in time to say goodbye. Let me be clear I am a nurse in a small rural hospital with far less staff or technology and I make those calls to keep family updated when they can’t be at bedside. Not all nursing staff was bad our RN Victoria in the icu made my mom comfortable and tried her best to comfort us family as well. This two stars is being gracious for the providers.
Dr. Haywood you have zero respect as a provider from me. You need a refresher in critical conversation skills. Your zero compassion for a grieving family and poor attitude during a families most difficult time was shocking.
Caring for the sick is more than a job, it’s supposed to be empathetic and kind.
My mother was failed so many crucial moments to come home and pass like she wanted because so many couldn’t take the time to tell us the real story.

Shoutout to the ED crew that was on the early morning shift 7/15/25 around 2:30am.  Specifically Dr. Forrest (can’t remember his last name),  Dr. Glick and his resident (forgot her name too, apologies).  My daughter had to get stitches near her eye and the empathy and kindness shown to us was so refreshing, both of the physicians were extremely patient with my daughter, answered all questions and were just all around pleasant.  Thank you all so so much💕

The team at UofP is absolutely phenomenal.  I've been here for open heart surgery and removal of a blood clot and the nurses, doctors and staff have been nothing but top notch.  Everyone has been professional, caring, tentative and sympathetic.    I'm so happy that we have UoP in our area.  This is definitely one of the best hospitals.

Terrible experience. I injured my foot playing soccer and went to the ER, they "fast tracked me," 7 hours later and I'm still here. Mind you all the X-rays and CT scan were negative. It took over an hour just to give me my discharge papers. No communication, just poor service. They will waste your time. Go somewhere else.

I was in the er for a joint related infection. I waited a long time. But what I observed there was a whole to of professional people who bend over backwards to accommodate you. Most people think that they should be put to the front of the line. They need to remember that they aren't the only ones there. I am amazed at how these people handle their work load. I sat a long time, but the people that went before me, should have been placed first. Unbelievable professionalism under extreme circumstances  I recommend to anyone. Just remember, you aren't the only one there. And don't forget the ambulances that never stop coming. God bless the doctors, nurses, the support staff, the senior surgeons, the office help! You need them!!

Currently, sitting in the ED observation unit for my mom and am appalled at the lack of attention and conditions as well as level of service.  There are numerous nurses that are shouting and laughing at the top of their lungs and not assisting patients or doing anything. I'm all for having fun at work but also do your job. I had to ask 2 times for a cup of ice, then had to get it myself. My mom used her commode (just pee) and it has not been touched in over 24 hours. She was never offered food the whole time here. Yet they stand at the nurses station chatting and when I look for the bathroom, they angrily yell at me for almost using the staff bathroom.
This is on top of the fact that we were her on Sat (today is Tues) and discharged, then called by the ED doctor on Monday telling my mom to come back because they re-read her test and got it wrong. And she could come right in once she got here. Then we sat waiting for 4 hours. Such a disappointment from a world class hospital.

My mother who is 95 wasn't feel well and we thought she might be having a stroke...I kid you not we came to the ER at 12:15 we are still sitting here at 8:49 on May 19, 2025 ...They said they're getting a bed cleaned so the doctor can see her that was 1 hours ago..I do not want to hear that message from you guys someone will call me...every chance I get I will share my experiencing 😫

The ER is horrendous with long long wait times. This needs to be rectified. But aside from that once admitted (cancer ward) the nurses and doctors are exceptional and attentive. Parking was not great. This hospital could really be something if they fixed some things.

This hospital saved my dad's life multiple times while he was there. The ICU nurses were some of the kindest people I had ever met. Although communication with the doctor's are limited, I had full faith in the doctor's decisions and their knowledge on how to treat him and save his life. I was the one approving procedures and treatments on my dad's behalf and when I finally did get a call from the doctor they made sure to explain the situation thoroughly to help me understand what was happening and what the plan of action was going forward. When he was finally moved from the ICU after 50 days, the nurses carefully removed all of the pictures and decorations we had hung up for him, moved them to his new room, and re-hung all of the pictures up for him to see and enjoy. As an added bonus, the rooms that aren't in the ICU are beautiful. They are huge and include things like an actual pull out bed, a huge tv, a mini fridge, a beautiful bathroom, and his view from the room (not in the ICU) is stunning. I don't know how much the bill will be, but I couldn't put a price on my dad's life and his comfort.

Edit: the "bill" was $9.1 million! My dad didn't have to pay that much, but that's what the hospital charged! I'm torn because I could never put a price on my dad's life, but really, America? This is the best we can do for Healthcare? The hospital has the right to bill $9.1 million to save a life? That is outrageous and unfair. We live below the poverty line, how is that fair to bill that much just to live?

I was recently seen at the emergency department for a seizure/seizure like activity. I’ve never felt compelled to review a healthcare provider until this unfortunate event. During a suspected seizure, in which I had elevated lactate, incontinence, and convulsions, I was shocked and disturbed to find that Dr. Alexander Tejeda attested that I was “faking foaming at the mouth.” Making a claim such as that is not only a disturbing assertion, but assumptions such as those are what make patients feel frightened and apprehensive to seek help in life threatening situations. I hope for the sake of future patients that you develop and grow throughout your career as an emergency physician, because a great deal of my faith in the medical system was lost that day. I wish you the best, and I hope this allows you to somewhat recognize how statements such as yours result in further damage to patients who are experiencing traumatic situations and look to trained professionals for help. I hope you have a successful career, and that your future patients receive the compassion and professionalism that I so sorely lacked.

47 years ago this hospital saved my newborn's life.  During the past 5 years, its Oncology Department has enabled my husband to survive his Stage 4 cancer diagnosis with a good quality of life.  This year the Cardiology Department has given my husband a new lease on life, by performing a successful ablation.  Yes, there is the odd staff member who underperforms, but 98% (unscientific measure) of the staff, from the dining people to the surgeons and everyone in between, seem proud to be part of an institution that, for the most part, excels in treating patients in a professional, caring and intelligent manner.  The ER Dept is a weak member of the HUP family and I am sure there are strenuous efforts working to improve the situation, which is difficult since it is an inner city institution where some citizens face enormous challenges.  In the end, given our family's experiences, we are grateful for the good fortune to have high quality health insurance, which means we can access the HUP's system.  I wish this accessibility for all.

This hospital has provided subpar care; I have been in the ER for eight hours and still have not been called in for my test results, which were available two hours ago. Despite my request, they refused to update my chart, instead offering the option to wait or leave if I wished to view the results. Furthermore, the ER administered medication without documenting it in my chart, making it impossible to track when it was given. I have never experienced a hospital that conducts tests and provides treatment without maintaining accurate records. I also requested an update, and he stated that he was not a nurse. I also feel that if you are not taking drugs, you will not be called to the back before the designated wait time you must follow.

Under no circumstances would I come back here or allow anyone to bring or refer me here. My Dr told me to report immediately to ER for an emergency blood transfusion because my hemoglobin levels were severely low, and so was my blood pressure. I came in at 12pm,  and it is now 7:56pm, and I’m seated in the waiting area with an IV in my arm, that they keep refusing to take out, because I want to leave, saying that it shouldn’t be much longer. I feel that I’ve had more than enough patience and understanding for them being short staffed. But with knowing that, why would they allow atleast 85 ppl to sit in this emergency room, knowing that they wouldn’t been seen for ATLEAST 10 HOURS. Not to mention, they have this extremely ignorant and rude male security guard or police officer.

I love this hospital and it’s hospital and staff but there billing department is a No for me. They’re quick to bill you for something without billing the proper insurance. God forbid if you have more than one insurance. You have to stay on top of them or you’ll be paying for things you shouldn’t have to pay for.

I am writing to formally express my concerns about the substandard care and medical management provided to my mother during her stay at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania (HUP). The following issues are of grave concern:

1. Overmedication and Lack of Proper Consultation: My mother was overmedicated with heart medication, without proper consultation with cardiology. Instead, a medical resident was involved in providing care that I believe to be negligent.

2. Unnecessary Restraints and Injuries: The nursing staff unnecessarily restrained my elderly mother, resulting in visible bruises on her wrists. This treatment was not only unjustified but also inhumane.

3. Inadequate Nutritional and Hydration Care: Despite my mother being able to eat, food was withheld for over a week. Additionally, her IV hydration needs were not met adequately, which contributed to her suffering.

4. Denied Transfer Request: I requested that my mother be transferred to Thomas Jefferson Hospital, yet my request was denied by Penn without a valid reason.

5. Improper Hospice Referral: HUP sent an unnecessary hospice referral despite my mother's non-terminal condition. Efforts to reverse this referral were unsuccessful and further compounded her distress.

6. Lack of Action from the Department of Health: I reported these concerns to the Department of Health, but unfortunately, no action was taken to address the situation.

My mother endured horrific and inhumane treatment during her time at HUP, and it is deeply troubling that her needs were not met in a manner that respects her dignity and well-being. I urge you to thoroughly investigate these matters and ensure that proper corrective actions are taken to prevent such negligence in the future.

My mother sadly died under the care of Penn Medicine Hospice. She would have been alive today, if not placed against her will on hospice and given meds not aligned with her medical needs.

I will continue to advocate for justice and accountability for my mother and other victims.

The billing department is clearly incompetent, we will be avoiding this hospital in the future.
Absolutely caring & compassionate on the 9th floor. Nurses are top notch ~ I’m so grateful my husband spent many of his last days treated like a loved family member. I am forever grateful.

I began my journey with Hackensack about a year ago. At first, they reached out several times, but I wasn’t yet mentally or physically ready to move forward with a transplant. Then, around five months ago, in February, I made the decision to reactivate myself on the list. The calls resumed, though initially not for the right match. I knew I needed a kidney transplant, but I also knew I had to be patient and make sure everything aligned with what I truly wanted long-term. After multiple consultations with their staff and doctors, we agreed on a plan—and then the calls paused again, as they waited for the exact criteria I had requested. And then, it happened—the perfect call came in. It was exactly what I had been waiting for, and the process officially began.

Hackensack had always been my first choice, but even then, I underestimated just how incredible this facility and its people truly are. From start to finish, everything—from the quality of information, level of service, and care—was flawless. They listened, they understood my unique needs, and they treated me not just as a patient, but as a whole person. This is what true healthcare should look like.

From the moment I walked into the facility, I was met with kindness, attentiveness, and a level of professionalism that exceeded all expectations. Just when I thought they had reached the peak of patient care, they went even further. I’m someone who has a very difficult time with any medical procedure—I can faint just hearing about them. When I say I need sedation even for the smallest things, it’s not a preference—it’s a necessity. They not only respected that but anticipated and accommodated it with care and empathy at every step.

The check-in and check-out processes, follow-ups, and every interaction along the way were handled with the highest standard of care. The doctors are approachable and genuinely listen. They answer questions with patience and provide reassurance and clarity. I feel truly blessed to have been cared for by such a remarkable team. While I would love to name each doctor, nurse, and staff member, there are simply too many to mention. From the medical team to the food service, pharmacy, and even the cleaning staff—everyone was exceptional.

Thank you to every single person who played a role in my care. I am deeply grateful and look forward to continuing my recovery with Hackensack by my side.

(Update 10/28/2025) - October 9, 2025 — Today marks my three-month kidneyversary, and while I’m celebrating it back in the hospital, I’m filled with gratitude and optimism. This past month has been quite a rollercoaster, but I truly feel blessed to have such an incredible team of medical professionals and a facility dedicated to my care and progress. I’m in both their hands and God’s hands—and I fully trust the process.

A few weeks ago, I developed some fluid buildup, and on September 25th, a drain was placed to help remove it. It wasn’t easy carrying it around, but it was a small price to pay for recovery. I was thrilled when my doctor removed it on October 2nd. Shortly after, I developed a hematoma in my abdomen, which lingered for a few weeks—uncomfortable, but again, just another small step in the journey.

When my creatinine levels became unstable, the team ordered a biopsy on October 3rd. By October 7th, the results showed a very mild rejection. Without hesitation, they had me admitted right away to begin a three-day course of IV anti-rejection medication. What amazes me most is how proactive and attentive this team is—they never leave anything to chance. Every concern is addressed immediately, and their 24/7 support gives me peace of mind knowing I’m never alone in this process.

A heartfelt thank you to the entire Hackensack Medical Team for your dedication, care, and compassion. You are truly the best.

The Hackensack staff was incredible during the birth of our daughter and the recovery team. The staff was incredibly effective, patient, and supportive. It was truly above and beyond care, and we couldn't be more grateful to have our daughter there. Special shoutout to our nurse Chrissy - she is exceptional!

My husband went to the ER, and his phone didn’t have internet access. I tried for hours to get information about him but couldn’t reach anyone. The front desk lady was extremely rude, saying that my husband is an adult. Yes, I know that — but I’m his wife and would simply like to have information about my adult husband, the father of my children.

TLDR: DO NOT step a foot into this negligent hospital. I came in at 11:00 pm to the ER and waited in the waiting room for 3 hours before I was taken in. The receptionist at the front was terrible; she didn’t let me finish telling my symptoms before she sent me to get an EKG (with a woman who didn’t even look at me or acknowledge me). After the 3 hours, i was in, they put me on a stretcher IN THE MIDDLE OF THE HALLWAY where about 10+ other patients were, and were basically ignored all night and no one tended to them. I wasn’t seen for another hour, and after the doctor asked for my symptoms and a urine sample, he left, and i didn’t see him again until 5 AM. Then another woman came for insurance information, and finally about 2 hours after a nurse came to take care of me. She was the only thing that made anything better, and was very kind, walking me through everything she was doing. However, I assume it was busy because she disappeared for about 2 hours and left me hooked up to liquids and on valium. Many nurses passed by and no one stopped to help me or talk to me. I was never put in a room, i was left in the hallway for hours. I had an IV of liquids, and so i had to use the bathroom often. There was no one there to unhook me. The very few nurses around kept talking about how they didn’t want to be there, and gossiping /laughing amongst themselves. All that needed to happen at that point was to unhook me from the fluids and take my vitals. It took ANOTHER 2 hours for anyone to see me. Nurse Francis was a godsend, and she was an impeccable nurse, with wonderful bedside manner. She lifted my spirits (as much as they could be lifted in that terrible place) however I would never go there again, and I wouldn’t recommend it to my worst enemy.

Too long, don't want to read? Hackensack University Medical Center's Neuropsychology Team fails its most vulnerable patients with ADHD and Adult Autism. Steer clear of ER care for autistic/psych patients and go to Englewood Hospital instead.

I am rewriting this because my first review did not capture the high-risk factors Hackensack Meridian Health ignored, or could have asked about.

On paper... I should have been prioritized or at least seen.... I already had a “North Bergen Pediatrics” marker on my chart within the legacy primary care systems' HMH had usurped.
I am super super high-risk and in need of neuropsychology at UMHC, and on Medicaid. I came with five medical referrals: four from outside doctors (Englewood Health Neurology, an independent PMHNP, a Holy Name NP and their MD supervisor) and one internal referral from HMH Palisades Primary Care. My family history is pretty high-risk: my mom has schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, my dad has suspected autism.

Despite that, I hit a wall. Calling the number for Hackensack University Medical Center never reaches the actual office. It goes to an answering person, that only "takes a message" When a nurse finally called back, I was told: “We aren't accepting any outside referrals, you must already be referred from within.” When I asked for help, the call was hung up on. Every other route I tried was the same story: no Medicaid accepted, or pay thousands up front out of network.

Yet even despite that, other patients had easily posted reviews for the same doctors that were “not accepting outside referrals”, and got care days-weeks, even months after I had called.

Patient Experience contacted me twice. Both times were the same intake and the same apology. No solutions. No accountability.

Here is the part patients need to know. There is a split between the HMH Neuroscience Institute neuropsychology team and the private neurodevelopmental clinics run by some of the same providers, like Elizabeth Kera, PhD, the head of Neuropsychology. Those private clinics do not take insurance and cater to families who can pay high fees. Yet HMH's own directory still lists those private clinics as numbers to call, while most other doctors only list the Neuroscience Institute or those same private clinics as the contact point.

In practice, it looks like this: wealthier patients pay privately for an autism evaluation first, then use that diagnosis to access follow-up care within HMH and bill insurance or Medicaid. Patients like me, who cannot afford the private assessment, are blocked at the front door.

Hackensack Meridian Health, specifically the neuropsychology department at HUMC, did not prioritize or help an autistic/ADHD patient with clear risk factors and multiple referrals. It felt like a two-tier system that rewards people who can pay cash and shuts out those who cannot. I cannot say or comment on the experience of even stepping into the place to get care; and I hope this review can help others steer clear.

If it is so hard to even receive care for Autism/Neurodevelopmental disorders at this place, imagine how it will be to bring Autistic patients for care in other places at HMH (ER? other care? I don't trust it now....) it's really shameful to me and others to see how HMH neglects it's most needy population.

Orthopedic sports medicine department. 20 Prospect 6th Floor.

Child fractured her elbow past Monday. ER treated her fine with a soft splint and was instructed to call to schedule a follow up for the same week Friday. Called Tues, Wed, Thurs, and Friday to the same excuse that they'll call back to schedule to no avail meanwhile my 2 year old daughter is continuously in the soft splint asking if she's OK on a daily basis.

Come following Monday, finally recieve a call at 7am and instructed to come in at 11am. Came in at 11am to check in, waited 45 minutes in the lobby and still waiting another 45 minutes for the doctor. Surpassing over 90 min waiting time as I'm writing this in the examination room.

Am I in the wrong to be irritated with this crappy service from start to finish? I'll definitely reiterate this review when it's time for the survey.

One of the front desk men named Walter, said he “was going to slap the shit out of you” to me and my mother (previously). The hospital staff are trying to minimize this threat as people arguing but nothing justifies it especially the damage that came with the threat from Walter. The staff also changed their tune once we decided to get police involved. Initially saying he was wrong then saying we were being threatening. How is someone in a wheelchair post surgery threatening? How is me saying you’re not going to speak to my mother any sort of way threatening? We still have to go there for her post op appointments and we’re expected to be comfortable walking into a hospital that allows someone to threaten a patient and their family member? That is not only a crime but illegal for him to do.
After filing a complaint with the HR
rep on the 11th, the patient experience coordinator called my mom (the patient) to tell her to tell me to call him for a follow up. I called him 3 times (9/12, 9/17, and 9/18) leaving voicemails and he NEVER called me back. They obviously do not care enough about patients and would rather protect an employee who threatens a patient and her family. Definitely not comfortable going here or having my mom go to her follow up appointments here but she has no other choice.

Updates as of 10/7: spoke with patient experience. They were very sympathetic to my experience and leveling. For confidentiality, that’s all I will say.

I went to Hackensack Meridian for a simple 30-minute checkup and was shocked with bills totaling $5,668.
All they did was check my blood pressure, urine, a quick scan, and prescribe Motrin  nothing serious at all.
My insurance already paid a few thousand, yet they still demand $1,323 from me, which I cannot afford as an international student.
Instead of helping, they only push payment plans that I still can’t manage  no real support at all.
I deeply regret choosing this hospital,
the charges are outrageous, and I would never recommend this place to anyone.

I was taken there via ambulance despite my request. I asked to be taken to Wayne st.joseph. upon my arrival I was giving three options get on a bed with wheels, get in a wheelchair or I couldn't get helped. So I sat in the wheel chair. Once inside I was stripped of my possessions. I was coherent and well aware of everything that was going on from the time that I got into the accident. In my wallet there was $34 and in my pockets a pack of cigarettes and various other things and in my bookbag there were 2 bottle and various other things. I was lied to about a few things by a few of the staff. As if I was out of my mind which made me a little uncomfortable. And while I was there witnessed other patients being not handled in such a good way😞. I sat and played my part so that I could get outta there without incident. I took the mental abuse and and stayed silent. However upon my release I noticed that my money was missing someone put that I came in there with 1 single dollar my cigarettes were gone not really mad about that. And my bottles weren't in my bag not even mad about that. Don't feel anyway about none of it really just wanted to contribute my experience to Google. And send a Thank you too the staff that handled they jobs Professionally

They sent my account to a law firm that my health insurance paid.  Then when that was proven, they have the audacity to send my child who was a patient that night to the law firm to try and collect that debt.  Your a hospital.  How dare you not only try to double bill but involve a child.
Waiting on phone over a half an hour to find out.If a patient was in there, only to be picked up and hung up on from everything I hear about this hospital.I wouldn't step foot in it.

I want to leave a heartfelt review for one of the best hospitals ever Hackensack Meridian Health Hospital .The doctors were truly amazing, compassionate, and highly professional. Special thanks to all the surgeons and their team who took care of everything with such dedication and professionalism. They were all so kind, respectful, and attentive. The nurses were beyond incredible — they showed unmatched care toward us. They always made sure we were comfortable and that we never lacked anything. Their professionalism was really good.

The physical therapists were highly skilled, supportive, and encouraging, while the social services team guided us seamlessly through each step, offering invaluable assistance. I was also impressed by the staff who focused on mental health and recreational support, offering activities and encouragement to help patients remain positive and engaged.

Everywhere we went, the staff welcomed us with warmth and kindness, always ready to assist. The food was healthy, clean, and nourishing, and the hospital environment was one of the cleanest and most organized I have ever seen. Everything was in order, comfortable, and welcoming .

I cannot thank HMH Hospital team enough for their outstanding care. From the doctors and nurses to the therapists, social workers, and every single staff member — everyone went above and beyond. This hospital is truly a blessing, and I will always remain grateful for everything they did  for us.

I went to Hackensack Hospital for foot surgery on 9/20/2025. Venedicta from 4 link north she was a cna. She was so nice and helpful and went out of her way. We should have more people like her is this world and it would be a better place. And thanks to all the nurses and doctors that took care of me

My son has stayed at EMU dept in the children building a few times and staff treats us amazing.
From housekeeping, food delivery, MAs, EEG techs, RNs, PA and MDs absolutely fantastic.

Stevlana 3-11pm shit she is an angel. Most sweetest lady. Treated my kid like her own, very attentive, always brought good energy if she noticed he was down she would make him smile or make him a special drink if he wasn’t eating too much.
Rns- Balil my kid really connected with him, felt extremely comfortable. Balil would speak to him in terms he actually understood what was happening. Took the time to always make sure we were ok. We will forever be grateful to him.
Mariana, Alma, Sherin, Keri, Alyssa M(from Picu) absolutely OUTSTANDING. HUMC should be honored to have such an amazing employees.
Alyssa D the PA- we will forever be grateful for your kindness, dedication, generosity there are no words to describe how much she means to us. Thank you for being there for us every step of the way and always answering our questions even when it wasn’t your job to do so you always took the time for us.
Dr. E Segal and Dr. Tomycz thank you for never giving up and fighting this battle with our family. For trying everything And anything for a better life.
They don’t make MDs like you guys. Thank you for never rushing our visits, listen to every concern, question we had. Thank you for sitting with us even if the visit took longer and never made us feel like you needed to rush out of the room.

You all will always have a special place in my heart ♥️

From the Costa Family

Thank you.

Went to Hackensack for an emergency and the nurses, staff, and the OBGYN team were amazing! They are so friendly and made me feel comfortable. They also explain what medicine you need and why you need it!

Really a terrible hospital that only cares about money and numbers. The staff are largely unprofessional, abrasive, and often malicious.

Patient experience is a literal joke. “Sorry the staff ignored your dying grandmother for 4 hours and let her get bed sores. Will a parking pass make you shut up?”

Not a surprise that they act this way when their CEO pays himself millions upon millions every year.

Update: Patient Experience gave their usual canned robotic response here. Sorry, not waiting again for a week for a call back only to be told “sorry about that”.
They literally saved my life.

I am in the Orthopedics Unit on the 8th floor, 59 Second Street, Helena Theurer Pavilion.
Since the morning I’ve been complaining about the room temperature and feeling cold and shivery… until now, no response… the nursing reaction here is very slow and tedious… I cover my whole body completely from my feet to the top of my head… and of course, this is not good for breathing.
Khairy Beshara

I had a very bad experience with the call center. I had called and got to someone after being on hold to ask if they can transfer me to the gastroenterology clinic, they say yes then I am on hold again for a while. Never answered, I could hear the phone slam and they hung up on me. I called back and told them what had happened, then they tell me they do not have a gastroenterology clinic. I asked how I was transferred to one then, and they say they could provide me with a referral number for one. I say okay and I am put on hold, then eventually the phone rings again and I am with a different person from the call center. Never got the referral number, just passed on to someone else from the call center and reset. This has been so frustrating and I hope that you guys can improve from this because this is for our health and wellbeing.

My nephew was admitted from the ER due to an accident. The hospital was clean and the care from doctors and nurses was great. We couldn’t be more thankful for the care. However, the downside was after discharge we contacted the social worker Thomas T. because we needed help with two things that were missing from his care. However, the social worker in short told us the hospital has nothing to do with the patient once they are discharged, and he can’t help me nor direct me to help. My nephew had surgery in his liver, however, was not given a follow-up for his liver. Also his insurance covers transportation but a form called 2015 form needs to be filled out. Only the hospital can help with these two things and we’re stuck trying to find help on this.

My first choice! Always! I had my kidney transplant last year, Dr Sultan was my surgeon! Very kind, caring and just all around best of the best! I had no worries going in to surgery! He made me feel at ease! Cheryl was my pre transplant coordinator and she was the best! I wish I could have had her post too! All the nephrologist are great!! Great experience all around! Thank you!

Had a very poor experience after having a total knee replacement. After giving much information on my med allergies, I was given 2 medications that I was allergic to. Evidently Hackensack pharmacist didn't read my history. I was given pain medication which did nothing to alleviate my pain and was in agony for two days. No new med was given for my pain. The nurses only came in to my room when I rang due to severe pain and they gave me the same med that I told them didn't relieve the pain. They never came to see how I was or if I needed anything unless I called them. Being an RN myself, I realized there was no compassion or empathy, this was a disgrace and very disappointing. The food was terrible, dried out sandwich. I didn't eat for 2 days due to the pain and no one checked whether I had even eaten.
Doesn't return phone calls

Horrendous patient care. My mother visited their emergency room late August 2025 and was told by a doctor that she had "too many complaints". She was sent home with tylenol and a day later came back with worsened symptoms and was hospitalized for over a week with a serious viral issue.

Dr Kim in the ER was exactly what ALL Drs should be like. The rarest quality in the medical field is only one Dr Kim’s strongest qualities in my experience: LISTENING. Everyone was overworked but when Dr Kim stopped to see me, he gave his full attention and time. He BELIEVED me and was HONEST in telling me what he can do. Then he asked with COMPASSION  “now what about follow up care?” And gave some referrals that could point us in the right direction. The ability to do that in such a fast paced environment is truly a gift and a skill. I am so grateful for how Dr Kim helped us and his honesty meant so much and was truly grounding when my husband and I weren’t sure of what to think. I also know that no one in that department is thanked enough for what they do. Thank you ALL for your hard work, effort, and willingness to take on the stress of what it takes to care for us. Thank you Dr Kim for getting me to a place where I can have the strength to reach out for follow ups and be able to function towards next steps.

creative✅, courageous✅, compassionate✅, collaborative ✅and connected✅.

THANK YOU! 🙏🏼

I went to the ER on Monday. The Staff nurse who treated me was courteous and friendly and best of all she listened to my concerns. I spent there almost seven hours. Everything went well except at the end. I was told by the pharmacy technician dispensing the prescription to wait for my paperwork discharge and she walked away. I waited for her for about 50 minutes. When she came back she asked me what I was waiting for which it took me by surprise. I spent there 50 unnecessary minutes while I was very exhausted, still in pain and wishing to go home already. They need to do better.

HACKENSACK HOSPITAL is the by far the worst hospital to ever go when sick. I went it on Monday afternoon waited in the waiting room for a long time. Once called I was put in a room because I asked to be put in a room if not they were gonna put me in the hall way. I was told I was being admitted at 10pm. Then I was moved to the hallway waiting area like at 11pm which I have waited in the area for almost 8 hours to be moved to a room upstairs. NEVER AGAIN WILL I GO TO THAT HOSPITAL. Staff was not the greatest either.

This hospital takes a long time to see the patient!! And of course, if all the employees are just on the phone while we wait, they should change the rules and the care would be better!! I've been waiting for 5 hours and they still haven't told me anything.

I ended up in the ER last night after a bad fall. My experience was not positive. To hear the way doctors, nurses, and security casually talked so badly about other patients was scary. They didn’t even blink an eye about making fun of people.

There were some nurses that did treat me kindly and that helped a lot!

When I was discharged there was a miscommunication leaving me to just be left there forgotten about for a little while.

I understand it’s just a job for some but a little empathy goes a long way!

The food was absolutely amazing and it arrived faster than expected when I ordered it for my mom. The staff is very friendly and courteous. The food was cooked well  and when I ordered the person I spoke to made sure I had everything I needed and helped me when I had questions. The woman who brought up the order was also very kind and helpful. She asked if anything else was needed so she can accommodate my mom and my mom really appreciated that. I did too. While I don’t like to be in a hospital, this hospital has my recommendation if you need to go. And that was just about the food alone!

Went to the ER and was helped quickly and thoroughly. Ricky and Tori are the example of what health care should be. They made me feel immensely relieved and were very knowledgeable. I knew I was being cared for properly. Diane was so sweet and brought me a warm blanket and adjusted my bed to make me as comfortable as possible without anyone asking. Thank you for taking care of me I appreciate it so much.
Went to the hospital, took about 6-7 hours but im okay now

At the hospital, I was served fruit with mold, which is harmful to a patient's health. Terrible service in that regard. I told the nurse and showed her the spoiled food, and she just went out to laugh with the other nurses. What a lack of empathy. Not even an apology. I find it very disrespectful that, after serving something rotten, they ended up laughing in my face. Can you imagine what the hospital kitchen must be like?

The waiting time for a kidney transplant is less than other hospitals pulling from the same organ pool.  However the after care is sub par at best.  The understaffed transplant after care team follows a strict after care model, that doesn’t allow for deviations for problematic transplants.  There is little follow up, frequent lack of response and any transplant patient puts themselves at risk for rejection by using this hospital

My complaint is that I have evidence of nursing staff not wanting to teach younger staff, and multiple "clicks". Are we that petty, when staff doesn't want to teach younger staff. WOW. You guys really suck

If you have a death wish for your family members then send them here. If you are looking for life savers, this is not the place to go. No one actually listens to the patient's wishes/complaints or uses clinical judement in developing the plan of care for patients. They were hoping to let my mother just die instead of giving her the antibiotics she desperately needed and instead of respecting her advance directives they pushed their own agenda and decided for her that she should just die. I can not  believe that this place is allowed to even say that they are a hospital. Please, for your life's sake, do not go here.

ADDENDUM: MY MOTHER IS NEARING THE END OF HER LIFE AND EVERY DAY THEY LIE ABOUT HOW LONG FAMILY CAN BE TOGETHER. NO ONE IS ON THE SAME PAGE. ADMINISTRATION LIES TO YOUR FACE OR BECOMES AGGRESSIVE AND HARASSES YOUR FAMILY (Superivsor Rosalee Cain-Francis). THIS IS NOT A HOSPITAL. RUN FAR AWAY.

This hospital may have a reputation as being in a “good area” of New Jersey, but my experience has been the opposite. I made a simple request for my own medical record, which I am legally entitled to receive under federal law (HIPAA). Instead of providing it, the staff have been unresponsive, evasive, and appear to be either hiding the record or intentionally withholding it from me.

No patient should have to fight tooth and nail to access their own medical information. This level of incompetence and lack of transparency raises serious concerns about how this hospital operates. If they cannot handle something as basic as a records request, I would be extremely cautious about trusting them with actual medical care.
Everyone at the hospital was so kind and helpful from the beginning to the end. They made me feel that I mattered, especially in a time of need. Thank you all. 😊
WORSE HOSPITAL OF ALL? HAD TO HAVE A CAT SCAN N SAT IN HALLWAY FOR 4 HOURS? NEVER WILL COME HERE AGAIN!!  AND 30+ PEOPLE IN LINE TO CHECK IN!!😡😡

I had a very upsetting experience at Hackensack University Medical Center WOMEN’S HOSPITAL with a lobby desk staff member named WILLIAM. My boyfriend and I came to visit my sister who just gave birth. William was extremely rude, raised his voice, ignored our questions, and even threatened to call security. I was just asking simple questions as a first-time visitor, and his aggressive behavior caused me panic and anxiety.

His attitude felt discriminatory toward my brother-in-law, who struggles with English. Visiting my newborn niece should have been a happy experience, but William’s hostility completely ruined it. I hope the hospital addresses this behavior and provides proper staff training.
Dr. Abid was amazing very with my mother in law/mom. Very thorough and reassuring.
Just had same day surgery and let me tell you…every person was as nice and knowledgeable as the next.  Top notch care!
Great hospital highly recommend everybody good nurses doctors. So nice

I want to say that I am so upset at how down hill this hospital has gone! My daughter was her as a premie and I gave this hospital all the praise but after my experience this past Tuesday I’m beyond upset! I went to the hospital not feeling well at all I explained my symptoms to the doctor and the doctor ordered an ultrasound of only one part of my abdomen when I said my pain travels from one side to the next and my back. The doctor told me my bw and UA was fine come to find out when I got to my pcp the next day I have a UTI ! Why would the doctor at the hospital tell me everything is fine when it’s not!!!! I’m so upset! Mind you I was left a big black and blue from an IV put in my arm for the second time. The first time the nurse tried to put it on the side of my wrist and was unsuccessful she did not take it out just left it there while it was hurting and tried higher in my arm !!! The only good part of my visit was when they took my vitals at the beginning when you check in at first that nurse was amazing she’s the only one that gets 5 stars in my opinion. To her thank you!

I was having epigastric pain this past weekend and I came to the ER early Saturday morning. The process was pretty quick and I was brought into a room in the ER. I was starting to feel nauseous but they gave me medications . Afterwards I was brought into the ultrasound department and discovered I had large stones in my gallbladder. The Dr. That works with Dr. Mazpule consulted with me about this and explained thoroughly how I needed to be admitted and the surgery process. The ER nurse and np really took great care of me when I was there. I was brought into the Helena theurer pavilion , which was beautiful,  I thought I was walking into a hotel suite. The nurse Simone and the night nurse ( i forgot her name) were both great I am so glad I had them taking care of me. They were sweethearts and they really cared. The next morning I was brought into the OR which was state of the art. The CRNA and the OR nurse were very nice also. Overall even though I was in pain , I was treated very well. Thank you, Hackensack

Absolutely disgusted by the way i was treated on the phone. Asked a simple question and all i got was attitude and rudeness. I have something serious going on and now im not even going to use this place anymore! extremely unprofessional

Excellent Service! ER Triage nurse saw me within 15 minutes after walking thru the door. 5 minutes later moved into a very full ER. First nurse took history, took vitals hooked up to Heart , Blood pressure O2 monitor,. 2 ER doctors ordered X-Ray and blood labs 10 minutes later. Nurse placed IV hung bags of Medicines without delay. Medicines kicked in stats settled down felt much better. Discharged 2 hours later with diagnosis RX, and follow up with Dr.

I went to the ER back in June of 2024 as I had been vomiting nonstop for 5 days straight. I couldn't even keep any water down, let alone food. The ER was a disaster and they had me go from waiting room to waiting room. I was sitting upright in a bed for maybe 20 min max and then back to the waiting room. They gave me so many different meds and IV drips and nothing was helping. In the end, they basically gave me a drug that made me feel loopy, but didn't help alleviate the nausea and discharged me. Then they charged me $7500 for making me sit in a cold waiting room for 7 hours and giving me a bunch of IV fluids so I don't die. I left the hospital not feeling any better than when I first got there. Not only that, billing has been an absolute nightmare. I had 2 insurances which they weren't billing properly. I called them 8+ times only to have the phone outsourced to the Philippines and they didn't know what they were talking about. They kept telling me to wait 4-6 weeks for a resolution between each call. Long story short, they sent me a bill, I financed the balance with Commerce bank. A couple months ago, they refunded Commerce bank the full amount financed and I received a refund from Commerce for the amount I paid so far. Today, a year plus since my visit, I received my final bill. Now they're recharging me $1000+. What the heck is going on with their billing??
Absolute worst, had a tube up my nose ro stomacj for over 17 hours without it being turned on. Now getting a bill for 63.44 for reading a chart. Go anywhere else but here.

I usually don't post any negative reviews. But this one incident made me post it. Worst customer service and useless patient registration department. I took my kid for knee xray. Very clearly asked how much it may cost, they said that they have no idea. So asked how much amount will they send to insurance and they said that they have no idea. Finally when the bill came, it was 1000 USD for just xray that I have to pay.

To me its lack of transparency and cheating.

Registration staff is either lazy or un-knowledgeable or cheaters. Has to be one of these. So if you can avoid, then avoid or don't get anything done unless you have confirm numbers shared with you or unless you have un-limited money.

My mom has spent alot of time here and they cannot for the life of them figure out pain meds. It is the most BASIC part of comfort yet they miss meds by hours, do not update proper medication, and communicate. It is incredibly frustrating to have your loved one be in pain because of incompetence.

I had ventral hernia surgery on July 24. Everything went smoothly. The doctors, nurses and staff were wonderful. A big shoutout to my surgeon, Dr. Stephen Pereira. He is not only a brilliant surgeon but a super nice guy! His fellow Dr. Michael Stoltz was equally impressive and friendly. The anesthesiologist, Dr. Seem relaxed me and the operating room staff were awesome. A big shoutout out to HMH. I will recommend this hospital to everyone.
They told me really good hospital I have been waiting 4 hours shame we in 2026

I have been trying to get a $25 over payment from a doctors visit for one year now, ever time I call I get the same answer that it is under review, when I ask to speak to someone to find out when I can receive my money I am told there is on one else I can talk to, I feel that one year to review a claim is a bit long.I have been holding off going to my doctor because every time I do they delay my payment again.I contacted the billing department today 7/29/25 and was told my over payment was still pending this is after a week ago I was told by the Patient Experience Department that they would follow up, so I still don’t have an answer when I will be receiving my over payment check and also was told there is no one else I can talk to about this issue.
Rooms are very comfortable,everything is nice and clean.The only hospital infection myself safe!

If I could give this hospital a 10/10 I would. Went in for stomach pain and was within 3 hours. The whole staff from the patient registrar to the nurses and doctor were very kind and professional. Everyone greeted with a smile making my anxious state at ease. Unfortunately my g.i issues have to be resolved with a gastroenterologist but it’s no surprise why Hackensack Hospital was voted #1 in New Jersey.

So for starters i'll start off with the cons :
For the most part the staff / nurses & surgeon
were very passive aggressive toward me being in excruciating pain. I had an emergency Gallbladder removal which is very painful to recover from. I know that there has been a few cases of people having a fast healing process from this surgery but I am not one of them nor am I the first or last! My abdominal area was completely sore to the point where I couldnt move that much even if I tried. I expressed this to the doctor and instead of him being empathetic towards my pain he made a mockery of it. Saying "well usually people heal very quickly" and that he knew someone that went to the work the same day. Kudos to them but respectfully , I dont give a damn that is not how you treat a patient , period!

Secondly , I was greeted literally the day after my surgery with a loud nursing assistant that was yelling at me to get out of bed and to sit up in a chair. I've done a lot of research on this procedure im damn near obsessed with the "ends and outs" because its my new reality! Yes , moving and allowing my body to get some type of motion is important! However, why was I being spoken to as if I didn't just have a surgery done (an organ taking out of my body). Then , to make matters worse she offered no assistance to help me get out of bed at all! All she did was slap a white cottony binder to support my body across the room!

Thirdly , I think its very important to mention that I am a Black woman and yes this plays a big part on how im treated. No matter how kind or receptive I am I'm still unfortunately met with harmful micro aggressive BS! Another thing I also expressed to them is that my current living quarters has a eight flight walk up with no elevator! Guess what! They had me walk up a whole bunch of stairs for "physical therapy".

Lastly , The surgeon discharged me without my consent. I know that insurance plays a big part in this which is why I do have it! ;  But these clowns didnt even put my card in the system! So the whole entire time I was listed as a non insured patient. I told him that I am a single woman and I just need a few more days to heal and he went right along and discharged me ! No sentiments or anything! My whole experience after surgery just seemed very robotic and sad. Also , I have to mention that I was told prior to the procedure that I wouldn't be rushed out and that they would totally understand if I needed more time.

Now lets get into the Pros:

The pros are the hospital room looked very much like a hotel. Big window to enjoy sunrises and sunsets, big flat screen TV , Impeccably clean room and a bathroom that was inside of my assigned room as well. Also , the TV had a variety of channels making my stay somewhat bearable. Another pro was the food. It was  definitely edible and they had a feature that allowed you to order food up once you scanned the QR Code.

Aesthetically my room didnt feel like a hospital room at all I felt like I was in a 3-4 star hotel that had a hospital bed in it. I appreciated that!

Also , the first nurse I was assigned to was very caring and had a real personality. Unfortunately, I was in too much pain to get everyone's name but ill definitely be doing a full YouTube video on my experience and including the surgeons name for sure! I also plan on talking to a patient advocate tomorrow.
This is a great  hospital
They gave  me a popsicle after my surgery and a Lego set

My mother was admitted to this hospital for a stem cell transplant in April of 2024. From the moment she was admitted it was one nightmare after another. They couldn’t get the port in the normal spot so they ended up placing it in her neck. Shortly after they began chemo her eye swelled shut and they couldn’t figure out the cause or how to treat it. She then started to complain of having trouble breathing. All the doctors brushed it off telling her it was normal and it was anxiety. It got to the point that she couldn’t get out of bed without having a massive panic attack because she could not breathe when she stood up. They gaslit her and told her it was all in her head and to push through. She then died suddenly in the middle of the night, and the hospital did not want to perform an autopsy. Instead they asked us to sign a form to test her for Covid that basically said if she tested positive it would be ruled her cause of death. We refused to sign and instead pushed for an autopsy that we would pay for. The autopsy revealed her cause of death was fluid in her chest cavity, multiple cups full of it, that led to her heart stopping. So for weeks she complained she could not breathe, they gaslit her saying it was in her head and upped her anxiety meds, and then she ended up dying from their lack of intervention. The doctor also happened to be away the week she passed, and when she returned she called us saying she was shocked. We were not since we knew she was declining for weeks and brought it to their attention multiple times. Do not go to this hospital.
Medical care is great, BUT the people on the front desk that hand visitors are the absolute worst, Rude, disrespectful, horrible people.
Got nothing but complaints about this place. If I ever want to die I'll just go here

Great facility
Also a shout to the cafeteria wow 😍
Amazing food had the lamb stew and rice yesterday and the pizzas were better then must pizzerias
Lovely helpful staff as well
The only downside is that parking is 8 bucks
No validated parking 🫤

A disappointing  experience from parking that cost 8 dollars with scary elevatrs..to an awful checking in system with non responsive check in clerks..to a filty toilet on the west wing that is so cold your water might freeze ..staff unavailability on the weekend.
Most consternation was the disorganized and dissassociative communication from the various so called teams..patient experience will answer this .then we have palliative care..then we care companions..then we doctors that come and go..we talked to 10..then the residents..then the nurses who are the last to know..a dreadful experience...You Far better off at Emglewood..
Overall they are forcing the patient to fit their antiquated systems..

I went there with my husband for what we would find out to be a kidney stone. In my past experiences at other emergency rooms I was used to being dismissed or not given answers. That wasn't the case at all here. The woman who saw us after checking my husband and his symptoms laid out exactly what it could be as well as explaining to us what kind of testing we would be doing and why. It was very refreshing. There isn't a lot of space here though and instead of a bed you have to wait in chairs or what seems to be a wheel chair if you're unable to move on your own. That I don't fault from the hospital as I think it honestly comes down to space and Hackensack being a busy place. Ultimately it's a hospital that listened and listened well!

Review from visit on July 2023. Everyone, literally everyone was very nice, helpful, super kind and caring. I am greatful and super thankful for Dr. Ditkowsky (supervising DR) and his team amazing, including Dr. Patrick (Resident DR) they were an AMAZING TEAM, I was super fortunate to have gotten them as my care team during my visit.

I also did notice how Dr. Ditkowsky treated his group of Resident Doctors, with such respect, kindness and trust.

There were 3 things I disliked about my visit:

1: My discharge forms state my BP was 170/65 (never! In my life had my BP gone over 130, I am always on the lower side) when the last ER TECH/Nurse took my vitals both my husband and I saw it at 120/65, the ER TECH wrote in a piece of paper too.

I walked in to HUMC my initial vitals show my BP at 107/(over something I can not recall) and for it to shoot to 170 during my ER visit, that is not normal, the that fact that it was overlooked, is upsetting. How could I be let out of the hospital with a BP that was at 109 when I walked in and shooting up to 170 within hours?

What makes me more upset, is that it is now noted in EPIC as part of my BP history and it is not accurate at all for future providers treating me at this hospital or any offices affiliated.

I understand this could have been an honest error, they probably put someone else’s BP in my chart but they should’ve realized this big error and fixed it promptly.

I am assuming it should have gone through MULTIPLE eyes prior to me being discharged, the ER TECH (took the vitals), nurse should have supervised it, treating Doctors should have triple supervised it prior to being discharged, unfortunately it was to late when I noticed, I was in my car and going back home (although I though about returning to the hospital and making them aware).

2: This I am 50/50 on but my bloodwork was drawn at 4:00pm, the nurse put it behind my bed in case the DR ordered blood work which I know they didn’t (or at least it was not mentioned to me).

I checked behind my bed around 11:00p (which was supposed to be my initial discharge time) my blood was still behind me.

I ended up getting discharged at around 1:00a due to excruciating pain I experienced during the initial 11:00p discharge attempt.

How does my discharge papers have blood work results when at 11:00p my blood work was still behind me…..on my bed?

This is why I am 50/50, maybe the nurse took it after 11:00p, realizing it was never sent for testing. But to be honest, I am not 100% sure being I did not check after.

Reading the blood work today, I compared it with a recent bloodwork the week prior, some off the numbers that should be off (that have been off and abnormal for months) were normal.

3: I was taken from the ER waiting to Area E where I was put on a stretcher and wheeled over. The poor ER ETCH did not know where to put me (it was a Monday and super, super busy) finally we found a spot! she put in front of the door of the “Shock, Trauma and Resuscitation” department.

As the night continued a lot of the rooms became available but yet no one in the hall was being moved to these available rooms.

But I figured there are probably a lot patients in the ER waiting area and it is easier to put them directly in a room than transferring the patients from the halls to the rooms having to update the charts, can cause confusion between the nurses and Doctors.

When I left at 1:00a, I walked a little and notice A LOT of rooms empty, the ER waiting area died down a lot and it was much less busier for the nurses in Area E, that would have been a great time to make these patients in the hall way much more comfortable to vomit, complain loudly about there pain, cough etc. in a much more private room.

But again, the Doctors and Staff were extremely amazing and I am super happy with the care, compassion, bed-side manner and kindness of everyone! Above and beyond care provider and staff wise and that made me super happy, relaxed and calm.

I would like to express my deepest gratitude to HMH Bariatric and Women’s Health for the exceptional care I received throughout my recent surgical journey.

I underwent robotic gynecologic surgery performed by Dr. Adam Shoman, and I can confidently say he is one of the most skilled, compassionate, and dedicated physicians in the country. From my very first appointment, Dr. Shoman took the time to listen, explain, and reassure me. His calm demeanor and expertise gave me complete confidence and peace of mind.

His incredible team mirrored that same excellence. From the clinic to the hospital stay and all the way through discharge, I felt genuinely supported and cared for every step of the way.

In the PACU, Nurse Victoria was a comforting and nurturing presence. Her kindness and attentiveness during my immediate recovery meant so much to me. On the surgical floor, Nurses Mary and Jennifer were outstanding—proactive, knowledgeable, and deeply compassionate.

A special thank you to Maggie, Daniella, and Ismenia, the nursing assistants who stayed by my side during the most difficult parts of my recovery. Their patience, care, and encouragement helped me more than words can express.

If you are seeking minimally invasive gynecologic surgery, I wholeheartedly recommend Dr. Shoman and his team. Their expertise, warmth, and patient-centered approach make all the difference.
Thank you .
Anna D

ABSOLUTLY NOT!!! If you have an elderly loved one stay away! My Grandfather was admitted to the hospital while I was away on business and over the course of 7 days I called this hospital over 20 times and not one of those phone calls was returned ( yes I was the point of contact for him) I only received a phone call to clear him for his MRI one time I called his room and someone in the background was yelling at him. He was released back to his nursing home not being able to eat or swallow  he had lost 10 pounds over the course of those 7 days . And now days after being released from the hospital he has passed away. In under a month this man went from being able to be released from the nursing home to come back to to being dead. Meanwhile I'm still waiting on a call back to find out what happened in the hospital for this to happen. We went from an infected toe to dead in two weeks...5 Years ago this happened to my Grandmother at this hospital she went in for something minor and ended up dead.. Something isn't right here the State needs to investigate.

2 Months for initial appointment .
Dr did not Listen or read my medical history. Suggested Surgery? “ I am a surgeon “.
Televisit came in from private cell.
PA had not read my medical history.
I had to call the office to schedule next appointment,because PA did not have access to system From cell phone.
Called office several times did not speak to anyone.
Final call I was informed “ We have NO appointments available for 2 months “..thats as far as I goes “.

..”nobody goes there anymore It’s too crowded!”(Yogi Berra)
I have found another provider
I was a visitor across 2 days and the treatment I received has very ample and generous. If I were to go to a different hospital, I probably wouldn’t be able to walk.

My father got his colon, prostate, and lymph nodes removed here. The staff care was exceptional. One person especially stood out; Millie, the RN who was working the evening of June 24th on the operating floor 2. She remembered our family member's names and my father's details the following afternoon when we arrived and she was still working. She worked a double shift and keep a radiant, warm smile. She took so much care of everyone on the floor. I  can only hope this review reaches management so she gets the praise she deserves.

Horrible polices. They care more about business than patient care. Too many administrators and policies inconveniencing patients rather than providing adequate and personalized medical care. As a medical professional I am not ignorant to business of medicine.  Horrible experience in fetal ultrasound. Would not let us take a picture of our future child due to “hospital policies”. I guarantee the legal team and administrators all have pictures of their ultrasounds. HMH policies take the joy out of pregnancy, and really know how to ruin the moment of hearing the first heart sounds. Horrible experience. Will go elsewhere and will not be recommending any of other patients use their system. If you want personalized medical care, go elsewhere. If you want to line the CEO and administrators pockets go to HMH business care system

Let me start by saying as a medical professional myself, this is by far the worse hospital, very disappointed with how I got treated a week ago. I went to the ER on 6/11/25 with labor pains, they checked and I was 3cm dilated, I was given Tylenol  IV and IV fluids and was sent home regardless of me telling them the Tylenol didn’t work, I was sent home in pain. On Friday 6/13/25 the pain got so intense, my doctor sent me back to the ER, given Tylenol again and again I told them it’s not working and I was still 3cm dilated. No one listens to me and as a FTM, I was hoping to get a better care.
They were going to send me home until my baby’s HR starts dropping, my doctor told them to monitor me overnight. I asked them if I can get something stronger because obviously no one believes that I was contracting. Epidural wasn’t offered, they told me I can Morphine and because i trust these professionals and I was in so much pain, I took it and that’s the option. Unbelievable.
Saturday 6/14/25, I woke up with more intense pain, I felt like my water broke, I asked the nurse and she said “no it can be from the cervix check from the night before “. I was so uncomfortable, the pain was 1min long. The NP came in to do a 30 mins US for fluids, while I was in pain.i kept asking them for something for the pain, nothing was offered, they told me to wait on my doctor to come in to see me. I’m crying while writing this right now.
I waited and waited in pain. NOTHING. I went on the toilet, I saw mucus plug with some blood, again I don’t know what this means so I asked the nurse and she kept saying it’s from the cervix check. I found myself pushing on the toilet when the pain starts, the nurse told me to lay in bed and my doctor walked in same time, cervix check me right away, the baby’s head was right there. I went straight into another room to deliver.
My point is this was negligence, and my pain was dismissive. I would not come here again to deliver my next child.
